TITLE: Oxidative cross-coupling of methane and toluene over LiCl-added Co sub 3 O sub 4
AUTHORS: Otsuka, Kiyoshi; Hatano, Masaharu; Amaya, Tohru
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 03 NATURAL GAS; 02 PETROLEUM; COBALT OXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; LITHIUM CHLORIDES; METHANE; OXIDATION; TOLUENE; METHYLATION; ALKYLATED AROMATICS; CATALYTIC REFORMING; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; STYRENE; SYNTHESIS; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKANES; AROMATICS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; COBALT COMPOUNDS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; LITHIUM COMPOUNDS; LITHIUM HALIDES; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; REFORMER PROCESSES; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 030300 - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing; 020400 - Petroleum- Processing
DESCRIPTION: A LiCl-added Co{sub 3}O{sub 4} has been found to be one of the most active catalysts for oxidative cross-coupling of methane and toluene. The reaction was examined at temperatures higher than 823 K and at a higher methane/toluene ratio than 10. In order to understand the whole network of this reaction, the kinetic studies on the homocoupling of each reactant have been carried out. The results suggested a Langmuir-Hinshelwood type mechanism for both reactants; i.e., the rate-determining step is at the abstraction of hydrogen from methane or from toluene, forming methyl or benzyl species on the surface, respectively, or liberating the corresponding alkyl radicals into the gas phase. The coupling of the alkyl intermediates produces each coupling product, i.e., C{sub 2} and C{sub 14} compounds. Under methane and toluene cofeed conditions, the formation of C{sub 8} compounds (ethyl-benzene and styrene) can be explained in terms of the coupling of methyl and benzyl intermediates. Although a large difference between the reactivities of methane and toluene made it difficult to carry out the kinetic studies on the cross-coupling of methane and toluene, the results were well interpreted in terms of the reaction mechanisms proposed for the oxidation of methane and that of toluene.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 137:2

TITLE: Pervaporation of water/ethanol mixtures by an aromatic polyetherimide membrane
AUTHORS: Huang, R Y.M.; Feng, Xianshe
SUBJECT: 09 BIOMASS FUELS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; ETHANOL; MEMBRANE TRANSPORT; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; FABRICATION; FLOWSHEETS; IMIDES; MEMBRANES; OPERATION; PERFORMANCE; PERMEABILITY; POLYMERS; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; QUANTITY RATIO; SORPTION; SORPTIVE PROPERTIES; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALCOHOLS; DATA; DIAGRAMS; DISPERSIONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; MIXTURES; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; SOLUTIONS; SURFACE PROPERTIES; 090900* - Biomass Fuels- Processing- (1990-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400105 - Separation Procedures
DESCRIPTION: The pervaporation of water/ethanol mixtures through an aromatic polyetherimide membrane was attempted. The membrane was laboratory prepared using the solution casting technique. The sorption characteristics in relation to pervaporation were also studied. It was found that the preferential sorption was altered when the liquid composition was changed, whereas the water component permeated through the membrane preferentially over the whole range of feed mixture compositions. The experimental results were analyzed in terms of sorption ratio and permeation ratio to characterize nonideality of sorption and pervaporation. The effects of some operating parameters, including temperature, feed concentration, and permeate pressure, on the pervaporation performance were also investigated.
RELATION: Journal Name: Separation Science and Technology; (United States); Journal Volume: 27:12

TITLE: The transient species formed over Ru-RuO sub x /TiO sub 2 catalyst in the CO and CO + H sub 2 interaction: FTIR spectroscopic study
AUTHORS: Gupta, N M; Kamble, V S; Iyer, R M; Thampi, K R; Graetzel, M
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; CHEMISORPTION; METHANATION; HYDROGEN; RUTHENIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; SORPTIVE PROPERTIES; RUTHENIUM OXIDES; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; CARBONYLS; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CATALYSTS; FOURIER TRANSFORMATION; HYDROGENATION; INFRARED RADIATION; METHYLENE RADICALS; PROMOTERS; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; SURFACE PROPERTIES; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; TITANIUM OXIDES; VALENCE; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ELEMENTS; INTEGRAL TRANSFORMATIONS; METALS; NONMETALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; RADIATIONS; RADICALS; REFRACTORY METAL COMPOUNDS; RUTHENIUM COMPOUNDS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SORPTION; SPECTROSCOPY; TITANIUM COMPOUNDS; TRANSFORMATIONS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: At least six C-O stretch vibrational bands at around 2,142, 2,132, 2,085, 2,050, 1,995, and 1,950 cm{sup {minus}1} were detected in the room temperature adsorption of both CO and CO + H{sub 2} over titania-supported partially reduced ruthenium. These bands were identifiable with the reported multicarbonyl and the linear-bonded monocarbonyl species and indicate that the different oxidation states of ruthenium serve as independent CO chemisorption sites which may coexist on a real catalyst surface at a particular temperature. The effect of exposure temperature and that of the postexposure thermal annealing on CO vibrational bands suggest that the multicarbonyl species transform progressively to monocarbonyl forms which are in turn identified as precursors to the methylene groups in the presence of hydrogen. Though the presence of hydrogen had no apparent effect on the shape and the frequency of different C-O stretch bands, CO + H{sub 2} interaction at temperatures above 400 K gave rise to hydrocarbon structures consisting of a chain of methylene groups. The presence of these hydrocarbon chains blocking binding sites responsible for v{sub CO} = 2,050 cm{sup {minus}1} monocarbonyl species. The promotional effect of oxidized ruthenium and the role of oxygenated surface complexes in CO methanation are discussed in light of the present results.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 137:2

TITLE: Permselective properties for aqueous ethanol solutions through copolymer membranes from benzyl methacrylate and polyethylene glycol dimethacrylate
AUTHORS: Okuno, Hiroshi; Okado, Takashi; Matsumoto, Akira; Oiwa, Masayoshi; Uragami, Tadashi
SUBJECT: 09 BIOMASS FUELS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; ETHANOL; MEMBRANE TRANSPORT; MEMBRANES; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; PERFORMANCE; ACRYLATES; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; GAS CHROMATOGRAPHY; MORPHOLOGY; PERMEABILITY; POLYETHYLENE GLYCOLS; POLYMERIZATION; POLYMERS; QUANTITY RATIO; SCANNING ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; SWELLING; ALCOHOLS; CARBOXYLIC ACID SALTS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMATOGRAPHY; DATA; DISPERSIONS; ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; GLYCOLS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; MICROSCOPY; MIXTURES; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC POLYMERS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SOLUTIONS; SYNTHESIS; 090900* - Biomass Fuels- Processing- (1990-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400105 - Separation Procedures
DESCRIPTION: Copolymer membranes prepared by bulk copolymerization of polyethylene glycol dimethacrylates of three different degrees of polymerization as macromonomer and benzyl methacrylate as comonomer were used for the separation of aqueous ethanol solutions in both pervaporation and evapomeation. The copolymer membranes preferentially permeated water from an aqueous ethanol solutions in both pervaporation and evapomeation. The copolymer membranes preferentially permeated water from an aqueous ethanol solution in evapomeation. In pervaporation, ethanol was predominantly permeated from an aqueous ethanol solution through the copolymer membranes containing a long polyethylene glycol (PEG) chain above about 20 wt% PEG content in a copolymer. This result was attributed to a remarkable swelling of the copolymer membrane containing a long PEG chain by the aqueous ethanol solution in pervaporation. In evapomeation, both the separation factors and the permeation rates through these membranes are not much affected by the ethanol concentration in the feed vapor. In pervaporation, they were significantly dependent on the ethanol concentration in the feed solution. The above results are discussed from the viewpoint of the physical structure of the membrane in evapomeation and pervaporation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Separation Science and Technology; (United States); Journal Volume: 27:12

TITLE: In situ solid-state NMR study of methanol-to-gasoline chemistry in zeolite HZSM-5
AUTHORS: Munson, E J; Kheir, A A; Lazo, N D; Haw, J F
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 40 CHEMISTRY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 66 PHYSICS; MOBIL M-GASOLINE PROCESS; NMR SPECTRA; ZEOLITES; METHANOL; GASOLINE; CATALYSTS; PH VALUE
DESCRIPTION: This paper uses {sup 13}C solid-state NMR to study the chemistry of a variety of absorbates related to the methanol-to-gasoline process. This study has resulted in a better understanding of the chemical reaction occurring inside the zeolite HZSM-5 used in this process. It is shown that ethylene is the first olefin formed and ethyl methyl ether is also formed during this hydrocarbon synthesis on zeolite HZSM-5.

TITLE: sup 13 C NMR studies of CO adsorbed on supported rhodium catalysts: Effects of alkali promotion
AUTHORS: Compton, D B; Root, T W
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; ADSORPTION; RHODIUM; SORPTIVE PROPERTIES; CARBON 13; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CATALYSTS; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; FISCHER-TROPSCH SYNTHESIS; NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE; POTASSIUM; PROMOTERS; QUANTITY RATIO; SILICON OXIDES; SURFACE PROPERTIES; ALKALI METALS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON ISOTOPES; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; EVEN-ODD NUCLEI; ISOTOPES; LIGHT NUCLEI; MAGNETIC RESONANCE; METALS; NUCLEI; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; RESONANCE; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SORPTION; STABLE ISOTOPES; SYNTHESIS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Changes in the chemical properties of silica-supported Rh catalysts on potassium promotion are observed in the {sup 13}C NMR spectra of adsorbed CO. Catalysts prepared by incipient wetness with 2.5% Rh loading and Rh:K ratios of 1:0, 3:1, and 1:3 show relatively constant CO adsorption site character but have large changes in relative populations of linear, bridging, isolated dicarbonyl, and metal-bound CO. Back-bonded metal electrons on CO produce a Gaussian peak near 275 ppm and indicate a transition to metallic behavior of the underlying Rh at high promotion levels. Purely electrostatic effects are shown to be too small to cause the shifts reported for IR and NMR peak positions. Alkali promotion inhibits the breakup of Rh particles and formation of isolated dicarbonyl sites during CO adsorption, probably by the conversion of surface {minus}OH groups to {minus}OK groups.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 137:1

TITLE: AlNbO oxides as new supports for hydrocarbon oxidation II. Catalytic properties of VO sub x -grafted AlNbO oxides
AUTHORS: Oliveira, P.G. Pries de; Eon, J G; Volta, J C
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 02 PETROLEUM; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; NIOBATES; PROPANE; DEHYDROGENATION; PROPANOLS; DECOMPOSITION; PROPYLENE; SYNTHESIS; VANADIUM OXIDES; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; CALCINATION; CATALYSIS; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; FOURIER TRANSFORMATION; HYDROXYL RADICALS; INFRARED RADIATION; PH VALUE; PHOTOELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; SCANNING ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; STOICHIOMETRY; TRANSMISSION ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; ULTRAVIOLET RADIATION; VANADIUM 51; VISIBLE RADIATION; X-RAY SPECTROSCOPY; ALCOHOLS; ALKANES; ALKENES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INTEGRAL TRANSFORMATIONS; INTERMEDIATE MASS NUCLEI; ISOTOPES; MICROSCOPY; NIOBIUM COMPOUNDS; NUCLEI; ODD-EVEN NUCLEI; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PYROLYSIS; RADIATIONS; RADICALS; REFRACTORY METAL COMPOUNDS; SPECTROSCOPY; STABLE ISOTOPES; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TRANSFORMATIONS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; VANADIUM COMPOUNDS; VANADIUM ISOTOPES; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 020400 - Petroleum- Processing
DESCRIPTION: Vanadium oxides were immobilized by grafting VOCl{sub 3} on AlNbO oxides calcined between 500 and 750 C. Chemical analysis, XPS, and STEM measurements suggest an incomplete but homogeneous stoichiometric reaction between superficial hydroxyl groups and vanadyl oxychloride. By FTIR studies, it is observed that the interaction involves preferentially basic hydroxyl groups bonded to aluminium cations. UV-visible spectra show that mainly V{sup 5+} is present at the solid surface. Corresponding spectra are compatible with tetrahedral symmetry, in agreement with a previous {sup 51}V NMR investigation. The acido-basic properties of the catalyst were tested by isopropanol decomposition and compared with the corresponding supports. It has been observed that basicity is higher for VO{sub x} grafted on AlBnO oxide calcined at high temperature and corresponding to the AlNbO{sub 4} structure. VO{sub x} grafted on AlNbO oxides calcined at intermediate temperatures and corresponding to a AlNbO disorganized structure present a good selectivity for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane into propene. It has been observed that, for both reactions, the turnover number increases with the temperature of calcination of the catalysts. The reactivity of the aluminium niobiate support.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 137:1

TITLE: Superequilibrium conversion of methane to acetylene under vibrational-translational nonequilibrium conditions
AUTHORS: Macheret, S O; Melik-Aslanova, T A; Potapkin, B V
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 03 NATURAL GAS; 40 CHEMISTRY; ACETYLENE; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; CHEMICAL REACTION YIELD; METHANE; EQUILIBRIUM; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS
DESCRIPTION: Using as an example the conversion of methane to acetylene, the possibility of increasing the yield of useful product and reduction in energy expenditure is investigated when vibrational-translational nonequilibrium is induced in a reaction system. An analysis of a simplified kinetic scheme is carried out. It is shown that even a small vibrational perturbation of the reagents leads to a substantial increase in the acetylene yield and reduction in its energy cost. Increasing the degree of nonequilibrium (ratio of the vibrational to translational temperatures) above a certain threshold is not worthwhile since further increase does not lead to an increase in the yield of useful product. 9 refs., 1 fig.
RELATION: Journal Name: High Energy Chemistry; Journal Volume: 26; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: Sep 1992; TN: Translated from Khimiya Vysokikh Energii; 26: No. 2, 159-162(Mar-Apr 1992)

TITLE: Direct synthesis of phenol from benzene during O[sub 2]-H[sub 2] fuel cell reactions
AUTHORS: Otsuka, K; Kunieda, M; Yamagata, H
SUBJECT: 30 DIRECT ENERGY CONVERSION; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; BENZENE; PARTIAL OXIDATION PROCESSES; CATHODES; MATERIALS TESTING; FUEL CELLS; PHENOLS; SYNTHESIS; CARBON BLACK; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CYCLOHEXANE; GRAPHITE; HYDROXYL RADICALS; TOLUENE; USES; WHISKERS; ALKANES; ALKYLATED AROMATICS; AROMATICS; CARBON; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CRYSTALS; CYCLOALKANES; DIRECT ENERGY CONVERTERS; ELECTROCHEMICAL CELLS; ELECTRODES; ELEMENTAL MINERALS; ELEMENTS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; MINERALS; MONOCRYSTALS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; RADICALS; REACTION KINETICS; TESTING; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; 300505* - Fuel Cells- Electrochemistry, Mass Transfer & Thermodynamics; 300504 - Fuel Cells- Applications; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: In this paper partial oxidation of benzene to phenol at the cathode is demonstrated at room temperature during O[sub 2]-H[sub 2] fuel cell reactions. The best cathode for this reaction was explored. Graphite, carbon black, active carbon, and carbon whisker were examined as the cathodes. Pretreatment of these carbon materials with HNO[sub 3] aqueous solution (6/7M) at 373 K improved the rate of phenol production remarkably. Among these carbon materials, the carbon whisker showed the best results. Hydroxyl radical was suggested to be the active oxygen species responsible for hydroxylation of benzene. The reaction mechanism assuming hydroxyhexadienyl radical as a reaction intermediate has been proposed. Coaddition of Pd black and Fe-cation to the carbons showed a market synergism for the formation of phenol. Pd black increases the rate of reduction of dioxygen. Fe-cation enhances the generation of hydroxyl radical as well as the selectivity to phenol. The combination of these effects explains the synergism of Pd black and Fe-cation. The same reaction system and the best cathode described above have been applied to the partial oxidations of toluene and cyclohexane.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the Electrochemical Society; (United States); Journal Volume: 139:9
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of the Electrochemical Society; (United States)

TITLE: Two promoting effects of gadolinium on Ni/SiO sub 2 catalysis for CO hydrogenation
AUTHORS: Shido, Takafumi; Iwasawa, Yasuhiro
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; GADOLINIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; NICKEL; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; DISSOCIATION; FOURIER TRANSFORMATION; GADOLINIUM OXIDES; HYDROGEN; HYDROGENATION; INFRARED RADIATION; METHANE; PROMOTERS; REDUCTION; SILICON OXIDES; SYNTHESIS; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; ALKANES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONTROL; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ELEMENTS; EVALUATION; GADOLINIUM COMPOUNDS; HYDROCARBONS; INTEGRAL TRANSFORMATIONS; KINETICS; METALS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RADIATIONS; RARE EARTH COMPOUNDS; RARE EARTHS; REACTION KINETICS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SPECTROSCOPY; TRANSFORMATIONS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Promoting effects of Gd and CO-H interaction in CO hydrogenation on Ni/Gd/SiO{sub 2} catalysts have been investigated by means of kinetics, TPR, and FT-IR. The reaction rate of CO hydrogenation on Ni/Gd/SiO{sub 2} was about five times faster than that on Ni/SiO{sub 2} above 500 K. The IR band of side-on CO (Ni-CO{double bond}O-Gd) on Ni/Gd/SiO{sub 2} was observed at 1,600 cm{sup {minus}1} in addition to the bands of on-top (ca. 2,040 cm{sup {minus}1}) and bridge CO (ca. 1,950 cm{sup {minus}1}). All side-on CO easily dissociates, whereas most on-top Gd exists as partially reduced GdO{sub x} and the GdO{sub x} acts as a reservoir of hydrogen. A new peak due to Gd-H was observed at 1,610 cm{sup {minus}1} under reaction conditions. The adsorbed hydrogen increased the amount of CO adsorbed on Ni/Gd/SiO{sub 2}. Consequently, the easy dissociation of CO and the storage of hydrogen on the Ni/Gd/SiO{sub 2} catalyst promoted the hydrogenation of CO to hydrocarbons (mainly methane).
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 137:1

TITLE: Alkylation of toluene with methanol over AlPO sub 4 , AlPO sub 4 -Al sub 2 O sub 3 , AlPO sub 4 -TiO sub 2 , and AlPO sub 4 -ZrO sub 2 catalysts
AUTHORS: Blanco, A; Campelo, J M; Garcia, A; Luna, D; Marinas, J M; Romero, A A
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 02 PETROLEUM; ALUMINIUM PHOSPHATES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; TOLUENE; METHYLATION; ADSORPTION; ALKYLATED AROMATICS; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; BROENSTED ACIDS; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CHEMICAL REACTION YIELD; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; GAS CHROMATOGRAPHY; KINETIC EQUATIONS; METHANOL; PH VALUE; PYRIDINES; SURFACE PROPERTIES; SYNTHESIS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; TEMPERATURE RANGE 0400-1000 K; TITANIUM OXIDES; XYLENES; ZIRCONIUM OXIDES; ALCOHOLS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; AROMATICS; AZINES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMATOGRAPHY; EQUATIONS; EVALUATION; HETEROCYCLIC COMPOUNDS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHOSPHATES; PHOSPHORUS COMPOUNDS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SORPTION; TEMPERATURE RANGE; TITANIUM COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; YIELDS; ZIRCONIUM COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 020400 - Petroleum- Processing
DESCRIPTION: The catalytic activity and selectivity of a series of AlPO{sub 4} (AP) and AP-metal oxide systems (Al{sub 2}O{sub 3}, TiO{sub 2}, and ZrO{sub 2} with an AP/metal oxide weight ratio of 3) were investigated at temperatures ranging from 673 to 873 K for the gas-phase microcatalytic alkylation of toluene with methanol. The results show that AP's catalyst exhibits surface acid sites accessible to toluene produces a mixture of xylenes (XY) as principal products, although 1,2,4- and 1,2,3-trimethylbenzenes (TMB) were also found to be dialkylation products for AP-Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} catalysts. Scarcely any side-chain-methylation of toluene to ethylbenzene (ETB) is found. The alkylation reaction follows the Bassett-Habgood kinetic equation for first-order reaction processes. The influence of the reaction temperature, pulse number, and toluene/methanol molarity upon the conversion of toluene and the selectivities of the products were investigated. The activity of AP and AP-metal oxide catalysts in the ring-methylation of toluene decreases in the order AP-Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} {much gt} AP > AP-TiO{sub 2} > AP-ZrO{sub 2}. This order is relatively well interpreted in basis to the surface acid properties studied gas-chromatographically through the irreversible adsorption of pyridine at temperatures in the range 473 to 673 K. This indicates that Broensted acidity decreases when Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} is substituted by TiO{sub 2} or ZrO{sub 2} in the AP-metal oxide system.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 137:1

TITLE: Supported Ru-Mo catalysts for syngas reaction to oxygenates
AUTHORS: Juan, A; Damiani, D E
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 03 NATURAL GAS; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; ETHANOL; SYNTHESIS; METHANOL; MOLYBDENUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; RUTHENIUM; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHEMISORPTION; CHLORIDES; COAL GAS; DESORPTION; HYDROGEN; IMPREGNATION; NATURAL GAS; OXIDATION; PHOTOELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; REDUCTION; SILICON OXIDES; SYNTHESIS GAS; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; X-RAY DIFFRACTION; X-RAY SPECTROSCOPY; ALCOHOLS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; COHERENT SCATTERING; CONTROL; DIFFRACTION; ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; ELEMENTS; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; METALS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; PYROLYSIS PRODUCTS; SCATTERING; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SORPTION; SPECTROSCOPY; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 030300 - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing
DESCRIPTION: Despite numerous reports on the activity and selectivity of modified Ru catalysts on the synthesis of oxygenates from syngas, not many papers have appeared on their characterization. The goal of the research here reported is to provide more information regarding these catalysts. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR), temperature programmed desorption (TPD), temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results, H{sub 2} and CO chemisorption uptakes, as well as activity and selectivity for the CO + H{sub 2} reaction and Cl{sup {minus}} evolution studies on RuMo catalysts are given here. The catalysts, prepared by co-impregnation of SiO{sub 2} with RuCl{sub 3} {center dot} 1 {center dot} 5H{sub 2}O and (NH{sub 4}){sub 6}Mo{sub 7}O{sub 24} {center dot} 4H{sub 2}O, were pretreated according to two different procedures: (I) oxidation at 673 K followed by reduction at 673 K or (II) reduction at 673 K. Pretreatment II eliminates all residual Cl{sup {minus}}. Pretreatment I on the other hand results in higher final Cl{sup {minus}} contents in the catalysts and renders them more selective to oxygenates. The results are interpreted in terms of the existence of Ru-Mo contacts which are necessary for ethanol production and Cl{sup {minus}} -containing Ru sites responsible for methanol production.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 137:1

TITLE: Low temperature CO adsorption on Na-ZSM-5 zeolites: An FTIR investigation
AUTHORS: Bordiga, S; Zecchina, A; Platero, E E; Arean, C O; Lamberti, C
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; ADSORPTION; ZEOLITES; SORPTIVE PROPERTIES; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; ALKANES; ALKENES; BROENSTED ACIDS; CATALYSTS; CATALYTIC CRACKING; FOURIER TRANSFORMATION; GASOLINE; HYDROXYL RADICALS; INFRARED RADIATION; INFRARED SPECTRA; LEWIS ACIDS; METHANOL; POLYMERIZATION; SURFACE PROPERTIES; ALCOHOLS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CRACKING; DECOMPOSITION; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; FUELS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ACIDS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; INTEGRAL TRANSFORMATIONS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; LIQUID FUELS; MATERIALS; MINERALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; PYROLYSIS; RADIATIONS; RADICALS; SILICATE MINERALS; SORPTION; SPECTRA; SPECTROSCOPY; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TRANSFORMATIONS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 020400 - Petroleum- Processing; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: CO was adsorbed at 77 K on two Na-ZSM-5 zeolites which had Si/Al = 14 and Si/Al = 35, respectively. IR spectra in the OH-stretching region showed adsorption bands at 3,747 and 3,673 cm{sup {minus}1} assigned, respectively, to terminal silanols and to hydroxyls located on extraframework aluminium species. These OH groups were more strongly perturbed than silanols by adsorbed CO, thus suggesting a more pronounced Broensted acidity. The major features of the spectra in the CO-stretching region are two intense absorptions centered, respectively, at 2,178 and 2,138 cm{sup {minus}1}. Neither of them, however, is a single-peak band. The 2,178-cm{sup {minus}1} band was assigned to CO molecules polarized by Na{sup +} ions. It could be resolved into two components, revealing coordination of Na{sup +} ions by one molecule (high-frequency component) or by more than one (low-frequency component). The high-frequency component showed an asymmetric profile which was assigned to the presence of Na{sup +} ions in slightly different environments. The 2,138-cm{sup {minus}1} band corresponds to liquid-like CO inside the zeolite channels where the molecule behaves as a hindered rotor, thus explaining the fine structure observed. A weak IR adsorption was also observed at 2,112 cm{sup {minus}1} and assigned to CO simultaneously interacting through both ends with two Lewis acid centers. Finally, a combination mode observed at 2,305-2,315 cm{sup {minus}1} allowed assignation of a value of ca. 140 cm{sup {minus}1} to the Na{sup +} -CO.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 137:1

TITLE: Reaction analysis of potassium promotion of Ru-catalyzed CO hydrogenation using steady-state isotopic transients
AUTHORS: Hoost, T E; Goodwin, Jr, J G
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; POTASSIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; RUTHENIUM; CARBON; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; DEACTIVATION; DEPOSITION; HYDROGENATION; METHANE; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; STEADY-STATE CONDITIONS; SURFACE PROPERTIES; SYNTHESIS; TRANSIENTS; ALKALI METALS; ALKANES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; METALS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; REACTION KINETICS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Steady-state isotopic transient analysis (SSITKA) with carbon tracing was used to decouple the effects of potassium on the methane-producing sites during steady-state CO hydrogenation over Ru/SiO{sub 2} catalysts having modifier loadings of up to (K/Ru){sub atom} = 0.2. The SSITKA results indicate that, during steady-state, CO hydrogenation, carbidic carbon evolved into methane via a high-reactivity C(h) and a low-reactivity C(l) trajectory. With increasing amounts of K{sup +} the average true intrinsic turnover frequency (k) of both of these carbidic pools decreased, as did their steady-state surface abundance. Relative to C(l), the C(h) pool was affected to a slightly greater extent, both in terms of its reactivity and abundance. It is likely that potassium was able to strengthen the carbon-metal interaction which made hydrogenation of the carbon adlayer more difficult, resulting in smaller methane-destined pools of active surface carbon. With time-on-stream, deactivation by deposition of inactive carbon did not significantly affect the product distribution or the methane rate constant at the prevailing K{sup +} doping levels; instead, deactivation was due to a loss in the steady-state abundance of carbon-containing surface intermediates exiting as methane. Implications of the role of potassium during steady-state CO hydrogenation in influencing the active metal surface, the carbidic adlayer, and the latter's transformation into unreactive carbon are addressed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 137:1

TITLE: The selective synthesis of acetonitrile from carbon monoxide, hydrogen, and ammonia over Mo/SiO sub 2
AUTHORS: Kim, Kyung, N.; Lane, A M
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; ACETONITRILE; SYNTHESIS; FISCHER-TROPSCH SYNTHESIS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; MOLYBDENUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; AMMONIA; AMMONOLYSIS; CARBON MONOXIDE; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; CHEMICAL REACTION YIELD; CYANIDES; HYDROGEN; METHANATION; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; SHIFT PROCESSES; SILICON OXIDES; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; WATER GAS PROCESSES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; DECOMPOSITION; ELEMENTS; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; METALS; NITRILES; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SOLVOLYSIS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; YIELDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-)
DESCRIPTION: The selective synthesis of acetonitrile from CO/H{sub 2}/NH{sub 3} over Mo/SiO{sub 2} was investigated. The effects of temperature, space velocity, and reactant compositions on conversion and selectivity were explored with a two-level factorial designed experiment. High selectivities (37-96% excluding CO{sub 2}) were achieved at reasonably high conversions (29-64%). The product's carbon number distribution differed significantly from that obtained from a CO/H{sub 2} feed under identical conditions. The results are explained in terms of three competing reactions: water-gas shift, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, and nitrile synthesis. Other experiments are described that indicate a nitrile synthesis mechanism involving a C-N intermediate which further reacts with a carbon species to form the acetonitrile. A mechanistic hypothesis involving an isocyanide ligand is proposed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 137:1

TITLE: Veba and RWE recycle plastics waste to crude
AUTHORS: Chynoweth, E
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; PETROLEUM; PRODUCTION; PLASTICS; RECYCLING; CAPACITY; CHEMICAL FEEDSTOCKS; FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF GERMANY; PETROCHEMICALS; REFINING; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; MATERIALS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; PROCESSING; RAW MATERIALS; SYNTHETIC MATERIALS; WESTERN EUROPE; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 320305 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Industrial & Agricultural Processes- Industrial Waste Management
DESCRIPTION: Veba Oel (Gelsenkirchen, Germany) and Ruhrkohle will recycle 40,000 m.t.-50,000 m.t. of mixed plastics waste back to synthetic crude next year as part of a technology demonstration program. The companies hope the project, to be carried out in an existing plant, will show that the process works on an industrial scale and is economically viable. A test earlier this year on 60 m.t. of mixed plastics waste was successful. Crude generated from the waste was fed into Veba Oel's refinery at Gelsenkirchen.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chemical Week; (United States); Journal Volume: 151:7

TITLE: Electrocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide with iron, cobalt, and nickel complexes of terdentate ligands
AUTHORS: Arana, C; Yan, S; Abruna, H D; Keshavarz-K, M; Potts, K T
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON DIOXIDE; REDUCTION; COBALT COMPLEXES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; IRON COMPLEXES; NICKEL COMPLEXES; ELECTROCATALYSTS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; HOMOGENEOUS CATALYSIS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CATALYSIS; CATALYSTS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COMPLEXES; DATA; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPLEXES; 400400* - Electrochemistry; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: There has been, in the recent past, much interest in the design of electrocatalysts for the reduction carbon dioxide to useful fuel products. These reactions are particularly difficult to catalyze since they not only involve multiple electron transfers but also are often coupled with chemical steps such as protonation. Furthermore, there can be multiple and competing reaction pathways giving rise to a variety and distribution of reaction products. The authors have prepared a wide variety of first-row transition-metal complexes that incorporate bis(terdentate) coordination around the metal center. The authors find that all of these materials exhibit some degree of electrocatalytic activity in the reduction of CO{sub 2}. The author describes preliminary observations and point to some future directions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Inorganic Chemistry; (United States); Journal Volume: 31:17

TITLE: Hoechst Celanese picks Methanex as partner for methanol restart
AUTHORS: Morris, G D.L.
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; METHANOL; PRODUCTION; CAPACITY; CHEMICAL PLANTS; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; PRICES; ALCOHOLS; ECONOMICS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 100700 - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Hoechst Celanese Chemical (Dallas) has chosen Methanex (Vancouver)-the former Ocelot Industries-as its partner for the restart of its long-mothballed 600,000-m.t./year methanol unit at Clear Lake, TX. The two firms are in the final stages of negotiations, and a formal announcement on the agreement could come as early as this week. Interest in methanol, has strengthened dramatically in the past couple of years, reflecting strong demand to feed production of fuel oxygenates.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chemical Week; (United States); Journal Volume: 151:7

TITLE: Mobil plans methanol plant in Nigeria
AUTHORS: Alperowicz, N
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; METHANOL; PRODUCTION; CAPACITY; CHEMICAL PLANTS; JOINT VENTURES; ALCOHOLS; COOPERATION; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; 100700* - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Mobil Chemical (Houston) is in discussions with Nigerian National Petroleum Corp. (NNPC; Lagos) on a joint venture methanol plant at Port Harcourt, Nigeria. The U.S. firm has invited process owners to submit proposals for a 1-million m.t./year unit and hopes to select the technology by the end of this year. Three proposals have been submitted: Lurgi, offering its own low-pressure process; John Brown/Davy, with the ICI process; and M.W. Kellogg, proposing its own technology. Shareholding in the joint venture is yet to be decided, but it is likely to be a 50/50 tie-up. Marketing of Mobil's share or of the entire tonnage would be handled by Mobil Petrochemical International (Brussels). The plant could be onstream in late 1996.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chemical Week; (United States); Journal Volume: 151:6

TITLE: Oxidation of tert-Butyl alcohol in a pulsed reactor
AUTHORS: Tyurin, Y N; Kochukova, E V
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 40 CHEMISTRY; BUTANOLS; OXIDATION; CATALYSTS; REDUCTION
DESCRIPTION: The oxidation of tert-butyl alcohol, reduction of IK-9-4 catalyst by the alcohol, and oxidation of the catalyst by air were studied in a pulsed reactor at 573-633 K with the tert-butyl alcohol concentration varying in pulses of 0.5-0.7 vol. %. During the reduction of the catalyst by the tert-butyl alcohol stable adsorption of the alcohol was detected; upon contact with the air the alcohol gives only products of deep oxidation, while upon contact with the reaction mixture it gives methacrolein to a greater degree. It was determined that the mechanism of conversion of tert-butyl alcohol to methacrolein is a redox mechanism. 6 refs., 4 figs., 3 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Russian Journal of Applied Chemistry; Journal Volume: 65; Journal Issue: 2; Other Information: PBD: 10 Aug 1992; TN: Translated from Zhurnal Prikladnoi Khimii; 65: No. 2, 381-386(Feb 1992)

TITLE: Indonesia to build methanol plant
AUTHORS: Alperowicz, N
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; METHANOL; PRODUCTION; CAPACITY; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; ALCOHOLS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; 100700* - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: P.T. Kaltim Methanol Industri (Jakarta), a company set up to build a new methanol plant in Indonesia, expects to award contracts for the construction of a new plant, Indonesia's second methanol unit, by the end of this year. P.T. Kaltim Methanol is a private company owned by P.T. Humpuss, an industrial group active in transport, airlines, and shipping of LNG and methanol. The 2,000-m.t./day plant will be built at Bontang, Kalimantan Island, close to the fertilizer producer P.T. Pupuk Kaltim and near the country's largest natural gas reserves. The site is also a deepsea port, handy for transportation of ready product. Three groups are in discussions with the investor on plant supply as well as methanol offtake deals. They are H G/Kockner; John Brown/Davy/Lucky Goldstar, offering the ICI process independently; and Lurgi/Metallgesellschaft (MG), proposing the Lurgi process. At least 60% of the output is expected to be exported, and both ICI and MG are understood to be interested in selling product from the future plant. Japan, Southeast Asia, and the US are targeted.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chemical Week; (United States); Journal Volume: 151:5

TITLE: Groundwater issues relating to an Alaskan methanol spill
AUTHORS: Robertson, S B
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; GROUND WATER; WATER POLLUTION; METHANOL; BIODEGRADATION; ACCIDENTS; ALASKA; DRINKING WATER; REMEDIAL ACTION; TRANSPORT; ALCOHOLS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; DECOMPOSITION; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; NORTH AMERICA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POLLUTION; USA; WATER; 540220* - Environment, Terrestrial- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (1990-); 100900 - Synthetic Fuels- Environmental Aspects- (1990-); 540250 - Environment, Terrestrial- Site Resource & Use Studies- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: This paper reports on a Dec. 1989 methanol spill which resulted from sabotage to three railroad tank cars. Samples taken from nearby drinking-water wells and groundwater-monitoring wells were below the analytical detection limit. Monitoring well data demonstrated that groundwater flow was not toward local residential wells. Dilution by snow and subsequent freezing in the soil limited the downward spread of the methanol, an advantage not found in milder, more temperate conditions. Contaminated material was removed and processed to reclaim the methanol. Volatilization and biodegradation should remove any remaining methanol. Cleanup options were limited by the possible hazardous waste classification of the contaminated soil. The regulatory status of spilled methanol waste should be re-evaluated, especially if use of methanol as a motor fuel increases.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Petroleum Technology; (United States); Journal Volume: 44:8
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ISSN 0022-3522; CODEN: JPTJAM; TRN: 92-037643

TITLE: Comparison of pentan-3-one formation with propionaldehyde formation during ethylene hydroformylation over Rh/active carbon catalyst
AUTHORS: Takahashi, Nobuo; Takeyama, Terushige; Yanagibashi, Takashi; Takada, Yoshio
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALDEHYDES; SYNTHESIS; ETHYLENE; ACYLATION; KETONES; RHODIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; ACTIVATED CARBON; CARBON MONOXIDE; CATALYSIS; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; FORMYL RADICALS; HYDROGEN; PARTIAL PRESSURE; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; REDUCTION; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ACYL RADICALS; ADSORBENTS; ALKENES; CARBON; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; EVALUATION; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; METALS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; RADICALS; REACTION KINETICS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 020400* - Petroleum- Processing; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The rhodium supported on active carbon has been found to be active for pentan-3-one formation from C{sub 2}H{sub 4}, CO, and H{sub 2} as well as propionaldehyde formation. Among three Rh/active carbon catalysts prepared from different kinds of rhodium compounds (RhCl{sub 3}, Rh(NO{sub 3}){sub 3}, and Rh(CH{sub 3}COO){sub 3}), one prepared from RhCl{sub 3} showed the highest activity for pentan-3-one formation. Comparing pentan-3-one formation with propionaldehyde formation, the effects of the following factors on the catalytic activity were observed to be different in both reactions; (I) effects of reaction temperature, (II) effects on H{sub 2} pretreatment of catalysts, and (III) effects of partial pressure of CO. On pentan-3-one formation, {sup 13}C{sub 2}H{sub 5}CO{sup 13}C{sub 2}H{sub 5} and C{sub 2}H{sub 5}{sup 13}COC{sub 2}H{sub 5} were found to be predominant products in the reaction of propionaldehyde-{sup 13}C{sub 2}H{sub 4}-CO-H{sub 2} and of propionaldehyde-C{sub 2}H{sub 4}-{sup 13}CO-H{sub 2}, respectively. These results indicate that the route for pentan-3-one formation is the reaction among two molecules of C{sub 2}H{sub 4} and each one molecule of CO and H{sub 2}, and not the reaction between C{sub 2}H{sub 4} and propionaldehyde.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:2

TITLE: The role of boundary layer mass transfer in partial oxidation selectivity
AUTHORS: Hickman, D A; Schmidt, L D
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 03 NATURAL GAS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; CHEMICAL REACTORS; MASS TRANSFER; METHANE; OXIDATION; AMMONIA; BOUNDARY LAYERS; CARBON MONOXIDE; CATALYSTS; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; FLOW RATE; GAS FLOW; GEOMETRY; HYDROCYANIC ACID; HYDROGEN; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; PLATINUM; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; RHODIUM; SURFACE PROPERTIES; SYNTHESIS GAS; TIME DEPENDENCE; ALKANES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CYANIDES; ELEMENTS; FLUID FLOW; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDRIDES; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ACIDS; LAYERS; MATHEMATICS; METALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 030300 - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing; 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-)
DESCRIPTION: Simple models predict that mass transfer in the boundary layer over a catalyst surface should have a large influence on reactor selectivity for any fast series reaction, but few experimental cases demonstrate this explicitly. In this paper, the authors show experimentally that selectivities of CH{sub 4} oxidation to CO and H{sub 2} over Pt-Rh gauzes and HCN synthesis from CH{sub 4}, NH{sub 3}, and air over Pt-coated ceramic monoliths are strongly affected by the gas flow rate and the catalyst geometry. For any series reactions in which that desired product is an intermediate species, such as HCN synthesis, an optimal residence time exists where the production of the desired component is maximized, and the selectivity of formation of the intermediate product improves with increasing rates of mass transfer. For parallel and series-parallel reactions, mass transfer may improve or reduce selectivity of formation of the intermediate product, with the effect of mass transfer depending strongly on the reaction orders of the kinetics. However, typical series-parallel partial oxidation reactions such as the partial oxidation of CH{sub 4} to synthesis gas require high rates of mass transfer for maximum reactor selectivity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:2

TITLE: Identification and application of partial chemical equilibria in reactor modeling
AUTHORS: Norval, G; Phillips, M J; Missen, R W; Smith, W R
SUBJECT: 09 BIOMASS FUELS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 02 PETROLEUM; CHEMICAL FEEDSTOCKS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; CHEMICAL REACTORS; EQUILIBRIUM; STOICHIOMETRY; GASOLINE; SYNTHESIS; METHANOL; ENERGY CONVERSION; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS; PROCESS CONTROL; SYNTHETIC PETROLEUM; ALCOHOLS; CONTROL; CONVERSION; FUELS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; LIQUID FUELS; MATERIALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; RAW MATERIALS; REACTION KINETICS; SYNTHETIC FUELS; 090900* - Biomass Fuels- Processing- (1990-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-); 023000 - Petroleum- Properties & Composition
DESCRIPTION: In this paper, a method is presented for identifying a subset of species (from a set of reacting species) that are within a specified numerical tolerance of equilibrium, as implied by a given experimental composition. The method also determines a linearly independent set of reactions involving these species and the number of stoichiometric restrictions inherent in the set. This is an aid in reactor modeling, for example, in the computation of concentration profiles, in examining kinetic schemes or reaction mechanisms, and in identifying rate-controlling processes. An example involving the methanol-to-gasoline synthesis is given to illustrate the method.
RELATION: Journal Name: AIChE Journal (American Institute of Chemical Engineers); (United States); Journal Volume: 38:8
JOURNAL_NAME: AIChE Journal (American Institute of Chemical Engineers); (United States)

TITLE: The direct partial oxidation of methane to liquid hydrocarbons over HZSM-5 zeolite catalyst
AUTHORS: Han, S; Martenak, D J; Palermo, R E; Pearson, J A; Walsh, D E
SUBJECT: 03 NATURAL GAS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; METHANE; CATALYTIC REFORMING; OXIDATION; ZEOLITES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; ADDITIVES; ALKYLATED AROMATICS; AROMATIZATION; CARBON 13; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; FORMALDEHYDE; GASOLINE; METHANOL; MOLECULAR WEIGHT; NATURAL GAS; SYNTHESIS; ALCOHOLS; ALDEHYDES; ALKANES; AROMATICS; CARBON ISOTOPES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ENERGY SOURCES; EVEN-ODD NUCLEI; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; ISOTOPES; KINETICS; LIGHT NUCLEI; LIQUID FUELS; MATERIALS; MINERALS; NUCLEI; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; REACTION KINETICS; REFORMER PROCESSES; SILICATE MINERALS; STABLE ISOTOPES; 030300* - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The direct partial oxidation (DPO) of CH{sub 4} with O{sub 2} in the presence of a C{sub 3} additive over HZSM-5 zeolite catalyst at 960 psig produced C{sub 5}{sup +} liquid hydrocarbons at the expense of the initially formed CH{sub 3}OH. Previous experiments with pure CH{sub 4} and O{sub 2} feed and with a sand-packed reactor conclusively showed the need for both the C{sub 3} additive and the zeolite in the system to produce C{sub 5}{sup +} liquids. Evidence of CH{sub 4} incorporation into the liquid products was given by selectivity calculations which indicated the C{sub 3} alone could not account for the C{sub 5}{sup +} hydrocarbons. CH{sub 4} incorporation has been conclusively confirmed by mass spectral analyses of tetramethylbenzene produced in a run with {sup 13}CH{sub 4} under identical conditions which show significant {sup 13}C enrichment in the C{sub 9}H{sub 11}{sup +} and C{sub 6}H{sub 5}{sup +} fragments. While CH{sub 4} undergoes DPO to CH{sub 3}OH in the system, two possible reaction mechanisms can explain the role of C{sub 3}; one involves C{sub 3} aromatization followed by aromatics alkylation with CH{sub 3}OH. Studies on this system with HZSM-5 catalysts having varying Al contents indicate a sensitivity to zeolite acidity except at high Al concentrations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:2

TITLE: Pervaporation of ethanol and acetone above normal boiling temperatures
AUTHORS: Windmoeller, D; Galembeck, F
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 09 BIOMASS FUELS; ACETONE; MEMBRANE TRANSPORT; ETHANOL; BOILING POINTS; DEHYDRATION; ETHANOL PLANTS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; KINETICS; MEMBRANES; MORPHOLOGY; PHASE DIAGRAMS; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; PRESSURIZATION; SCANNING ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; SILICONES; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALCOHOLS; DATA; DIAGRAMS; ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; INFORMATION; KETONES; MICROSCOPY; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC SILICON COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POLYMERS; SILOXANES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; TRANSITION TEMPERATURE; 400105* - Separation Procedures; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 090900 - Biomass Fuels- Processing- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Pervaporation experiments were performed at higher than normal feed liquid boiling temperatures by applying pressure to the feed compartment. Ethanol, acetone, and aqueous ethanol solutions were pervaporated through silicone rubber dense membranes. Large increases were observed in the permeate flow as the temperature rose above the liquid boiling temperature. Separation factors in aqueous ethanol pervaporation are not affected by these increases in permeate output, and they are in the same range as those obtained in conventional pervaporation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Separation Science and Technology; (United States); Journal Volume: 27:10

TITLE: Application of a new CAVERN design to the study of reactions on catalysts using in situ solid-state NMR
AUTHORS: Munson, E J; Ferguson, D B; Kheir, A A; Haw, J F
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; CATALYSTS; EVALUATION; MATERIALS HANDLING EQUIPMENT; DESIGN; NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE; SAMPLE PREPARATION; ADSORPTION; CATALYTIC REFORMING; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; FABRICATION; GASOLINE; HETEROGENEOUS CATALYSIS; METHANOL; OPERATION; ZEOLITES; ALCOHOLS; CATALYSIS; EQUIPMENT; FUELS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; LIQUID FUELS; MAGNETIC RESONANCE; MATERIALS; MINERALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; REFORMER PROCESSES; RESONANCE; SILICATE MINERALS; SORPTION; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-)
DESCRIPTION: A new approach to preparing samples for in situ magic-angle spinning (MAS) NMR studies of chemical reactions on catalysts that offers several significant improvements over existing methods is described. This contribution describes the design and use of a second-generation CAVERN apparatus that is easily fabricated from glass and other inexpensive materials. The success rate using this apparatus for preparing reactive catalyst-adsorbate samples for study by MAS NMR is nearly 100%. A second major advantage of this design is that it permits the MAS rotor to be returned to the vacuum line for the adsorption of additional reactants prior to resuming in situ NMR study. The use of the second-generation CAVERN apparatus is illustrated by demonstrating the sequential adsorption feature. The observed induction period in the conversion of methanol to gasoline on HZSM-5 is studied by sequential adsorption of methanol. Although the first aliquot of methanol exhibited a long induction period before hydrocarbon synthesis at 523 K, none was observed following adsorption of a second aliquot, showing that the products have an influence on the observed kinetics.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:2

TITLE: Molecular orbital calculation of the soft-hard acidity of zeolites and its catalytic implications
AUTHORS: Corma, A; Sastre, G; Wilson, C Zicovich; Viruela, R
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; TOLUENE; METHYLATION; ZEOLITES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; PH VALUE; ALUMINIUM; METHANOL; MOLECULAR ORBITAL METHOD; QUANTITY RATIO; SILICON; ALCOHOLS; ALKYLATED AROMATICS; AROMATICS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; MATERIALS; METALS; MINERALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; SEMIMETALS; SILICATE MINERALS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 020400 - Petroleum- Processing; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The relative hardness of different compositions of model clusters of acid zeolites and the same clusters containing a metoxy group as alkylating agent were evaluated using the energy of the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital as the index. Different basis sets and pseudopotentials were used in ab initio calculations. Semiempirical MNDO-PM3 calculations were also performed. The results show that the hardness of the zeolite increases when the Si/Al ratio decreases. On the basis of Pearson's HSAB principle, the selectivity obtained during the alkylation of toluene with methanol catalyzed by acid zeolites was interpreted.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:2

TITLE: Silver catalysts in the partial oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde
AUTHORS: Devochkin, A N; Pestryakov, A N; Kurina, L N; Sakharov, A A
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; SILVER; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; METHANOL; OXIDATION; CATALYST SUPPORTS
DESCRIPTION: A comparative study of the catalytic activity of supported (Ag/pumice, LNKh-M) and bulk (Ag{sub cryst}, SD, KS) catalysts for methanol oxidation was carried out. The effect of technological parameters on the partial oxidation of methanol was studied. The optimum conditions for conducting the process on the catalysts studied were determined. 5 refs., 1 tab.
