TITLE: Influence of dispersity on the activity, selectivity, and stability of Raney-Nickel catalyst during the hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol into 1,4-butanediol
AUTHORS: Rusina, S V; Litvin, E F; Kheifets, V I; Sharf, V Z
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 02 PETROLEUM; NICKEL; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; ALKYNES; HYDROGENATION; CATALYSTS; BUTANEDIOLS
DESCRIPTION: Raney-nickel catalysts are widely used in the hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol into 1,4-butanediol, an important intermediate for the preparation of thermostable resins, plasticizers, pharmaceutical preparations, and other compounds. The authors carried out the investigation of the influence of the dispersity of the Raney-nickel catalysts on their activity, selectivity, and stability in the hydrogenation reaction of 1,4-butynediol into 1,4-butanediol.
RELATION: Journal Name: Russian Journal of Applied Chemistry; Journal Volume: 65; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: 10 Jul 1992; TN: Translated from Zhurnal Prikladnoi Khimii; 65: No. 1, 151-155(Jan 1992)

TITLE: Reaction of methane with vapor-phase transition-metal chlorides
AUTHORS: Didenko, L P; Chekh, N A; Shiryaev, A A; Savchenko, V I
SUBJECT: 03 NATURAL GAS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 40 CHEMISTRY; METHANE; CHLORINATION; MOLYBDENUM CHLORIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; TUNGSTEN CHLORIDES; CATALYSTS
DESCRIPTION: Chemical processing of raw materials with the natural gas, methane, is under study to see if it can replace the gases normally used. Interest in the reaction of methane with transition-metal chlorides in the vapor phase is due to the following factors. First, methane as a reducing agent can replace hydrogen, widely used for reducing metal chlorides, to yield ultrapure metals. Second, metal chlorides are of interest as catalysts for methane chlorination with subsequent conversion to ethylene or aromatic hydrocarbons. The latter two-step method of obtaining organics from methane is industrially simpler than by direct conversion of methane into ethylene by the Benson method. Chlorinated methanes are obtained by heating methane with molecular chlorine. This reaction is the basis of industrial chlorinated methane production but has a number of problems that prompt searching for catalytic chlorinations. The present paper presents a more detailed study of methane chlorination in the presence of MoCl{sub 5}, WCl{sub 6} and correlates the results with the reaction of methane with other vapor-phase transition-metal chlorides. 12 refs., 3 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Russian Journal of Applied Chemistry; Journal Volume: 65; Journal Issue: 1; Other Information: PBD: 10 Jul 1992; TN: Translated from Zhurnal Prikladnoi Khimii; 65: No. 1, 145-150(Jan 1992)

TITLE: Influence of alkali promoters in the selective hydrogenation of 3-methyl-2-butenal over Ru/SiO{sub 2} catalysts
AUTHORS: Waghray, A; Wang, Jian; Oukaci, R; Blackmond, D G
SUBJECT: 40 CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALDEHYDES; HYDROGENATION; RUTHENIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; SILICA; POTASSIUM; CATALYSTS; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; CATALYST SUPPORTS
DESCRIPTION: The addition of potassium as a promoter to a Ru/SiO{sub 2} catalyst resulted in a striking shift in product selectivity in the hydrogenation of 3-methyl-2-butenal. The rate of hydrogenation of the C=O bond to produce the unsaturated alcohol increased concomitant with a decrease in the rate of C=C hydrogenation. IR spectroscopy showed a strong perturbation of the C=O bond for the alkali-promoted catalyst, and volumetric chemisorption and TPD results suggested that the alkali species blocked adsorption at low-coordination Ru sites. These adsorption and reaction studies suggest that polarization of the adsorbed substrate at the C=O bond is responsible for the significant shift in product selectivity upon alkali promotion. This work combines spectroscopic tools with the use of the catalytic reaction itself as a probe of catalyst surface chemistry. 40 refs., 6 figs., 3 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Physical Chemistry; Journal Volume: 96; Journal Issue: 14; Other Information: PBD: 9 Jul 1992

TITLE: Interaction of cyclohexadiene with Pt(111) studied by BPTDS and HREELS
AUTHORS: Hugenschmidt, M B; Diaz, A L; Campbell, C T
SUBJECT: 40 CHEMISTRY; 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; PLATINUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CYCLOALKENES; DEHYDROGENATION; ACTIVATION ENERGY; ADSORPTION; SORPTIVE PROPERTIES
DESCRIPTION: The interactions of 1,3- and 1,4-cyclohexadiene with Pt(111) have been studied with bismuth postdosing thermal desorption mass spectroscopy (BPTDS) and high-resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy (HREELS). Both species adsorb molecularly on Pt(111) at 100 K. Upon warming, both species dehydrogenate completely to produce adsorbed benzene. The reaction occurs at about 230-260 K with an activation energy of 14 {plus_minus} 2 kcal/mol. The adsorbed benzene thus produced either dehydrogenates, ultimately to graphitic carbon, or desorbs, both occuring above 450 K. When cyclohexadiene is coadsorbed with hydrogen adatoms, no significant amounts of hydrogenated products (<2%) are observed in normal TDS or in BPTDS. 19 refs., 5 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Physical Chemistry; Journal Volume: 96; Journal Issue: 14; Other Information: PBD: 9 Jul 1992

TITLE: Decomposition of cyclohexene on Pt(111): A BPTDS and HREELS study
AUTHORS: Henn, F C; Diaz, A L; Bussell, M E; Hugenschmidt, M B; Domagala, M E; Campbell, C T
SUBJECT: 40 CHEMISTRY; 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CYCLOALKENES; DECOMPOSITION; PLATINUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; DEHYDROGENATION; MASS SPECTROSCOPY; DESORPTION; DEUTERIUM; ISOTOPIC EXCHANGE
DESCRIPTION: The interactions of cyclohexene with a Pt(111) surface have been studied using a combination of bismuth postdosing thermal desorption mass spectroscopy (BPTDS) and high-resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy (HREELS). BPTDS is a technique which utilizes vapor-deposited Bi (at a surface temperature of {approximately} 100 K) to passivate a previously prepared adlayer against intraadsorbate bond-breaking reactions. After such passivation, the surface is heated and adsorbed intermediates desorb intact for mass spectral indentification, provided they have stable gas-phase analogues. Here, the authors show that BPTDS is a useful technique for monitoring the coverages of adsorbed intermediates produced during the dehydrogenation of cyclohexene on Pt(111). At 95 K, cyclohexene adsorbs molecularly in a di-{sigma} fashion. By 200 K (E{sub a} {congruent} 13.7 kcal/mol) this species converts to another form of di-{sigma}, molecularly adsorbed cyclohexene, which itself converts to {pi}-allyl c-C{sub 6}H{sub 9,a} (plus adsorbed hydrogen) at 200-240 K (E{sub a}{congruent} 14.4 kcal/mol). At about the same temperature, part of the cyclohexene decomposes, producing small amounts of adsorbed benzene and cyclohexadiene. At about 340 K, the c-C{sub 6}H{sub 9,a} species converts to adsorbed benzene (E{sub a} = 20.8 kcal/mol) and the adsorbed hydrogen desorbs as H{sub 2}. The c-C{sub 6}H{sub 9,a} intermediate is identified in BPTDS by its deuteration to c-C{sub 6}H{sub 9}D gas at {approximately} 190 K when coadsorbed with deuterium. No significant H-D exchange occurs between coadsorbed deuterium and molecularly adsorbed hydrocarbons when probed by BPTDS. 48 refs., 6 figs., 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Physical Chemistry; Journal Volume: 96; Journal Issue: 14; Other Information: PBD: 9 Jul 1992

TITLE: A BPTDS and HREELS study of the interaction of cyclohexane with the Pt(111) surface
AUTHORS: Bussell, M E; Henn, F C; Campbell, C T
SUBJECT: 40 CHEMISTRY; 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; PLATINUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CYCLOHEXANE; DEHYDROGENATION; ADSORPTION; SORPTIVE PROPERTIES; DESORPTION; HYDROGEN
DESCRIPTION: The surface chemistry of cyclohexane (c-C{sub 6}H{sub 12}) adsorbed on the Pt(111) surface has been investigated using bismuth postdosing thermal desorption mass spectroscopy (BPTDS) and high-resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy (HREELS). Cyclohexane was found to adsorb molecularly at 95 K in agreement with others. Cyclohexane decomposition begins at {approximately} 195 K and is complete by {approximately}230 K as determined by BPTDS. Between 230 and 290 K, the dominant species on the surface are c-C{sub 6}H{sub 9,a} and H{sub a}, with small amounts of adsorbed benzene also present. The c-C{sub 6}H{sub 9,a} converts to adsorbed benzene in the temperature range 290-340 K, almost simultaneous with the desorption of H{sub a} as H{sub 2}. 25 refs., 4 figs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Physical Chemistry; Journal Volume: 96; Journal Issue: 14; Other Information: PBD: 9 Jul 1992

TITLE: Texaco presses projects for gasification process
SUBJECT: 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; COAL GASIFICATION; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; COMBINED-CYCLE POWER PLANTS; IEUS; METHANE; YIELDS; TEXACO GASIFICATION PROCESS; BOILER FUELS; CALIFORNIA; DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS; INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION; ITALY; OPTIMIZATION; PETROLEUM; PETROLEUM REFINERIES; POWER GENERATION; RESIDUAL FUELS; SURFACTANTS; VISCOSITY; ALKANES; COOPERATION; DEVELOPED COUNTRIES; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL OILS; FUELS; GASIFICATION; HYDROCARBONS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; LIQUID FUELS; NORTH AMERICA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; USA; 200102* - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Cycles; 010404 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Gasification; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 294001 - Energy Planning & Policy- Coal
DESCRIPTION: This paper reports that Texaco Inc. continues to press international ventures for its gasification process. A combine of Italian companies plans an $800 million integrated gasification/combined cycle power plant at a refinery in Sicily that will use Texaco's process to gasify refinery residual to produce electrical power. Other Italian refiners are expected to follow suit with similar projects. Meanwhile, Texaco and Bitor America Corp., have signed a letter of agreement to develop integrated gasification/combined cycle electrical power generation projects. The venture plans to use Texaco's gasification process and Orimulsion, a boiler fuel that is an emulsion of Venezuelan heavy crude, water, and surfactant, as feedstock. Bitor, Boca Raton, Fla., and its parent, Bitumenes Orinoco SA, are units of Venezuela's state oil company Petroleos de Venezuela SA.
RELATION: Journal Name: Oil and Gas Journal; (United States); Journal Volume: 90:27

TITLE: Surface structure and reactivity of CrO sub 3 /SiO sub 2 catalysts
AUTHORS: Kim, D S; Wachs, I E; Tatibouet, J M
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CHROMIUM OXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; MOLECULAR STRUCTURE; METHANOL; OXIDATION; ACETIC ACID; CARBON DIOXIDE; CARBON MONOXIDE; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; FORMALDEHYDE; LAYERS; PHASE STUDIES; RAMAN SPECTROSCOPY; SILICON OXIDES; SYNTHESIS; ALCOHOLS; ALDEHYDES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CARBOXYLIC ACIDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; LASER SPECTROSCOPY; MONOCARBOXYLIC ACIDS; ORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SPECTROSCOPY; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The molecular structure of the two-dimensional chromium oxide overlayer on the silica support at different chromium oxide contents has been investigated by in situ Raman spectroscopy. Under dehydrated conditions, the surface chromium oxide content. The catalysts above 2% CrO{sub 3}/SiO{sub 2} also contain crystalline {alpha}-Cr{sub 2}O{sub 3} particles in addition to the surface monochromate species. The methanol oxidation studies reveal that the catalytic activity per Cr atom, the turnover number (TON), decreases as the chromium oxide content increases. The major reaction product is HCHO, while HCOOCH{sub 3}, CO, and CO{sub 2} are next in abundance. The selectivity for HCHO increases as the chromium oxide content increases and the precalcination temperature is increased. The opposite trend is observed for the selectivity of HCOOCH{sub 3}. These selectivity changes are due to dehydroxylization of the silica surface by precalcining at elevated temperatures and increasing the surface chromium oxide species. The current results suggest that HCHO and HCOOCH{sub 3} are produced on two different catalytic sites: HCHO is formed on the Cr site, whereas HCOOCH{sub 3} is produced via hemiacetal intermediates, which are formed by interaction between HCHO adsorbed on the Cr site and CH{sub 3}O adsorbed on the silica site. The CO and CO{sub 2} combustion products are produced on both the Cr and silica site.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: Heterogeneous-homogeneous reactions involving free radicals in processes of total catalytic oxidation
AUTHORS: Ismagilov, Z R; Pak, S N; Yermolaev, V K
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CHROMATES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; COPPER COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM; PROPANOLS; OXIDATION; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CATALYSTS; ELECTRON SPIN RESONANCE; HETEROGENEOUS CATALYSIS; HOMOGENEOUS CATALYSIS; QUANTITY RATIO; RADICALS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALCOHOLS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CATALYSIS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; MAGNETIC RESONANCE; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; RESONANCE; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Using a modified matrix isolation ESR technique conditions for initiation of a heterogeneous-homogeneous reaction by total oxidation catalysts CuCr{sub 2}O{sub 4}/{gamma}-Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} and 0.64% Pt/{gamma}-Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} and reaction dependences at atmospheric pressure have been studied. The dependences of homogeneous component contribution into the total conversion on the concentration and the ratio of reactants and catalyst temperature have been established. The object of the study was the reaction of n-propanol oxidation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: Study of Raney ruthenium catalyst for methanol synthesis
AUTHORS: Takeishi, Kaoru; Aika, Kenichi
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; METHANOL; SYNTHESIS; RUTHENIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; FISCHER-TROPSCH SYNTHESIS; HYDROGENATION; PHASE STUDIES; POWDERS; SURFACE PROPERTIES; ALCOHOLS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-)
DESCRIPTION: Ruthenium (Ru) catalysts are known to dissociate the CO bond easily and to be effective for methanation or Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. However, several Ru systems yield oxygen-containing compounds. The reasons for these oxygenate synthesis activities have not been well discussed. Raney Ru catalysts have also been found active for methanol synthesis from CO and H{sub 2}. Methanol can be synthesized at a temperature as low as 353 K on Raney Ru. Fine particles of raney Ru powder catalyst can be suspended in a solution for the low-temperature methanol synthesis process in which a reduced Ni complex catalyst is supposed to be used. A new methanol process under low temperature and low pressure could save much of the energy required for the process, and new catalysts including Raney Ru should be studied in detail. The point of interest in the case of Raney Ru is why methanol is produced selectively, although Ru powder gives hydrocarbon exclusively. Here, the authors tried to identify the surface state of raney Ru that is related to methanol selectivity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: Effect of alloying on CO hydrogenation activity over SiO sub 2 -supported Co-Ni alloy catalysts
AUTHORS: Ishihara, Tatsumi; Horiuchi, Nobuhiko; Inoue, Takanori; Eguchi, Koichi; Takita, Yusaku; Arai, Hiromichi
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; COBALT ALLOYS; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; NICKEL ALLOYS; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; ADSORPTION; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; DEUTERIUM; ELECTRON DENSITY; FISCHER-TROPSCH SYNTHESIS; GASOLINE; HYDROGEN; HYDROGENATION; INFRARED RADIATION; ISOTOPIC EXCHANGE; NITRIC OXIDE; PHOTOELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; SILICON OXIDES; SYNTHESIS; X-RAY SPECTROSCOPY; ALLOYS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; ELEMENTS; FUELS; HYDROGEN ISOTOPES; ISOTOPES; KINETICS; LIGHT NUCLEI; LIQUID FUELS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN OXIDES; NONMETALS; NUCLEI; ODD-ODD NUCLEI; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; RADIATIONS; REACTION KINETICS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SORPTION; SPECTROSCOPY; STABLE ISOTOPES; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Alloying Co with Ni is effective for enhancing the activity for CO hydrogenation as well as the selectivity to gasoline. Infrared spectra of adsorbed NO and XPS spectra for the 3p{sub 3/2} orbital of Co and Ni suggest that Co in the alloy interacts electronically with Ni in the outer shell orbital, resulting in the creation of adsorption sites with a new electron density. As a result, alloying Co with Ni strengthens the hydrogen adsorption. Thus alloying Co with Ni allows hydrogen to compete more effectively for adsorption sites in the co-adsorption of CO and H{sub 2}. Since the rate of H{sub 2}-D{sub 2} exchange on CO preadsorbed Co-Ni alloy shows a good correlation with the CO hydrogenation activity, the reactivity of adsorbed hydrogen in the presence of CO plays a decisive role in determining the activity for CO hydrogenation in this alloy system.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: Methanol synthesis from H sub 2 , CO, and CO sub 2 over Cu/ZnO catalysts
AUTHORS: Chanchlani, K G; Hudgins, R R; Silveston, P L
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; COPPER; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; METHANOL; SYNTHESIS; ACTIVATION ENERGY; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; AUGER ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; CARBON DIOXIDE; CATALYST SUPPORTS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; DEACTIVATION; HYDROGENATION; PHOTOELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; QUANTITY RATIO; SHIFT PROCESSES; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; WATER GAS; X-RAY SPECTROSCOPY; ZINC OXIDES; ALCOHOLS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; ELEMENTS; ENERGY; EVALUATION; FLUIDS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INTERMEDIATE BTU GAS; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SPECTROSCOPY; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; ZINC COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-)
DESCRIPTION: Methanol synthesis kinetics at steady state are reported for two catalysts: Cu/ZnO (as Cu:Zn = 30:70 atomic ratio) and Cu/ZnO/Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} (Cu:Zn:Al = 60:30:10 atomic ratio) for various syngas compositions and temperatures from 200 to 275 C. In addition, catalyst deactivation is discussed along with XPS-Auger measurements of surface composition for fresh and used catalysts. Apparent activation energies for methanol synthesis on the Cu/ZnO catalyst depend on both temperature and fractional CO{sub 2} in the CO-CO{sub 2} mixture and reflect a change in the importance of the CO and CO{sub 2} as sources of methanol in the synthesis. The water-gas shift reaction does not proceed to equilibrium for CO mole fractions below 0.05. Experimental results confirm earlier observations that methanol is formed directly from CO and CO{sub 2}. However, in syngas mixtures, methanol production from CO and CO{sub 2} is not just additive; some interconversion must be involved.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: Catalytic behavior and surface chemistry of copper/ZnO/Al sub 2 O sub 3 catalysts for the decomposition of 2-propanol
AUTHORS: Pepe, F; Polini, R
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; COPPER; PROPANOLS; DEHYDROGENATION; ZINC OXIDES; CATALYSIS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; DECOMPOSITION; SURFACE AREA; SURFACE PROPERTIES; ALCOHOLS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SYNTHESIS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; ZINC COMPOUNDS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: CuO/ZnO/Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} samples (1 and 4 Cu atoms and 1, 5, 15, and 30 Zn atoms per 100 Al atoms, respectively) have been tested as catalysts for the decomposition of 2-propanol. The samples were pretreated in a controlled way in hydrogen or in the reaction medium in order to have a known surface content of Cu(0). Below 440 K the samples showed only dehydrogenating activity. A linear relationship was found between the rate constant and the surface area of zero-valent copper. It is hence proposed that surface Cu(0) species are responsible for the dehydrogenation. The higher values of turnover frequency for the present system in comparison with the values previously found on CuO/Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} enable a proposal to be made for the role of the zinc in the activity of the Cu(0) species. The beneficial effect of the zinc on the reducibility of Cu{sup 2+} ions and a reduction mechanism are also discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: Electronic interaction between supports and ruthenium catalysts for the hydrogenation of carbon monoxide
AUTHORS: Ishihara, Tatsumi; Harada, Kazuaki; Eguchi, Koichi; Arai, Hiromichi
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CONFIGURATION INTERACTION; CATALYSTS; RUTHENIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; ADSORPTION; BINDING ENERGY; DESORPTION; ELECTRONIC STRUCTURE; HYDROGENATION; INFRARED RADIATION; NITRIC OXIDE; PHOTOELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; X-RAY SPECTROSCOPY; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONTROL; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; ELEMENTS; ENERGY; METALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN OXIDES; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; RADIATIONS; SORPTION; SPECTROSCOPY; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The effect of oxide supports in hydrogenation of CO was investigated using Ru supported on metal oxides as catalysts. Activity for CO hydrogenation and product distribution depended on the electron affinity of the oxide supports. A support-effect was also recognized in the adsorption state of hydrogen and carbon monoxide from temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments. The support effect observed in this study seems to result from electronic interaction between Ru and support oxide, since the binding energy Ru 3d{sub 2} XPS peaks and the IR adsorption frequency of linear-type NO depended on the electron affinity of the oxide support. The extent of charge transfer was represented by the electronegativity of support oxide in this study. The activity and the chain growth probability in CO hydrogenation are enhanced by using Ru on support oxides with high electronegativity because the deficient electron density of Ru weakened the CO adsorption and enhanced the concentration of hydrogen on catalyst surface.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: Study of carbonaceous deposits on Fischer-Tropsch oxide-supported iron catalysts
AUTHORS: Galuszka, J; Sano, T; Sawicki, J A
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; DEPOSITION; STRUCTURAL CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; CATALYSTS; POISONING; FISCHER-TROPSCH SYNTHESIS; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CATALYST SUPPORTS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; CORRELATIONS; FOURIER TRANSFORMATION; INFRARED RADIATION; IRON; IRON 57; IRON CARBIDES; IRON OXIDES; MOESSBAUER EFFECT; OXIDATION; SILICON OXIDES; SPECTROSCOPY; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; THERMAL GRAVIMETRIC ANALYSIS; TITANIUM OXIDES; ZIRCONIUM OXIDES; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBIDES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONTROL; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ELEMENTS; EVALUATION; EVEN-ODD NUCLEI; GRAVIMETRIC ANALYSIS; INTEGRAL TRANSFORMATIONS; INTERMEDIATE MASS NUCLEI; IRON COMPOUNDS; IRON ISOTOPES; ISOTOPES; MATERIALS; METALS; NUCLEI; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; QUANTITATIVE CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; RADIATIONS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; STABLE ISOTOPES; THERMAL ANALYSIS; TITANIUM COMPOUNDS; TRANSFORMATIONS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; ZIRCONIUM COMPOUNDS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Fischer-Tropash synthesis was performed at semi-industrial conditions (300 C, 1,515 kPa, H{sub 2}/CO = 1) on various oxide (SiO{sub 2}, Al{sub 2}O{sub 3}, TiO{sub 2}, ZrO{sub 2})-supported iron catalysts. The carbonaceous materials deposited on the catalysts after 20 h on stream were characterized by FTIR spectroscopy and thermogravimetry during temperature-programmed oxidation, and by {sup 57}Fe Moessbauer spectroscopy. The characteristics of the carbonaceous deposits were strongly affected by the nature of the catalyst supports. At least five different forms of carbonaceous materials have been identified: aliphatic, aromatic, oxygenated, carbidic, and amorphous. Iron carbides have been found in all used catalysts. Moessbauer spectra of all used catalysts after heating in air at 400 C showed reoxidation of all carbides to {alpha}-Fe{sub 2}O{sub 3}. A tentative correlation of the carbonaceous deposit characteristics with the nature of the catalysts supports is offered.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: CO hydrogenation over PdNi sub x alloys encaged in NaY zeolite
AUTHORS: Feeley, J S; Stakheev, A Yu; Cavalcanti, F A.P.; Sachtler, W M.H.
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; NICKEL ALLOYS; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; PALLADIUM ALLOYS; BIMETALS; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; CRYSTAL LATTICES; DISTRIBUTION; HYDROGENATION; METHANE; METHANOL; METHYL ETHER; MIXTURES; NICKEL; PALLADIUM; PHOTOELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; SURFACE PROPERTIES; SYNTHESIS; X-RAY DIFFRACTION; X-RAY SPECTROSCOPY; ZEOLITES; ALCOHOLS; ALKANES; ALLOYS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COHERENT SCATTERING; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; DIFFRACTION; DISPERSIONS; ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; ELEMENTS; ETHERS; EVALUATION; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; KINETICS; MATERIALS; METALS; MINERALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METAL ALLOYS; PLATINUM METALS; REACTION KINETICS; SCATTERING; SILICATE MINERALS; SPECTROSCOPY; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Bimetallic (Pd + Ni)/NaY samples were studied and compared with monometallic Pd/NaY and Ni/NaY samples and their physical mixture. Samples were characterized by XRD, XPS, and CO hydrogenation. The formation of PdNi, alloy particles encaged in NaY zeolite was found for the bimetallic samples. Under conditions of CO hydrogenation, significant changes in sizes and distributions of Pd, Ni, and PdNi{sub x}, particles take place. Metal particle growth is accompanied by local collapse of the zeolite lattice. The selectivity of PdNi{sub x} alloys for methane formation was significantly higher than that of monometallic Pd or Ni particles or of their physical mixtures. On mixed PdNi{sub x} ensembles the rate of CO dissociation and/or CH{sub x} hydrogenation appears to be enhanced with respect to monometallic ensembles. Acid leaching of Ni by zeolite protons from alloy particles restores a metal surface rich in Pd, leading to an enhanced with respect to monometallic ensembles. Acid leaching of Ni by zeolite protons from alloy particles restores a metal surface rich in Pd, leading to an enhanced selectivity to methanol and its consecutive products, dimethyl ether and higher hydrocarbons.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: Preparation and characterization of chlorine-free ruthenium catalysts and the promoter effect in ammonia synthesis. 2. A lanthanide oxide-promoted Ru/Al sub 2 O sub 3 catalyst
AUTHORS: Murata, Shuzo; Aika, Ken-ichi
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; AMMONIA; SYNTHESIS; CERIUM NITRATES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CESIUM NITRATES; LANTHANUM NITRATES; RUTHENIUM; SAMARIUM NITRATES; ACTIVATION ENERGY; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CATALYSTS; CESIUM HYDROXIDES; CESIUM OXIDES; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; CHEMISORPTION; CHLORINE; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; CONFIGURATION INTERACTION; LANTHANUM OXIDES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PROMOTERS; SURFACE PROPERTIES; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CERIUM COMPOUNDS; CESIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; ENERGY; EVALUATION; HALOGENS; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXIDES; LANTHANUM COMPOUNDS; METALS; NITRATES; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NONMETALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; RARE EARTH COMPOUNDS; SAMARIUM COMPOUNDS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SORPTION; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: La(NO{sub 3}){sub 3}, Ce(NO{sub 3}){sub 3}, and Sm(NO{sub 3}){sub 3} were proved to be more effective promoters of ammonia synthesis than CsNO{sub 3} when they were applied to a chlorine-free Ru/Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} catalyst. Small amounts of lanthide nitrates (M/Ru = 1) were as effective as a much greater amount of CsNO{sub 3}(Cs/Ru = 10) for 2 wt% Ru/Al{sub 2}O{sub 3}. A chemisorption study disclosed that a smaller amount of lanthanide oxide could cover the Ru surface, whereas much more cesium oxide was necessary to cover the Ru surface. Lanthanide oxide was suggested to have a stronger interaction with the Ru surface than Cs{sub 2}O and/or CsOH, which are strongly basic and have a greater interaction with the Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} surface. A model of promoter action is proposed. The apparent activation energies of this reaction were lower (11 to 15 kcal/mol) than those using a Cs promoter (24 kcal/mol) under 101 kPa of N{sub 2} + 3H{sub 2}.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: Preparation and characterization of chlorine-free ruthenium catalysts and the promoter effect in ammonia synthesis. 1. An alumina-supported ruthenium catalyst
AUTHORS: Murata, Shuzo; Aika, Ken-ichi
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; AMMONIA; SYNTHESIS; CESIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; RUBIDIUM; RUTHENIUM; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CARBONYLS; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CATALYSTS; CESIUM HYDROXIDES; CESIUM OXIDES; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHLORINE; CONFIGURATION INTERACTION; HYDROGEN; NITROGEN; POTASSIUM HYDROXIDES; POTASSIUM OXIDES; PROMOTERS; RUBIDIUM HYDROXIDES; RUBIDIUM OXIDES; RUTHENIUM CHLORIDES; RUTHENIUM COMPOUNDS; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALI METALS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CESIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; ELEMENTS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HALOGENS; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXIDES; KINETICS; METALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NONMETALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; REFRACTORY METAL COMPOUNDS; RUBIDIUM COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Ru/Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} catalyst prepared from Cl-free Ru carbonyl was much more active for ammonia synthesis under 1.01 bar of N{sub 2} + 3H{sub 2} than that prepared from RuCl{sub 3}. The high activity was related to the high dispersion and lack of Cl. Alkali metal ion (oxide or hydroxide of Cs{sup +}, Rb{sup +}, and K{sup +}) was an effective promoter for the Cl-free Ru catalyst, suggesting that the alkali acted as an electronic promoter for Ru. The synthesis rate was maximum when the Cs/Ru ratio was as high as 10. Alkali had a strong interaction with the Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} surface and a weak interaction with the Ru surface.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: Dispersion and activity of molybdena-alumina catalysts prepared by impregnation and solid/solid wetting methods
AUTHORS: Reddy, B M; Reddy, E P; Srinivas, S T
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 02 PETROLEUM; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; METHANOL; OXIDATION; MOLYBDENUM OXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; THIOPHENE; DESULFURIZATION; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CARBON DIOXIDE; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CATALYTIC REFORMING; CHEMISORPTION; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; ELECTRON SPIN RESONANCE; HEAT TREATMENTS; IMPREGNATION; OXYGEN; PHASE STUDIES; X-RAY DIFFRACTION; ALCOHOLS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COHERENT SCATTERING; DIFFRACTION; ELEMENTS; EVALUATION; HETEROCYCLIC COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; MAGNETIC RESONANCE; MOLYBDENUM COMPOUNDS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC SULFUR COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REFORMER PROCESSES; REFRACTORY METAL COMPOUNDS; RESONANCE; SCATTERING; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SORPTION; SYNTHESIS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 020400 - Petroleum- Processing; 010402 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Purification & Upgrading
DESCRIPTION: Alumina-supported molybdena catalysts were prepared by both the standard incipient wetness method and by mixing MoO{sub 3} and Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} (solid/solid wetting), followed by thermal treatment of 500 C under dry or wet O{sub 2} atmospheric conditions. These catalysts were characterized by means of O{sub 2} chemisorption at {minus}78 C, CO{sub 2} uptake at ambient temperature, X-ray diffraction (XRD), and electron spin resonance (ESR) techniques. Activities of the catalysts were determined for partial oxidation of methanol and hydrodesulfurization of thiophene at atmospheric pressure. XRD results suggest high dispersion of Mo-oxide on alumina support irrespective of their method of preparation. However, O{sub 2} and CO{sub 2} uptake measurements reveal partial coverage of the Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} support surface by the Mo-oxide phase and appear to depend on the gas atmosphere (wet or dry O{sub 2}) during heat treatments in case of solid/solid wetting method. ESR, oxygen and carbon dioxide uptakes and the catalytic properties clearly demonstrate that spontaneous spreading of MoO{sub 3} on the Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} support at 500 C in the presence of wet O{sub 2} is a most effective alternative method for preparing molybdenum-alumina catalysts.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: Preparation and characterization of chlorine-free ruthenium catalysts and the promoter effect in ammonia synthesis. 3. A magnesia-supported ruthenium catalyst
AUTHORS: Aika, Ken-ichi; Takano, Tomiko; Murata, Shuzo
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; AMMONIA; SYNTHESIS; CESIUM HYDROXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CESIUM NITRATES; POTASSIUM NITRATES; RUBIDIUM NITRATES; RUTHENIUM; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMISORPTION; CHLORINE; CONFIGURATION INTERACTION; HYDROGEN; MAGNESIUM OXIDES; NITRATES; PERFORMANCE TESTING; PROMOTERS; RARE EARTH COMPOUNDS; SODIUM OXIDES; SURFACE PROPERTIES; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CESIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; HALOGENS; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXIDES; KINETICS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; METALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NONMETALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; RUBIDIUM COMPOUNDS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SORPTION; TESTING; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The support and promoter effects of Ru in ammonia synthesis were studied systematically using Ru carbonyl, Ru{sub 3}(CO){sub 12}, as a precursor of the Ru catalyst. MgO was found to be the most effective support among several pure oxides. The high activity is thought to be due to the high Ru dispersion, the Cl-free system, and the basicity of the support. Modifying MgO by adding other oxides was also tried. Na{sub 2}O-MgO and Al{sub 2}O{sub 3}-MgO supports were found to be as effective as the pure MgO. Fourteen kinds of metal nitrates, including alkali metals, alkali earth metal nitrates (Cs{sup +}, Rb{sup +}, and K{sup +}), especially CsNO{sub 3}, were most effective. The synthesis rate was greatest when the Cs/Ru ratio was as low as 1.0, where the activity was 20 times as high as that without CsNO{sub 3} at 588 K and under 80 kPa of N{sub 2} + 3H{sub 2}. CsNO{sub 3} was considered to be disproportionated to CsOH during the hydrogen treatment. The alkali promoter proved to act not only as a Cl scavenger in the case of a Cl-containing Ru catalyst but also as an electronic surface modifier to Ru. Hydrogen chemisorption studies disclosed that alkali covered mostly the Ru surface but had a weak interaction with the MgO surface. The importance of surface morphology in the combination of Ru and promoter was noted. Ru-CsOH/MgO (5 wt%: Cs/Ru = 1) was even more active than 4.7 wt% Ru-K/AC and was comparable to the Raney Ru-CsNO{sub 3} catalyst, which had previously been reported to be the most active catalyst at 573 and under 80 kPa of N{sub 2} + 3H{sub 2}.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 136:1

TITLE: Robust inferential control for a packed-bed reactor
AUTHORS: Budman, H M; Webb, C; Holcomb, T R; Morari, M
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CHEMICAL REACTORS; CONTROL; METHANATION; DESIGN; FLUIDIZED BEDS; LEAST SQUARE FIT; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; PERFORMANCE; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; MAXIMUM-LIKELIHOOD FIT; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: In this paper, two different inferential control schemes are applied to an experimental fixed bed methanation reactor. The first scheme, proposed initially by Brosilow, is designed based on Kalman filter estimation. The second less traditional design uses an estimator computed from the partial least squares regression method (PLS). The second approach was found to give superior performance when the nonlinear system under study is operated in a wide range of operating points. Due to the nonlinearity of the system it is essential to address the issue of robustness of the proposed schemes. This is formally done in this work using structured singular value theory. For the robustness analysis it is crucial to develop a realistic but not overly conservative uncertainty description. Since the PLS estimator uses a large number of measurements, a robust design based on the uncertainty associated with each one of the measurements, a robust design based on the uncertainty associated with each one of the measurements would be very conservative. To overcome this problem, a lumped uncertainty description is proposed which is identified directly form experiments.
RELATION: Journal Name: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research; (United States); Journal Volume: 31:7
JOURNAL_NAME: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research; (United States)

TITLE: Lurgi, Haldor Topsoe win Statoil methanol
AUTHORS: Alperowicz, N
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CHEMICAL PLANTS; CONSTRUCTION; METHANOL; PRODUCTION; CAPACITY; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; FINANCING; ALCOHOLS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; 100700* - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Following intensive screening and evaluation of technologies, Statoil (Stavanger) and Conoco, partners in a major methanol project in Norway, have selected a Lurgi (Frankfurt)/Haldor Topsoe (Copenhagen) process combination for the NK2.6-billion ($423.5 million) plant. Capacity of the plant, which will become Europe's largest and one of the biggest in the world, will be enlarged to 1 million m.t./year (3,000 m.t./day) against earlier plants of 825,000 m.t./year. Conoco will have 18.125% in the venture and Statoil the remainder. Part of the financing will come from Statoil's own reserves. Engineering work is expected to begin almost immediately with completion planned for end-1996.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chemical Week; (United States); Journal Volume: 150:24

TITLE: Rhodium-catalyzed hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to formic acid
AUTHORS: Tsai, Jing-Cherng; Nicholas, K M
SUBJECT: 40 CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; RHODIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CARBON DIOXIDE; HYDROGENATION; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE; FORMIC ACID
DESCRIPTION: The complex [Rh(NBD)(PMe{sub 2}Ph){sub 3}]BF{sub 4} (2; NBD = norbornadiene) has been found to serve as a precatalyst for the hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to formic acid at moderate temperatures in THF solution, with turnover numbers of 10-60/day. Water accelerates formic acid production, whereas PMe{sub 2}Ph is an inhibitor. Kinetic studies show that the rate of formic acid appearance in first order each in [2], pH{sub 2}, and p{sub CO2} in the range 50-300 psi (following prehydrogenation). In situ high-pressure IR and NMR experiments reveal that the addition of H{sub 2} to [Rh(NBD)(PMe{sub 2}Ph){sub 3}]BF{sub 4} (2) produces rhodium dihydride complexes [H{sub 2}Rh(PMe{sub 2}Ph){sub 3}(S)]BF{sub 4}(4, 5; S = H{sub 2}O, THF) and [H{sub 2}Rh(PMe{sub 2}Ph){sub 4}]BF{sub 4} (3). IR and NMR studies of the reaction of 3-5 with CO{sub 2} indicate that 3 is unreactive toward CO{sub 2} but that 4 and 5 insert CO{sub 2} to give species 6 and 7, formulated as formato complexes [HRh(S)(PMe{sub 2}Ph){sub 2}({eta}{sup 2}-OCHO)]BF{sub 4}, respectively; complexes 6 and 7 are also detected under catalytic conditions by IR spectroscopy. Aquo dihydride complex 4 has been found to insert CO{sub 2} more rapidly than the THF complex 5. [H{sub 2}Rh(PMe{sub 2}Ph){sub 3}(S)]BF{sub 4} (4, 5) also catalyze the decomposition of formic acid to CO{sub 2} and H{sub 2}. Combined kinetic and spectroscopic results suggest that reductive elimination of formic acid from the intermediate formato complexes is the rate-limiting step in the catalytic cycle. 30 refs., 11 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the American Chemical Society; Journal Volume: 114; Journal Issue: 13; Other Information: PBD: 17 Jun 1992
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of the American Chemical Society

TITLE: Palladium catalysis of O{sub 2} reduction by electrons accumulated on TiO{sub 2} particles during photoassisted oxidation of organic compounds
AUTHORS: Wang, Chong-Mou; Heller, A; Gerischer, H
SUBJECT: 40 CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; PALLADIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; OXYGEN; REDUCTION; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDATION; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; TITANIUM OXIDES; PARTICLES; PHOTOCHEMICAL REACTIONS; QUANTUM EFFICIENCY
DESCRIPTION: Earlier theoretical analysis suggested that the quantum efficiency of photoassisted oxidation of organic compounds in water by O{sub 2} on n-TiO{sub 2} surfaces can be limited by the kinetics of the reduction of O{sub 2}. When the rate of O{sub 2} reduction is not sufficiently fast to match the rate of reaction of holes, an excess of electrons will accumulate on the TiO{sub 2} particles, and the rate of electron-hole recombination will increase. The authors now show experimentally that electrons do indeed accumulate on slurried TiO{sub 2} particles during photoassisted oxidation of 1.6 M aqueous methanol and that electrons on the slurried particles persist for at least {approximately}1 min even in O{sub 2}-saturated solutions. The rate of particle depolarization, i.e. of electron transfer to dissolved O{sub 2}, is increased and the negative charge on the TiO{sub 2} particles is completely eliminated upon incorporation of Pd{sup 0} in the surface of the TiO{sub 2} particles. The authors also show that incorporation of Pd{sup 0} in the surface increases the quantum efficiency of the photoassisted oxidation of 10{sup -2} M aqueous 2,2-dichloropropionate 3-fold at 0.01 wt % Pd and 7-fold at 2 wt % Pd. 30 refs., 6 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the American Chemical Society; Journal Volume: 114; Journal Issue: 13; Other Information: PBD: 17 Jun 1992
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of the American Chemical Society

TITLE: The application of catalytic ring-closing olefin metathesis to the synthesis of unsaturated oxygen heterocycles
AUTHORS: Fu, G C; Grubbs, R H
SUBJECT: 40 CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; HETEROCYCLIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; ALKENES; CATALYSIS
DESCRIPTION: The development of general approaches to carbon-carbon bond formation represents an important ongoing challenge for synthetic organic chemists. One efficient method for constructing carbon-carbon double bonds, the transition metal alkylidene-catalyzed olefin metathesis reaction, has been the focus of intense interest in recent years from the standpoint of both mechanism and polymer synthesis, in contrast, use of this transformation in organic synthesis has been limited. As part of a broader program directed toward establishing transition metal alkylidenes as versatile reagents for organic chemistry, the authors report the successful application of catalytic olefin methathesis to the generation of a variety of unsaturated oxygen heterocycles. 13 refs., 1 fig., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the American Chemical Society; Journal Volume: 114; Journal Issue: 13; Other Information: PBD: 17 Jun 1992
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of the American Chemical Society

TITLE: Identification of alcohol adsorption sites on [gamma]-alumina
AUTHORS: DeCanio, E C; Nero, V P; Bruno, J W
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALCOHOLS; ADSORPTION; DEHYDRATION; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; SORPTIVE PROPERTIES; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; CATALYSTS; DESORPTION; ETHANOL; ETHERS; FOURIER TRANSFORMATION; INFRARED RADIATION; LEWIS ACIDS; MASS SPECTROSCOPY; METHANOL; OXYGEN 18; POISONING; PYRIDINES; SURFACE PROPERTIES; SYNTHESIS; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; AZINES; CHALCOGENIDES; CONTROL; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EVEN-EVEN NUCLEI; HETEROCYCLIC COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ACIDS; INTEGRAL TRANSFORMATIONS; ISOTOPES; LIGHT NUCLEI; NUCLEI; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN ISOTOPES; RADIATIONS; SORPTION; SPECTROSCOPY; STABLE ISOTOPES; TRANSFORMATIONS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: A novel temperature-programmed desorption technique in which the probe of a mass spectrometer is used as the reactor has been developed. FT-IR and this new technique have been used to study the adsorption and dehydration reactions of a series of aliphatic alcohols on [gamma]-alumina. It was found that the facility with which the various alkoxides undergo elimination processes is dependent on the size of the alkyl groups and the degree of branching. Reactions involving [[sup 18]O]ethanol and [[sup 18]O]methanol produce two isotopomeric ether products (R[sup 18]OR and R[sup 16]OR), which shows that bound alkoxides are formed by two routes: (a) dissociative adsorption on Lewis acid sites and (b) nucleophilic attack by a surface oxide on an alcohol that is probably activated toward C-O cleavage. Poisoning experiments using 2.6-dimethylpyridine confirm that the ether isotopomers are formed from different alkoxide species. Time studies indicate that there is no scrambling of the [sup 16]O and [sup 18]O alkoxides between the different types of surface sites.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 135:2

TITLE: Cobalt-modified Cu-Zn-Cr catalysts in the synthesis of methanol
AUTHORS: Fornasari, G; Trifiro, F; Vaccari, A; D'Huysser, A; Mintchev, L
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; CHROMIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; COBALT; COPPER; METHANOL; SYNTHESIS; ZINC; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; DEACTIVATION; DESORPTION; FISCHER-TROPSCH SYNTHESIS; MORPHOLOGICAL CHANGES; PHASE STUDIES; POISONING; PRECURSOR; QUANTITY RATIO; REDUCTION; SURFACE PROPERTIES; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; X-RAY DIFFRACTION; ALCOHOLS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COHERENT SCATTERING; CONTROL; DIFFRACTION; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SCATTERING; SORPTION; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The structural modifications and changes in reactivity in the low-temperature synthesis of methanol induced by the presence of small amounts of cobalt in Cu-Zn-Co-Cr catalysts were investigated. In all cases homogeneous precursors with a hydrotalcite-type structure were prepared, which upon calcination formed mainly cubic nonstoichiometric spinel-type structure were prepared, which upon calcination formed mainly cubic nonstoichiometric spinel-type phases. The presence of small amounts of Co led to considerable modification in the surface reactivity of the main Cu-containing fraction and the formation of a smaller less reducible fraction. On the other hand, TPD tests showed a considerable increase in the strength of the CO interaction with the surface. The catalytic data showed a change from a low-temperature methanol to a Fischer-Tropsch catalyst, which occurred in two stages: (1) With Co content up to 2% a dramatic deactivation was observed without any change in selectivity and (2) at higher Co contents an increase in activity was detected, but with a high selectivity in hydrocarbons. This behavior was interpreted as being due to the formation by reduction of the cubic nonstoichiometric spinel-type phase mainly of a highly dispersed metallic Cu, not detectable by XRD analysis and probably characterized by low-Miller-index surface planes. The low amounts of Co destroyed the catalytic activity by poisoning the oxidizing capacity of the catalyst surface, while further Co additions resulted in an increase in the activity with a change in selectivity to hydrocarbons, probably the result of a synergetic effect between the well-dispersed metallic Cu and the Co-containing cubic spinel-type phase.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 135:2

TITLE: Comparative FT-IR and MAS NMR spectroscopic studies of Rh/SiO[sub 2] catalysts exposed to CO/H[sub 2] at high temperature and pressure
AUTHORS: Chudek, J A; McQuire, M W; Rochester, C H
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; CATALYSTS; RHODIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; INFRARED SPECTRA; NMR SPECTRA; SILICON OXIDES; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; ADSORPTION; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CHEMISORPTION; ETHANOL; FOURIER TRANSFORMATION; HYDROGENATION; INFRARED RADIATION; METHANOL; NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE; QUANTITY RATIO; ALCOHOLS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INTEGRAL TRANSFORMATIONS; MAGNETIC RESONANCE; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; RADIATIONS; RESONANCE; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SORPTION; SPECTRA; SPECTROSCOPY; TRANSFORMATIONS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: [sup 13]C and [sup 1]H MAS NMR spectra of Rh/SiO[sub 2] catalysts after exposure to methanol and ethanol at 473 K or to CO:H[sub 2] mixtures at 15 atm (ratios 1:14, 1:2 and 14:1) and 473, 523, and 553 K are reported. The NMR spectra complement FT-IR spectra and confirm that adsorbed OMe and OEt groups resulting from CO/H[sub 2] reactions over Rh/SiO[sub 2] exist predominantly on the silica surface. NMR was better than FT-IR for distinguishing adsorbed OMe, OEt, and hydrocarbon species and also enabled identification of immobile chemisorbed species and weakly adsorbed mobile product molecules. Changes in the CO:H[sub 2] ratio had a profound effect on the nature of resulting surface species in situ under reaction conditions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 135:2

TITLE: Mechanistic aspects of the higher alcohol synthesis over K[sub 2]O-promoted ZnCr oxide: Temperature-programmed reaction and flow experiments of C[sub 3], C[sub 4], and C[sub 5] oxygenates
AUTHORS: Lietti, L; Tronconi, E; Forzatti, P
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALCOHOLS; SYNTHESIS; CHROMIUM OXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; POTASSIUM OXIDES; ZINC OXIDES; ALDEHYDES; ALKENES; CARBON DIOXIDE; CARBOXYLIC ACIDS; CATALYSIS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CRACKING; DECARBOXYLATION; DEHYDRATION; DEHYDROCYCLIZATION; DEHYDROGENATION; HYDROGENATION; KETONES; MOLECULAR STRUCTURE; PROPANOLS; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS; CONTROL; DECOMPOSITION; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; ORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; PYROLYSIS; REACTION KINETICS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; ZINC COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Mechanistic aspects of the higher alcohol synthesis (HAS) over a K[sub 2]O-promoted ZnCrO catalyst are investigated by temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) of C[sub 3] oxygenates (1-propanol, n-propanal, and n-propanoic acid) and by flow microreactor experiments of 1-propanol, 3-pentanone, and 2-butanone. A number of chemical functions are identified by the TPSR study and those prevailing under steady-state conditions. TPSR and continuous-flow experiments lead to the identification of a general reaction network for C[sub N] oxygenate molecules, based on the following routes: (i) hydrogenation/dehydrogenation reactions of oxygenate molecules: (ii) aldolic-type condensations of aldehydes and ketones, both in the normal and in the reversal mode, leading to the formation of higher aldehydes and ketones, both in the normal and in the reversal mode, leading to the formation of higher aldehydes and ketones; (iii) ketonization reactions, leading to the formation of 2-ketones and CO[sub 2]; (iv) reversal [alpha]-addition reactions, which result in the formation of 2-ketones; (v) dehydration of oxygenates, and particularly of secondary alcohols, leading to the formation of olefins. Olefins may also be formed by decarboxylation of surface carboxylate species. The reactivity of the species participating in the various reactions is discussed on the basis of their molecular structure, and results are compared with catalytic tests performed under HAS conditions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 135:2

TITLE: Infrared study of the CO insertion reaction on reduced, oxidized and sulfided Rh/SiO[sub 2] catalysts
AUTHORS: Chuang, S S.C.; Pien, S I
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; ETHYLENE; ACYLATION; CARBONYLATION; RHODIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; RHODIUM OXIDES; RHODIUM SULFIDES; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; ALDEHYDES; CATALYSIS; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; FISCHER-TROPSCH SYNTHESIS; FORMATES; HYDROGENATION; INFRARED RADIATION; SILICON OXIDES; SYNTHESIS; ALKENES; CARBOXYLIC ACID SALTS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ELEMENTS; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; RADIATIONS; REACTION KINETICS; REFRACTORY METAL COMPOUNDS; RHODIUM COMPOUNDS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SPECTROSCOPY; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 020400* - Petroleum- Processing; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-)
DESCRIPTION: The reaction of adsorbed CO with C[sub 2]H[sub 4]/H[sub 2] and ethylene hydroformylation over reduced, oxidized, and sulfided Rh/SiO[sub 2] catalysts has been investigated under reaction conditions by in situ infrared spectroscopy. Both reactions involve the CO insertion step resulting in the formation of propionaldehyde. The linear CO adsorbed on the Rh[sup 0] site of the reduced Rh/SiO[sub 2] and the linear CO adsorbed on the Rh[sup +] site of the oxidized Rh/SiO[sub 2] are consumed and propionaldehyde is produced as the adsorbed CO reacts with C[sub 2]H[sub 4] and H[sub 2]. The results show that both single Rh[sup 0] atoms and Rh[sup +] ion sites are active for the CO insertion reaction. In situ infrared observations of steady-state ethylene hydroformylation show that the oxidized Rh/SiO[sub 2] containing considerable amounts of Rh[sup +] sites exhibits rate and selectivity for the formation of propionaldehyde higher than those of the reduced Rh/SiO[sub 2]; the sulfided Rh/SiO[sub 2] comprising mainly single Rh sites shows rate and selectivity for the formation of propionaldehyde higher than that of the reduced Rh/SiO[sub 2]. The low selectivity of the reduced Rh/SiO[sub 2] for ethylene hydroformylation is attributed to the higher hydrogenation activity of the Rh crystallite surface on the reduced Rh/SiO[sub 2].
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 135:2

TITLE: The relationship between catalyst morphology and performance in the oxidative coupling of methane
AUTHORS: Hargreaves, J S.J.; Hutchings, G J; Joyner, R W; Kiely, C J
SUBJECT: 03 NATURAL GAS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; LITHIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; MAGNESIUM OXIDES; METHANE; CATALYTIC REFORMING; OXIDATION; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; DECOMPOSITION; DISLOCATIONS; DOPED MATERIALS; ETHANE; ETHYLENE; GRAIN BOUNDARIES; GRAIN SIZE; MAGNESIUM; MAGNESIUM CARBONATES; MAGNESIUM HYDROXIDES; MORPHOLOGY; NATURAL GAS; SURFACE AREA; SYNTHESIS; TRANSMISSION ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; ALKALI METALS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METALS; ALKANES; ALKENES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBONATES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CRYSTAL DEFECTS; ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; ELEMENTS; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXIDES; LINE DEFECTS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; MATERIALS; METALS; MICROSCOPY; MICROSTRUCTURE; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REFORMER PROCESSES; SIZE; SURFACE PROPERTIES; 030300* - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: A detailed study of the oxidative coupling of methane over magnesium oxide and lithium-doped MgO catalysts is presented. The morphology of a number of different catalysts has been examined by detailed transmission electron microscopy and the results have been correlated with catalyst performance, in particular selectivity to C[sub 2] hydrocarbons. Three samples of magnesium oxide have been prepared by different methods. Magnesium oxides prepared from the hydroxide, (ex OH), and from burning magnesium ribbon in air show similar morphology, exposing largely (100) planes; they also show very similar catalytic selectivity and specific activity. Steps and corner sites are present in much greater density on the ex OH samples than on the ribbon residue, and, since catalyst performance is unchanged, it is clear that these sites play no significant part in the catalysis over these materials. The active site is therefore located on the planar (100) surfaces. The most selective magnesium oxide catalyst was prepared by thermal decomposition of magnesium hydroxycarbonate and exposed a greater proportion of higher index mean crystal planes, e.g., (111), than the less selective forms of magnesium oxide. The morphology/performance relationship has also been examined for lithium-doped magnesium oxide catalysts. The emergence of a dislocation at the surface of the crystallite provides a locus for [Li[sup +]O[sup [minus]]] centres, thought to be the active site in methyl radical generation in methane coupling. Similar dislocations are observed in Au/MgO catalysts, which are much less selective to C[sub 2] hydrocarbons than in pure MgO.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 135:2

TITLE: Kinetic studies of the oxidative coupling of methane over a NaOH/CaO catalyst
AUTHORS: Lehmann, L; Baerns, M
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 03 NATURAL GAS; CALCIUM OXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; METHANE; CATALYTIC REFORMING; OXIDATION; SODIUM HYDROXIDES; CARBON OXIDES; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; ETHANE; ETHYLENE; KINETIC EQUATIONS; OXYGEN; PARTIAL PRESSURE; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; SYNTHESIS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; TEMPERATURE RANGE 0400-1000 K; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKANES; ALKENES; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; EQUATIONS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXIDES; KINETICS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; REFORMER PROCESSES; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; TEMPERATURE RANGE; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 030300 - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing
DESCRIPTION: The effects of the partial pressures of oxygen and methane as well as temperature on the rates of C[sub 2] hydrocarbon formation, carbon oxide formation, and total methane conversion in the oxidative coupling of methane over a NaOH/CaO catalyst were studied at differential operating conditions in a microcatalytic fixed-bed reactor. Temperature and partial pressures of the reactants were varied within the following ranges: 933 K [le] T [le] 1,033 K, 5 kPa [le] P[sub CH[sub 4]] [le] 80 kPa, 0.3 kPa [le] P O[sub 2] [le] 20 kPa. The rate of CO[sub x] formation was of 0.5 order in methane as well as in oxygen; the rate of C[sub 2] hydrocarbon formation was first order in methane while it passed through a maximum with respect to oxygen partial pressure. The rate of methane conversion was well described by a power-law rate equation. Mechanistic assumptions derived from these kinetic results and corroborated by kinetic isotope effects are presented. In addition, kinetic equations for C[sub 2] hydrocarbon formation, carbon oxide formation, and methane conversion as reported in the literature were scrutinized for their applicability to describing the experimental data obtained in this work.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 135:2

TITLE: Acidity and catalytic activity of MeAPSO-34 (Me = Co, Mn, Cr), SAPO-34, and H-ZSM-5 molecular sieves in methanol dehydration
AUTHORS: Hocevar, S; Levec, J
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CHROMIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; COBALT; MANGANESE; METHANOL; DEHYDRATION; MOLECULAR SIEVES; ZEOLITES; ALKENES; BIOMASS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; COAL; COKE; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; DEPOSITION; DESORPTION; ETHYLENE; METHYL ETHER; NATURAL GAS; PH VALUE; SYNTHESIS; SYNTHESIS GAS; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; ADSORBENTS; ALCOHOLS; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; CONTROL; ELEMENTS; ENERGY SOURCES; ETHERS; EVALUATION; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; KINETICS; MATERIALS; METALS; MINERALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SILICATE MINERALS; SORPTION; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: SAPO-34 and the isomorphously substituted MeAPSO-34 (Me = Co, Mn, Cr) molecular sieves have been synthesized. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) profiles and the reaction rates of methanol dehydration have been measured on these samples in comparison with H-ZSM-5. The acidity strength of samples has been determined qualitatively from the temperatures of dimethyl ether desorption peaks, and the following sequence has been obtained: H-ZSM-5 > MnAPSO-34 > CoAPSO-34 > CrAPSO-34 > SAPO-34. The following sequence of catalytic acitivty has been observed: H-ZSM-5 [much gt] SPAO-34 > CrAPSO-34 > CoAPSO-34 > MnAPSO-34. The selectivities for the formation of low olefines have been observed to decrease rapidly with time on stream for all catalysts in the SAPO-34 and MeAPSO-34 series as a consequence of coking. The highest selectivity to ethane production among these catalysts has been found for MnAPSO-34.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (United States); Journal Volume: 135:2

TITLE: Reduction of aldehydes and ketones by transition-metal hydrides. 1. Reaction of trans,trans-WH(CO){sub 2}(NO)(PMe{sub 3}){sub 2} with simple and phenoxy-functionalized aldehydes and ketones
AUTHORS: van der Zeijden, A A.H.; Bosch, H W; Berke, H
SUBJECT: 40 CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALDEHYDES; REDUCTION; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; KETONES; TUNGSTEN COMPLEXES; TUNGSTEN HYDRIDES; MONOCLINIC LATTICES; ORGANOMETALLIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; BENZALDEHYDE
DESCRIPTION: The tungsten complex, trans, trans-WH(CO){sub 2}(NO)(PMe{sub 3}){sub 2} reacts with propanol, benzaldehyde, salicylaldehyde, 2-hydroxyacetophenone, methyl salicylate, and 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde to yield insertion products. The reactions and their products were studied by IR, mass spectrometry, and X-ray crystallography. Structures of selected products were discussed. 1 fig., 7 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Organometallics; Journal Volume: 11; Journal Issue: 6; Other Information: PBD: Jun 1992

TITLE: Carbon dioxide chemistry of the trinuclear complex [Ni{sub 3}({mu}{sub 3}-CNMe)({mu}{sub 3}-I)(dppm){sub 3}][PF{sub 6}]. Electrocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide
AUTHORS: Ratliff, K S; Lentz, R E; Kubiak, C P
SUBJECT: 40 CHEMISTRY; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON DIOXIDE; REDUCTION; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; NICKEL COMPLEXES; ORGANOMETALLIC COMPOUNDS; ELECTROCATALYSTS; CATALYSIS
DESCRIPTION: Reduction of CO{sub 2} in the presence of the electrocatalyst complex, [Ni{sub 3}({mu}{sub 3}-CNMe{mu}{sub 3}-I)(dppm){sub 3}][PF{sub 6}] (1) was studied. (1) is an electrocatalyst active in the reduction of CO{sub 2}. In the presence of CO{sub 2}, 1 reduces CO{sub 2}. The products of this reduction reflect disproportionation to CO and carbonate ion. 34 refs., 1 fig.

TITLE: Roles of chemisorbed oxygen and zinc oxide islands on Cu(110) surfaces for methanol decomposition
AUTHORS: Fu, S S; Somorjai, G A
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 40 CHEMISTRY; METHANOL; DECOMPOSITION; COPPER; CATALYSIS; ZINC OXIDES; CATALYSTS; OXYGEN; CHEMISORPTION
DESCRIPTION: The interaction of methanol with Cu-Zn-O surfaces is studied on a model system produced by depositing zinc oxide islands on Cu(110) surfaces. Various amounts of oxygen are then adsorbed onto the exposed copper part of the surface to form ZnO{sub x}/y ML O/Cu(110) surfaces. The role of O/Cu(110) in methanol decomposition on the authors model Cu-Zn-O surfaces was discerned by examining the interaction of methanol, adsorbed at 150 K in ultrahigh vacuum, with these ZnO{sub x}/y ML O/Cu(110) surfaces using temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), low energy electron diffraction (LEED), and Auger electron spectroscopy (AES). Methanol reduces the zinc oxide and removes oxygen chemisorbed on copper. The decomposition temperatures of formate and methoxy species formed upon methanol decomposition on the components of oxygen covered Cu(110) and ZnO{sub x} are unaffected by the presence of the other component. However, the amount of formate species decomposed on the ZnO{sub x} component of ZnO{sub x}/O/Cu(110) surfaces is controlled by the amount of chemisorbed oxygen on copper. The authors show that there are cooperative effects between O/Cu and ZnO which increases the total amount of formate formed; for ZnO{sub x}/0.2 ML O/Cu(110) surfaces, the concentration of surface formate doubles on the three-component system as compared to the sum of the concentration of formate species on the separate components. This produces a change in the relative surface formate to methoxy ratio from 1:9, for the case of 0.2 ML O/Cu(110), to 1:3, for the case of ZnO{sub x}/0.2 ML O/Cu(110) surfaces. 20 refs., 12 figs., 3 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Physical Chemistry; Journal Volume: 96; Journal Issue: 11; Other Information: PBD: 28 May 1992

TITLE: Hydrogenation catalysts based on complexes of palladium(II) and polyvinylpyridines
AUTHORS: Zharmagambetova, A K; Mukhamedzhanova, S G; Bekturov, E A; Saltykov, Yu P
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 40 CHEMISTRY; PALLADIUM COMPLEXES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; ALCOHOLS; HYDROGENATION; CATALYSTS
DESCRIPTION: Recently methods for producing a new type of catalyst, grafted complexes have been developed. Polymers containing functional groups have been used quite successfully as a substrate in such catalysts. The refinement of the preparative method for metallopolymeric complexes (MPC) is of some importance. By varying the conditions of interaction between the polymers and the metal compounds the catalytic properties of MPC can be improved significantly. In this study the authors have looked at the effect of the preparative conditions for complexes of palladium(II) with poly-2-vinylpyridine (Pd-P2VP) on their catalytic activity in the hydrogenation of 2-propen-1-ol. 13 refs., 3 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Russian Journal of Applied Chemistry; Journal Volume: 64; Journal Issue: 12; Other Information: PBD: 20 May 1992; TN: Translated from Zhurnal Prikladnoi Khimii; 64: No. 12, 2547-2551(Dec 1991)

TITLE: Mechanism of alkylation of isobutane by olefins in the presence of sulfuric acid
AUTHORS: Baiburskii, V L; Khadzhiev, S N; Ovsyannikov, V P
SUBJECT: 40 CHEMISTRY; 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 2-METHYLPROPANE; ALKYLATION; ALKENES; CATALYSTS; SULFURIC ACID
DESCRIPTION: The authors attempted here to examine the mechanism of alkylation of isobutane by olefins in the presence of sulfuric acid in terms of an initial stage of activation of isoparaffin. The version of formation of tert-alkyl cations and the role of the catalyst in this stage were analyzed. 10 refs., 1 fig., 1 tab.
