TITLE: Butanediol via maleic anhydride
AUTHORS: Harris, N; Tuck, M W
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; BUTANEDIOLS; SYNTHESIS; SYNTHETIC FUELS INDUSTRY; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; BUTANE; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; MALEIC ACID; MARKET; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; ALCOHOLS; ALKANES; CARBOXYLIC ACIDS; DICARBOXYLIC ACIDS; GLYCOLS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INDUSTRY; KINETICS; ORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 100700 - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-); 100900 - Synthetic Fuels- Environmental Aspects- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: A new butanediol process offers the opportunity for new producers to enter a growth market previously dominated by a very few major companies. Butanediol (BDO) and its derivatives compete with alternative products on a cost basis in their end use applications. The ability of the new route to produce BDO at a lower cost than established technology will lead to further market penetration and an expansion of the uses for the product. The feedstock, n-butane, is widely available and likely to fall in cost relative to the cost of the feedstocks used by competing processes. The process is environmentally acceptable and less hazardous than competing technologies.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrocarbon Processing; (USA); Journal Volume: 69:5

TITLE: Redox properties of chromic acid supported on silica
AUTHORS: Hill, W; Oehlmann, G
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CHROMIC ACID; REDOX POTENTIAL; ACTIVATION ENERGY; ALCOHOLS; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CATALYSTS; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CHARGE STATES; CHEMICAL PROPERTIES; CHROMIUM OXIDES; ETHANOL; ETHYLENE; HYDROGEN; IMPREGNATION; OXIDATION; POLYMERIZATION; QUANTITY RATIO; REDUCTION; SILICON OXIDES; SPECTROSCOPY; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; ALKENES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS; CONTROL; ELEMENTS; ENERGY; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ACIDS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 020400 - Petroleum- Processing; 102000 - Synthetic Fuels- Products & By-Products- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Redox properties of chromium/silica catalysts prepared by impregnation of silica with an aqueous solution of CrO{sub 3} are studied for chromium contents between 10{sup {minus}3} and 1% by weight. Temperature-programmed experiments and spectroscopic data are used to characterize the kinetics and final states of reduction by hydrogen and ethanol as well as the oxidation of reduced samples by molecular oxygen. The oxidation of hydroxylated Cr{sup 3+} species to Cr{sup 6+} exhibits an activation energy of 113 kJ/mol.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 123:1

TITLE: Reactivity of (1,4,7,10,13-pentaazacyclohexadecane-14,16-dionato(2-))nickel(II) toward derivatives of methyl-coenzyme M
AUTHORS: Drain, C M; Sable, D B; Corden, B B
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; CYCLOALKANES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; METHANE; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; NICKEL COMPLEXES; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; CATALYSIS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COENZYMES; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; METHANOGENIC BACTERIA; ALKANES; BACTERIA; COMPLEXES; DATA; HYDROCARBONS; INFORMATION; KINETICS; MICROORGANISMS; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPLEXES; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: The reactivity of (1,4,7,10,13-pentaazacyclohexadecane-14,16-dionato(2-))nickel(II), Ni{sup II}L, toward H{sub 3}CSCH{sub 2}CH{sub 2}SO{sub 3}{sup {minus}}, methyl-coenzyme M, possesses striking similarities to the active site chemistry of methyl-coenzyme M reductase, which contains the nickel tetrapyrrole species F{sub 430}. The initial rate of substrate conversion for a series of substrate analogues of the formula RX(CH{sub 2}){sub n}Y{sup {minus}} is reported, where the R and X groups have the greatest influence on reactivity. When R = CH{sub 3} and X = S, little change in reactivity is observed when n = 2, 3, or 6 or when Y{sup {minus}} = SO{sub 3}{sup {minus}}, CO{sub 2}{sup {minus}}, or PO{sub 3}{sup {minus}}. These results are consistent with the two-site model for substrate binding at F{sub 430}, the proposed enzyme active site. 27 refs., 5 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Inorganic Chemistry; (USA); Journal Volume: 29:7

TITLE: An evaluation of direct methane conversion processes
AUTHORS: Fox, III, J M; Chen, T P; Degen, B D
SUBJECT: 03 NATURAL GAS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 09 BIOMASS FUELS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; METHANE; ENERGY CONVERSION; FISCHER-TROPSCH SYNTHESIS; GASOLINE; LIQUEFIED NATURAL GAS; METHANOL; SYNTHESIS GAS; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; ALCOHOLS; ALKANES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONVERSION; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; LIQUEFIED GASES; LIQUID FUELS; NATURAL GAS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; 030400* - Natural Gas- Products & By-Products; 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 090900 - Biomass Fuels- Processing- (1990-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Methane is the primary constituent of both natural gas and the associated gas resulting from crude oil production. These gases have little value unless they can be moved to large-scale consumers through a pipeline or transported as liquefied gases. Because conversion of methane to a transportable liquid hydrocarbon fuel would open new markets, it is a goal being actively pursued by many groups around the world. Currently, two large-scale, viable approaches for converting methane to liquid hydrocarbons are being used: the methanol-to-gasoline (MTG) route, and the Fischer--Tropsch (FT) route. Both of these processes begin with the production of synthesis gas from methane,which is a high-temperature, endothermic, costly operation. Concepts for directly converting methane to a liquid hydrocarbon fuel without reforming methane to synthesis gas conceptually appear attractive. A few have reached the stage where a preliminary evaluation directed at understanding the critical process factor is possible. The authors report on their studies involving the following process schemes: oxidative coupling, partial oxidation, and oxyhydrochlorination.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chemical Engineering Progress; (USA); Journal Volume: 86:4

TITLE: Subatmospheric burning characteristics of AP/CTPB composite propellants with burning rate modifiers
AUTHORS: Krishnan, S; Jeenu, R
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 33 ADVANCED PROPULSION SYSTEMS; 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; BUTADIENE; COMBUSTION KINETICS; PROPELLANTS; ATMOSPHERIC PRESSURE; AUTOMOTIVE FUELS; CHROMIUM OXIDES; COMPOSITE MATERIALS; COPPER OXIDES; DEPOSITS; FUEL ADDITIVES; IRON OXIDES; MICROSTRUCTURE; PETROLEUM; QUANTITATIVE CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; SYNTHETIC FUELS; VISCOSITY; ADDITIVES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS; COPPER COMPOUNDS; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; DIENES; ENERGY SOURCES; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; HYDROCARBONS; IRON COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; MATERIALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POLYENES; REACTION KINETICS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 400800* - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 330800 - Emission Control- Alternative Fuels; 025000 - Petroleum- Combustion; 100400 - Synthetic Fuels- Combustion- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: While burning at subatmospheric pressure, composite propellant generally fume and under certain conditions eject partially reacted particles. This characteristic property is exploited in this study to understand the mechanism of burning rate modification. The additives CuCr{sub 2}O{sub 4}, Fe{sub 2}O{sub 3}, Sb{sub 2}O{sub 3}, Al(OH){sub 3} gel, and LiF were used with unmetallized AP/CTPB (carboxy terminated polybutadiene) composite propellants, and the following studies were done: burning rate measurements below and above atmospheric pressure (up to 70 bar); quantitative chemical analysis of fume deposits and ejected particles; and scanning electron microscope examination of the microstructure of the surface extinguished propellant samples. The results of the studies at subatmospheric pressure indicate that burning rate enhancers augment the AP/binder interfacial reactions, CuCr{sub 2}O{sub 4} decomposes into copper oxide and chromium oxide with net heat release, and if this occurs at the surface, it constitutes one route by which the burning rate could be enhanced, Fe{sub 2}O{sub 3} possibly enhances near-surface breakdown of heavy fuel molecules, and the melt layer on AP particles and the low-viscosity binder-melt, which exist when LiF is present in the propellants, possibly depress the burning rate.
RELATION: Journal Name: Combustion and Flame; (USA); Journal Volume: 80:1

TITLE: Activity and selectivity in carbon monoxide hydrogenation over rhodium supported on pure zirconia and on K-, P-, and Y-doped zirconia
AUTHORS: Benedetti, A; Pinna, F; Tessari, R; Strukul, G; Carimati, A; Marengo, S; Zerlia, T; Zanderighi, L
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; RHODIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; CHEMISORPTION; DOPED MATERIALS; ETHANOL; FISCHER-TROPSCH SYNTHESIS; FOURIER TRANSFORMATION; HYDROGEN; HYDROGENATION; INFRARED SPECTRA; OXYGEN; PHOSPHORUS; PHOTOACOUSTIC SPECTROSCOPY; POTASSIUM; QUANTITY RATIO; REDUCTION; SURFACE PROPERTIES; SYNTHESIS; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; X-RAY DIFFRACTION; YTTRIUM; ZIRCONIUM OXIDES; ALCOHOLS; ALKALI METALS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COHERENT SCATTERING; CONTROL; DIFFRACTION; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INTEGRAL TRANSFORMATIONS; MATERIALS; METALS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; SCATTERING; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SORPTION; SPECTRA; SPECTROSCOPY; TRANSFORMATIONS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; ZIRCONIUM COMPOUNDS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Catalysts for the CO/H{sub 2} reaction were prepared by supporting Rh{sub 4}(CO){sub 12} on pure ZrO{sub 2}, with different phase compositions, and on ZrO{sub 2} doped at the surface or in the bulk with K{sub 2}O, P{sub 2}O{sub 5}, or Y{sub 2}O{sub 3}, and by decomposing the supported carbonyl in a hydrogen stream at 523 or 823 K. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, oxygen and hydrogen chemisorption, TPR, FT-IR/PAS, and catalytic activity measurements both in temperature-programmed experiments and in isothermal condition runs, at atmospheric pressure and with different feed compositions. The phase composition of the support or the doping procedure (bulk or surface) has a minor effect on the physicochemical properties and catalytic activity. Also, the various doping agents, with the exception of K{sub 2}O, have minor effects. K{sub 2}O doping decreases the activity and changes the selectivity of Rh/ZrO{sub 2} in the CO/H{sub 2} reaction, favoring the formation of oxygenated compounds. Activation at high temperature (823 K) decreases the activity but does not change the selectivity of the catalysts. A significant influence of the feed H{sub 2}/CO ratio on activity and selectivity has been found: activity decreases with H{sub 2}/CO ratio and selectivity to oxygenates increases. The role of the various parameters investigated is discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 122:2

TITLE: The effect of lanthanum promoter on the selectivity of Pd/zeolite-X in methanol synthesis
AUTHORS: Choudary, B M; Matusek, K; Bogyay, I; Guczi, L
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; LANTHANUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; METHANOL; SYNTHESIS; PALLADIUM; BIMETALS; CALCINATION; CATALYSIS; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMISORPTION; DESORPTION; ETHERS; HYDROGEN; HYDROGENATION; LANTHANUM OXIDES; OXYGEN; PALLADIUM OXIDES; PROMOTERS; REDUCTION; STABILIZATION; SURFACE PROPERTIES; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; TITRATION; ZEOLITES; ALCOHOLS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONTROL; DECOMPOSITION; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; KINETICS; LANTHANUM COMPOUNDS; MATERIALS; METALS; MINERALS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PALLADIUM COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; PYROLYSIS; RARE EARTH COMPOUNDS; RARE EARTHS; REACTION KINETICS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SORPTION; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-)
DESCRIPTION: The promoting effect of various amounts of lanthanum on Pd/zeolite-X in enhancing selectivity in CO hydrogenation toward methanol/oxygenates has been investigated. The catalysts were characterized by temperature-programmed reduction, O{sub 2}-H{sub 2} titration, and temperature-programmed desorption. The dispersion and H{sub 2} chemisorption of Pd/zeolite-X catalysts were almost unchanged on La promotion. The virtually unchanged chemisorption capacity of the Pd/zeolite-X catalysts on La promotion is attributed to the cationic exchange method adopted to introduce La after Pd introduction into the zeolites. The La{sub 2}O{sub 3} formed during calcination was partially reduced during reduction with hydrogen due to its contact with palladium. PdLaO{sub x} entities formed thereby trigger the activation of coordinated CO/H{sub 2} and facilitate the hydrogenation of CO to methanol/oxygenates at low temperature. Thus, the Pd sites responsible for methanol synthesis are stabilized by La at low and high pressures. Dimethyl ether, dominant for low La content Pd/zeolite-X catalysts, may be ascribed to the acid sites developed, but other mechanisms cannot be ruled out. The effect of the zeolite matrix lies in the stabilization of PdLaO{sub x} entities, but otherwise it behaves in a similar fashion to other supports. The zeolite lattice, however, ensures the maintenance of small PdLaO{sub x} particles. The turnover frequency values obtained with the optimum La promotion on Pd/zeolite-X are consistent with the reported values observed on Pd/La{sub 2}O{sub 3} catalysts. The zeolites are therefore potential alternative supports in the preparation of suitable bimetallic systems.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 122:2

TITLE: Solid electrolyte aided study of methane oxidative coupling; Electrochemical oxygen pumping on Pt and Au-YSZ
AUTHORS: Eng, D W
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; HYDROCARBONS; CATALYTIC CRACKING; METHANE; ENERGY CONVERSION; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; COMBUSTION PRODUCTS; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; HIGH-TEMPERATURE FUEL CELLS; MAGNESIUM OXIDES; PLATINUM; SOLID ELECTROLYTES; YTTRIUM OXIDES; ZIRCONIUM OXIDES; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKANES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHEMISTRY; CONVERSION; CRACKING; DECOMPOSITION; DIRECT ENERGY CONVERTERS; ELECTROCHEMICAL CELLS; ELECTROLYTES; ELEMENTS; FUEL CELLS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; PYROLYSIS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; YTTRIUM COMPOUNDS; ZIRCONIUM COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-)
DESCRIPTION: This paper reports on the study of methane oxidative coupling. Work has been done to convert methane to C{sub 2} hydrocarbons. The author examines the effects of electrochemical oxygen pumping on methane coupling in a solid electrolyte cell. The work reported focuses on results obtained with P + and Au-YSZ (yttrium-stabilized zirconia) catalysts.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the Electrochemical Society; (USA); Journal Volume: 137:4

TITLE: Selective dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde over silicalite-1
AUTHORS: Matsumura, Yasuyuki; Hashimoto, Keiji; Yoshida, Satohiro
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ACETALDEHYDE; SYNTHESIS; ETHANOL; DEHYDROGENATION; ZEOLITES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; ADSORPTION; HEAT TREATMENTS; INFRARED SPECTRA; LEACHING; PH VALUE; POISONING; SILICON OXIDES; SODIUM; SURFACE PROPERTIES; ALCOHOLS; ALDEHYDES; ALKALI METALS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; DISSOLUTION; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; MATERIALS; METALS; MINERALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SORPTION; SPECTRA; 102000* - Synthetic Fuels- Products & By-Products- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Silicalite-1 catalyzes ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde. On the basis of the IR spectra of ethanol adsorbed on its surface, the active sites are believed to be the active oxygen bridges on which dissociative adsorption of ethanol can take place. The active sites are stable compared with the active oxygen bridges on highly dehydrated silica, which also catalyze the selective ethanol dehydrogenation. Since there were trace amounts of acid site on the silicalite-1, simultaneous ethanol dehydration was observed. However, almost all the acid sites disappeared by heating at 1,070 K in the case of silicalite-1 containing 0.7 wt% of sodium ions, and ethanol was selectively converted to acetaldehyde. In this treatment, the sodium ions partly poison the active sites for dehydrogenation, but their activity is restored by leaching excess sodium ions from the silicalite-1 under reflux in water.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 122:2

TITLE: Mechanism of catalase activity in aqueous solutions of dimanganese(III,IV) ethylenediamine-N,N prime -diacetate
AUTHORS: Rush, J D; Maskos, Z
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; CATALASE; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; HYDROGEN PEROXIDE; REDUCTION; MANGANESE COMPOUNDS; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; EDTA; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; AMINO ACIDS; CARBOXYLIC ACIDS; CHELATING AGENTS; DATA; DISPERSIONS; ENZYMES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; MIXTURES; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDOREDUCTASES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PEROXIDASES; PEROXIDES; SOLUTIONS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 100300* - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: Manganous ions, ligated by ethylenediamine-N,N{prime}-diacetate (edda = L) decompose hydrogen peroxide with a rate law {minus}d(H{sub 2}O{sub 2})/dt = k{sub 17}(Mn(edda))(H{sub 2}O{sub 2}) where k{sub 17} = 5.4 M{sup {minus}1} s{sup {minus}1} at pH 7. The reduction of peroxide to water is initiated by the reaction of Mn{sup II}L with a dinuclear Mn{sup III,IV}L{sub 2}. A subsequent fast reaction between the transient product of this reaction and hydrogen peroxide or tert-butyl hydroperoxide effectively oxidizes Mn(II) to Mn(IV) in a concerted step without formation of the hydroxyl radical. The green mixed-valence complex, which is probably a bis({mu}-oxo)-bridged structure, is stable in neutral aqueous solution and exhibits a 16-line ESR signal in frozen solution. The basis of catalase activity is the autocatalytic formation of this complex when hydrogen peroxide is reduced by manganese(II). The catalase cycle is independent of the formation of oxy radicals. Mononuclear Mn{sup III}edda and Mn{sup II}edda react with superoxide radicals, but the decomposition of peroxide is virtually independent of these reactions. In unbuffered solutions, with a moderate excess of hydrogen peroxide, an oscillation in the concentration of the dinuclear complex is detected. 28 refs., 10 figs., 5 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Inorganic Chemistry; (USA); Journal Volume: 29:5

TITLE: Preparation and study of the Fe sub 2 sup + -benzyne ion in the gas phase
AUTHORS: Huang, Yongqing; Freiser, B S
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; ALKANES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; AROMATICS; IRON COMPLEXES; ORGANOMETALLIC COMPOUNDS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; COMPLEXES; DATA; HYDROCARBONS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPLEXES; 100300* - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: The results of a study of the preparation and reactivity of the Fe{sup +}{sub 2}-benzyne ion in the gas phase is reported herein. This study continues the investigation into the reactivity of transition-metal dinuclear ions as compared with their constituent monoatomic ionic species. The enhanced reactivity of Fe{sup +}{sub 2}-benzyne over the Fe{sub 2}{sup +} is thought to be due to two effects: (1) the ligand polarizes or in some way changes the electronic structure of the metal center to prevent oxidative addition and (2) the combination of the highly unsaturated benzyne ligand provides a very efficient pathway for further reaction steps following initial metal center oxidative insertion. 24 refs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Inorganic Chemistry; (USA); Journal Volume: 29:5

TITLE: X-ray study of Ta(CHCMe sub 3 )(S-2,4,6-C sub 6 H sub 2 -i-Pr sub 3 ) sub 3 (SEt sub 2 ) suggests why it is inactive for metathesis of ordinary olefins
AUTHORS: Wallace, K C; Davis, W M; Schrock, R R
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; ALKANES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; DECOMPOSITION; HETEROCYCLIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC SULFUR COMPOUNDS; ORGANOMETALLIC COMPOUNDS; TANTALUM COMPLEXES; CATALYSIS; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COMPLEXES; DATA; HYDROCARBONS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPLEXES; 100300* - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: The catalytic effect on the metathesis of olefins of tantalum alkylidene complexes of the type Ta(CHCMe{sub 3})(DIPP){sub 3}(THF) (DIPP = 0-2,6-C{sub 6}H{sub 3}-i-Pr{sub 2}) and Ta(CHCMe{sub 3})(TIPT){sub 3}(THF) (TIPT = S-2,4,6-C{sub 6}H{sub 2}-i-Pr{sub 2}) are contrasted. The complexes of DIPP react with terminal olefins or ethylene to yield base-free tantalacyclobutane complexes, but the TIPT complexes do not react with ordinary olefins and will not methasize them. The TIPT complex has been prepared in crystalline form, and its structure was found to be significantly different from that of the DIPP complex to partially explain the differences in catalytic behavior. 13 refs., 1 fig., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Inorganic Chemistry; (USA); Journal Volume: 29:5

TITLE: Butene-1 is made from ethylene
AUTHORS: Hennico, A; Leonard, J; Forestiere, A; Glaize, Y
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; BUTENES; MARKET; ETHYLENE; ENERGY CONVERSION; POLYETHYLENES; MANUFACTURING; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; HOMOGENEOUS CATALYSIS; LOW PRESSURE; ALKENES; CATALYSIS; CONVERSION; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC POLYMERS; POLYMERS; POLYOLEFINS; REACTION KINETICS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100700 - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The development of industrial processes to manufacture at relatively low pressure a very high quality linear low density polyethylene (LLDPE) has considerably influenced the market potential of butene-1. Not only can butene-1 be polymerized directly to polybutene, but butene-1 is finding greater use as a comonomer with ethylene in the manufacture of various types of polyethylenes, mainly LLDPE (see accompanying box). This paper presents a process which will produce butene-1 by selectively dimerizing ethylene. The process uses a homogeneous catalyst system where reactants, products and catalyst are all soluble in the same liquid phase---thereby avoiding some of the disadvantages of heterogenous catalysts. The catalyst system also avoids isomerization of butene-1 to butene-2 and hence there is no need for product superfractionation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrocarbon Processing; (USA); Journal Volume: 69:3

TITLE: Make C sub 3 -C sub 4 olefins selectively
AUTHORS: Pujado, P R; Vora, B V
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; BUTENES; MANUFACTURING; PROPYLENE; ALKENES; CATALYTIC CRACKING; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CRACKING; DECOMPOSITION; HYDROCARBONS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PYROLYSIS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: When the demand for C{sub 3} olefin, a specific C{sub 4} olefin or group of these, exceeds the amount available as byproduct from existing processes, a more selective process is preferred. The Oleflex catalytic dehydrogenation process represents an economical method to produce propylene and butenes in high selectivities from the corresponding paraffin. The process can be operated as a stand-alone unit or integrated in a new or existing olefin complex. This article outlines several different processing schemes that incorporate the Oleflex process.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrocarbon Processing; (USA); Journal Volume: 69:3

TITLE: Ethylene profitability trends
AUTHORS: Field, S
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ETHYLENE; PRODUCTION; ECONOMICS; OPERATION; PETROCHEMICAL PLANTS; ALKENES; CHEMICAL PLANTS; HYDROCARBONS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; 020500* - Petroleum- Products & By-Products; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 100700 - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The profitability of ethylene production is related mainly to plant capacity use. The world ethylene capacity squeeze in 1988 and 1989 caused net margins to soar to unprecedented levels. The rush to capture the alluring profits by increasing production via new capacity additions will cause increasing competition and a normal decline in profitability over the next few years. A period of reasonable profit stability is expected to follow. According to the author, the world petrochemical industry is now operating at the high-capacity use, high-profitability end of the spectrum.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrocarbon Processing; (USA); Journal Volume: 69:3

TITLE: Remote gas conversion in worldscale methanol plant
AUTHORS: LeBlane, J R; Rovner, J M
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 03 NATURAL GAS; METHANOL PLANTS; OPERATION; NATURAL GAS; ENERGY CONVERSION; COMPUTER-AIDED DESIGN; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; GLOBAL ASPECTS; MARKET; CONVERSION; EFFICIENCY; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 100700 - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-); 030400 - Natural Gas- Products & By-Products
DESCRIPTION: The authors' company is using a methanol plant to help move Chilean natural gas to distance markets. The plant's capacity is 2,500 short tons per day (stpd) making it the world's largest single-train methanol plant in successful operation. This paper discusses how design and construction of the project used new and innovative technology along with computer aided engineering execution. The results included: completion ahead of schedule, smooth startup, highly energy efficient operation and exceptionally high serviceability for a plant located in a remote part of the world.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrocarbon Processing; (USA); Journal Volume: 69:3

TITLE: New developments in shift catalysts for ammonia
AUTHORS: Carstensen, J H; Bogild-Hansen, J; Pedersen, P S
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; AMMONIA; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMICAL PLANTS; HEAT RECOVERY; BY-PRODUCTS; CARBON MONOXIDE; ENERGY CONVERSION; LOW TEMPERATURE; OPTIMIZATION; PRESSURE DROP; SHIFT PROCESSES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CONVERSION; ENERGY RECOVERY; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; KINETICS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; RECOVERY; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: The steam requirement of an ammonia unit can be reduced by lowering the steam-to-carbon (S/C) ratio to the primary reformer, but a number of drawbacks can exist downstream in the high and low temperature shift (HTS and LTS) converters: byproduct formation in the HTS, pressure drop buildup in the HTS, reversible poisoning of low temperature shift catalyst, and higher CO equilibrium concentrations existing HTS and LTS. Two solutions to these problems are presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrocarbon Processing; (USA); Journal Volume: 69:3

TITLE: The kinetics of formaldehyde oxidation and emissions reduction in methanol fueled vehicles
AUTHORS: Sodhi, D; Abraham, M A; Summers, J C
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; AUTOMOBILES; AIR POLLUTION CONTROL; FORMALDEHYDE; OXIDATION; CARBON DIOXIDE; CARBON MONOXIDE; CATALYTIC CONVERTERS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; METHANOL FUELS; PLATINUM; ALCOHOL FUELS; ALDEHYDES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONTROL; ELEMENTS; EQUIPMENT; FUELS; KINETICS; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; POLLUTION CONTROL; POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT; REACTION KINETICS; SYNTHETIC FUELS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; VEHICLES; 100900* - Synthetic Fuels- Environmental Aspects- (1990-); 540120 - Environment, Atmospheric- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Oxidation of formaldehyde over supported platinum catalyst produced CO{sub 2} as a major product and CO as a minor product under a wide range of inlet concentrations and reaction temperatures. The temporal variation of CO yield proceeded through a maximum suggesting that it was produced as an intermediate in the pathway leading to CO{sub 2}. CO selectivity (s{sub CO} = y{sub CO}/x{sub HCHO}) was maximized by operating at oxygen concentration below the stoichiometric point and at high reaction temperatures. A mechanism for formaldehyde oxidation is proposed which involves adsorption of formaldehyde followed by catalytic decomposition to CO and H{sub 2} and oxidation of the surface species; the rate limiting step apparently shifts from the decomposition at high oxygen concentration to the oxidation of surface species at low concentration. The rate expression was obtained from the postulated mechanism and found to be consistent with the experimental results. The maximum for the yield of CO provided a second method by which to confirm the postulated rate expression.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the Air and Waste Management Association; (USA); Journal Volume: 40:3
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of the Air and Waste Management Association; (USA)

TITLE: The nature of catalytic sites on lanthanum and neodymium oxides for dehydration/dehydrogenation of ethanol
AUTHORS: Rosynek, M P; Koprowski, R J; DelliSante, G N
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; ETHANOL; DEHYDRATION; DEHYDROGENATION; LANTHANUM OXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; NEODYMIUM OXIDES; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; INFRARED SPECTRA; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; PH VALUE; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; SAMPLE PREPARATION; SURFACE PROPERTIES; ALCOHOLS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; LANTHANUM COMPOUNDS; NEODYMIUM COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RARE EARTH COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; SPECTRA; 102000* - Synthetic Fuels- Products & By-Products- (1990-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: The multi-pathway (dehydration/dehydrogenation) conversion of ethanol has been used to investigate the nature and behavior of catalytically active sites on lanthanum and neodymium sesquioxides. Catalytic reaction data, coupled with infrared spectroscopic characterizations of adsorbed species, indicate that at least two different types of catalytically active sites are generated on activated La{sub 2}O{sub 3} and Nd{sub 2}O{sub 3} surfaces that are prepared by thermal dehydration of the corresponding trihydroxides. One kind of site (designated Type I) is much less numerous than the other (Type II), but is more strongly basic and has a much higher initial activity for alcohol dehydration, via a probable ethoxide intermediate, at 300-400{degree}C. The parallel alcohol dehydrogenation pathway, on the other hand, occurs only on Type II sites, which also have moderate dehydration activity. The resulting aldehyde products readsorbs exclusively on the more strongly basic Type I sites, where it undergoes a series of secondary condensation reactions that cause a decrease in the overall rate of alcohol dehydration. The comparative behavioral features of the two kinds of sites may be due to differing surface environments, with Type I sites being in structurally more defective and/or more energetic surface locations than are Type II sites. Increases in pretreatment temperature of the oxides cause thermally induced transformations of Type I sites into Type II sites by a surface annealing or restructuring process, with corresponding modifications in the observed catalytic behavior for the two alcohol conversion pathways. 33 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 122:1

TITLE: Preparation and characterization of bimetallic oxides of chromium and titanium
AUTHORS: Cheng, Soofin; Cheng, Shengyuan
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; CHROMIUM OXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; ETHANE; DEHYDROGENATION; PROPANOLS; DECOMPOSITION; TITANIUM OXIDES; ADSORPTION; CALCINATION; CARBON DIOXIDE; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; ETHYLENE; INFRARED SPECTRA; MICROSTRUCTURE; MIXTURES; OXIDATION; PYRIDINE; QUANTITY RATIO; SODIUM HYDROXIDES; SURFACE PROPERTIES; SYNTHESIS; ALCOHOLS; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKANES; ALKENES; AZINES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS; DISPERSIONS; HETEROCYCLIC COMPOUNDS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXIDES; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PYRIDINES; PYROLYSIS; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SORPTION; SPECTRA; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TITANIUM COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 020400 - Petroleum- Processing; 102000 - Synthetic Fuels- Products & By-Products- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Mixed oxides of Cr(III) and Ti(IV) were prepared by the hydrothermal method in basic solutions (pH > 12). With NaOH as base, the resultant materials had a layered structure. After exchange with NH{sub 4}{sup +} ions and calcination at 623 K, the layered structure was converted to the anatase phase. When the calcination temperature was raised to 723 K and higher, a portion of the anatase phase was converted to the rutile phase for samples of high Cr(III) content. The latter also contained a small amount of Cr{sub 2}O{sub 3} structure. When the 2-propanol decomposition reaction was carried out, the mixed oxides demonstrated both acidic and basic sites on the surfaces. Furthermore, both Broensted and Lewis acid sites were found on the surface of the bimetallic oxides, based on IR spectra of the adsorbed pyridine. The Broensted acid sites were identified as CrO-H groups. When the bimetallic oxides were used as catalysts in oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane, activity was found to be a function of Cr content. The Cr-O species were proposed to be the active sites for formation of both ethylene and CO{sub 2}. Titanium served as a diluent.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 122:1

TITLE: X-ray absorption spectroscopic evidence for binding of the competitive inhibitor 2-mercaptoethanol to the nickel sites of Jack bean urease. A new Ni-Ni interaction in the inhibited enzyme
AUTHORS: Clark, P A; Wilcox, D E; Scott, R A
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; AMMONIA; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; NICKEL COMPLEXES; STRUCTURAL CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; ORGANOMETALLIC COMPOUNDS; UREA; HYDROLYSIS; UREASE; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; CATALYSIS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; PLANTS; X RADIATION; AMIDES; AMIDINASES; CARBONIC ACID DERIVATIVES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COMPLEXES; DATA; DECOMPOSITION; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ENZYMES; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROLASES; INFORMATION; IONIZING RADIATIONS; LYSIS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NON-PEPTIDE C-N HYDROLASES; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; RADIATIONS; SOLVOLYSIS; SPECTROSCOPY; SYNTHESIS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPLEXES; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The enzyme Jack bean urease has been identified as the first nickel-containing metalloenzyme to catalyze the hydrolysis of urea to carbon dioxide and ammonia. Competitive inhibitors such as 2-mercaptoethanol (2-ME) have been shown to dramatically affect the ground-state electronic properties of the urease Ni(II) ions. Results of preliminary structural investigations using x-ray absorption spectroscopy of the nickel salts of urease in its native and 2-ME bound forms are presented. The binding of 2-ME to Ni(II) through the thiolate sulfur is confirmed by the results of this study. 17 refs., 2 figs., 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Inorganic Chemistry; (USA); Journal Volume: 29:4

TITLE: Synthesis of rhodium-containing heterobimetallic hydride complexes
AUTHORS: Casey, C P; Whiteker, G T
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; HYDRIDES; SYNTHESIS; RHENIUM COMPLEXES; RHODIUM COMPLEXES; TANTALUM COMPLEXES; MOLECULAR STRUCTURE; REDUCTION; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COMPLEXES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPLEXES; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: The reduction chemistry of heterobimetallic dihydrides are of much interest. Three heterobimetallic monohydride complexes containing Rh bound to either Re or Ta were isolated during synthetic attempts at preparing heterobimetallic dihydrides. The mode of synthesis, characterization, and reactivity of these three heterobimetallic compounds are discussed herein. 19 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Inorganic Chemistry; (USA); Journal Volume: 29:4

TITLE: Harried LP-gas marketers recount the recent price/supply nightmare
AUTHORS: Prowler, S
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES; MARKET; FORECASTING; PRICES; PROPANE; SUPPLY AND DEMAND; SURVEYS; ALKANES; FLUIDS; HYDROCARBONS; LIQUEFIED GASES; LIQUIDS; NATURAL GAS LIQUIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; 020700* - Petroleum- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 100700 - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-)

Supply strategies for the future are discussed.

TITLE: Gas dehydration process upgraded
AUTHORS: Smith, R S
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; BENZENE; RECOVERY; TOLUENE; XYLENES; BY-PRODUCTS; DEHYDRATION; GLYCOLS; PETROLEUM REFINERIES; SEPARATION PROCESSES; ALCOHOLS; ALKYLATED AROMATICS; AROMATICS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; 020400* - Petroleum- Processing; 020500 - Petroleum- Products & By-Products; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Gas dehydration for special situations can be achieved by the glycol enhancement technology of the Drizo process. This paper describes a process schematic of a Drizo gas dehydration unit. The process uses technology practiced for the past ten years to achieve very high concentrations of glycol. Occasionally, the technology can be retrofitted into an existing glycol unit, but in general, it is preferable to incorporate various modifications to conventional dehydration and install some new equipment. The following elements would be added to a conventional glycol unit to convert to a Drizo system: solvent-water overhead condenser, solvent-water separator, solvent pumps and solvent heater.
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrocarbon Processing; (USA); Journal Volume: 69:2

TITLE: Surface organometallic chemistry on metals. III. Formation of a bimetallic Ni-Sn phase generated by reaction of a Sn(n-C sub 4 H sub 9 ) sub 4 and silica-supported nickel oxide
AUTHORS: Agnelli, M; Candy, J P; Basset, J M; Bournonville, J P; Ferretti, O A
SUBJECT: 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; NICKEL ALLOYS; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; PHASE STUDIES; NICKEL OXIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; TIN ALLOYS; TIN COMPOUNDS; ACETATES; BIMETALS; CARBON MONOXIDE; CATALYSIS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMISORPTION; ELECTRON DENSITY; ETHANOL; HYDROGENATION; HYDROXYL RADICALS; INFRARED SPECTRA; METHANATION; ORGANOMETALLIC COMPOUNDS; REDOX POTENTIAL; SCANNING ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; SYNTHESIS; TRANSMISSION ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; ALCOHOLS; ALLOYS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CARBOXYLIC ACID SALTS; CHALCOGENIDES; ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; MICROSCOPY; NICKEL COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RADICALS; REACTION KINETICS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SORPTION; SPECTRA; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 360102* - Metals & Alloys- Structure & Phase Studies; 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Reaction of Sn(n-C{sub 4}H{sub 9}){sub 4} with NiO/SiO{sub 2} occurs above 423 K according to the apparent following stoichiometry: NiO + xSn(n-C{sub 4}H{sub 9}){sub 4} {yields} NiSn{sub x} + (2x + 1)C{sub 4}H{sub 8} + (2x {minus} 1)C{sub 4}H{sub 10} + H{sub 2}O. Various compositions of the bimetallic phase can be achieved by changing the initial Sn/Ni ratio. The obtained catalysts were very active and selective in the hydrogenation of ethyl acetate to ethanol. Characterization of the bimetallic phase has shown that the particles are bimetallic (STEM). As a result of chemisorption IR, and magnetic measurements, it appears that the presence of tin has four effects: (i) it decreases significantly the amount of CO and H{sub 2} adsorbed; (ii) it isolates nickel atoms from their neighbors; (iii) it increases electron density on nickel; and (IV) it suppresses the magnetic properties of nickel. Redox behavior of Ni-Sn/SiO{sub 2} toward surface OH indicates that surface hydroxyls can oxidize Sn{sup (0)}, probably to Sn{sup (II)} with evolution of H{sub 2}, the process being reversible with H{sub 2}. It is suggested that during this oxidation process, tin migrates to the periphery of the bimetallic particle with formation of (chemical bond Si-O){sub 2}Sn{sup (II)} surface species.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 121:2

TITLE: Structure and water-oxidizing capabilities of dimeric ruthenium EDTA complex ions
AUTHORS: Zhou, Jinzhong; Xi, Wu; Hurst, J K
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; EDTA; STRUCTURAL CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; IONS; RUTHENIUM COMPLEXES; WATER; OXIDATION; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; ISOTOPE EFFECTS; OXYGEN 18; AMINO ACIDS; CARBOXYLIC ACIDS; CHARGED PARTICLES; CHELATING AGENTS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COMPLEXES; DATA; EVEN-EVEN NUCLEI; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; ISOTOPES; LIGHT NUCLEI; NUCLEI; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN ISOTOPES; STABLE ISOTOPES; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPLEXES; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 400202 - Isotope Effects, Isotope Exchange, & Isotope Separation; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Low-temperature resonance Raman (RR) spectra of the dimeric Ru{sup III}Ru{sup IV} ion formed by oxidation of Ru(edta)OH{sub 2}{sup {minus}} exhibited a prominent band at 433 cm{sup {minus}1}, which shifted to 431 cm{sup {minus}1} upon substitution of ({sup 18}O)-H{sub 2}O in the primary coordination sphere of the precursor ion. A second band, at 324 cm{sup {minus}1}, underwent a comparable isotope-dependent shift to lower energies. The RR spectra were insensitive to deuterium substitution. These features establish that the dimer is a {mu}-oxo ion, i.e. (Ru(edta)){sub 2}O{sup 3{minus}}; from the magnitude of the isotopic shifts, the Ru-O-Ru angle was estimated to be 165{degree}. The reduction potential for the Ru{sup IV}{sub 2}/Ru{sup III}Ru{sup IV} couple was acid-insensitive over the range pH 2-11, suggesting that the dimer does not contain coordinated H{sub 2}O in either oxidation state. Cyclic voltammographic results in neutral solution suggested that (Ru(edta)){sub 2}O{sup 2{minus}} was unstable with respect to decomposition. A reinvestigation of the water-oxidizing capabilities of this ion by polarographic, gas chromatographic, and mass spectrometric methods failed to reveal O{sub 2} among the gaseous products. Instead, copious quantities of CO{sub 2} were formed, the source of which was coordinated EDTA. 29 refs., 8 figs., 1 tab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Inorganic Chemistry; (USA); Journal Volume: 29:2

TITLE: Ozone control and methanol fuel use
AUTHORS: Russell, A G; Pierre, D; Milford, J B
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; METHANOL; USES; OZONE; CONTROL; AIR POLLUTION; AIR QUALITY; AUTOMOTIVE FUELS; CALIFORNIA; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; ALCOHOLS; DATA; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; FEDERAL REGION IX; FUELS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; NORTH AMERICA; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; POLLUTION; USA; 100900* - Synthetic Fuels- Environmental Aspects- (1990-); 540120 - Environment, Atmospheric- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Methanol fuel use in motor vehicles and stationary combustion has the potential to improve air quality. A modeling study of methanol fuel use in Los Angeles, California, shows that the low chemical reactivity of methanol vapor slows ozone formation and would lead to lower ozone concentrations. Predicted peak ozone levels decreased up to 16% and exposure to levels above the federal standard dropped by up to 22%, when pure (M100) methanol fuel use was simulated for the year 2000. Similar results were obtained for 2010. Use of a gasoline-methanol blend (M85) resulted in smaller reductions. Predicted formaldehyde levels and exposure were not increased severely, and in some cases declined, in the simulations of methanol use. 17 refs., 3 figs., 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science (Washington, D.C.); (USA); Journal Volume: 247:4939

TITLE: Webb report adds support for choosing LPG as a motor fuel
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 33 ADVANCED PROPULSION SYSTEMS; BUTANE; MARKET; PROPANE; VEHICLES; FUEL SUBSTITUTION; LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES; SUPPLY AND DEMAND; SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALKANES; FLUIDS; FUELS; HYDROCARBONS; LIQUEFIED GASES; LIQUIDS; NATURAL GAS LIQUIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; 100700* - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-); 330800 - Emission Control- Alternative Fuels
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses a study on choosing propane and butane as an alternate transportation fuel (ATF). According to this article, the results of the study indicate that propane and butane have met two of the challenges facing selection of an ATF: there is a ready supply of the product and conversion equipment is easily available. Primary goals identified by the study are presented and discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Butane-Propane News; (USA); Journal Volume: 22:1

TITLE: In central Washington, LP-gas helps keep fruit baskets overflowing
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 17 WIND ENERGY; PROPANE; COMBUSTION; WIND TURBINES; FUEL SUPPLIES; CROPS; DRYING; HEATERS; LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES; USES; ALKANES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ENERGY SUPPLIES; FLUIDS; HYDROCARBONS; LIQUEFIED GASES; LIQUIDS; MACHINERY; NATURAL GAS LIQUIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDATION; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 100400* - Synthetic Fuels- Combustion- (1990-); 100700 - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-); 170601 - Wind Energy Engineering- Applications
DESCRIPTION: This article describes how propane-fueled wind machines are being in the fruit production process. The application discussed include frost protection with wind machines and heaters, pesticide spraying, and crop drying. Wind machine products are described. A comparison of wind machines and heaters is presented.

TITLE: Influence of oil aromaticity on N sub 2 -flooding in North Sea fields; Preliminary thermodynamic analysis
AUTHORS: de Leeuw, V V; Bekkering, P E; Runde, H; de Loos, T W; de Swaan Avons, J
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 42 ENGINEERING; NITROGEN; INJECTION; NORTH SEA; OIL FIELDS; ENHANCED RECOVERY; PETROLEUM; VISCOSITY; BINARY MIXTURES; BUTANE; CALCULATION METHODS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; DECANE; HYDROCARBONS; METHANE; MISCIBLE-PHASE DISPLACEMENT; PHASE STUDIES; THERMODYNAMICS; ALKANES; ATLANTIC OCEAN; DISPERSIONS; ELEMENTS; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUID INJECTION; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; INTAKE; KINETICS; MINERAL RESOURCES; MIXTURES; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM DEPOSITS; REACTION KINETICS; RECOVERY; RESOURCES; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; 020300* - Petroleum- Drilling & Production; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 423000 - Engineering- Marine Engineering- (1980-); 023000 - Petroleum- Properties & Composition
DESCRIPTION: A synthetic oil has been defined, typical for crudes found in the North Sea. It consists of 65 mole % methane, 15 mole % n-butane and 20 mole % n-tetradecane. Aromaticity has been varied by replacing n-tetradecane by n-octyl-benzene. Minimum miscibility pressures (MMP's) and vapor-liquid equilibria (VLE) of these synthetic oils have been calculated for adding nitrogen. The Peng-Robinson equation of state has been used in conjunction with binary interaction parameters, either experimentally determined or from independent correlations. It appeared that aromaticity hardly influences MMP's but that it has a significant impact on the mutual miscibility of equilibrium phases at 373.15 K and 400 bar. The MMP-calculation shows to be very sensitive to the (methane + n-octyl-benzene) interaction parameter.
RELATION: Journal Name: In Situ; (USA); Journal Volume: 14:3

TITLE: Kinetics of liquid phase catalytic dehydration of methanol to dimethyl ether
AUTHORS: Gogate, M R; Lee, B G; Lee, S; Kulik, C J
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; METHANOL; CATALYTIC CONVERTERS; ACTIVATION ENERGY; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; GASES; LIQUIDS; MASS TRANSFER; METHYL ETHER; MIXTURES; PHASE STUDIES; REGRESSION ANALYSIS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; ALCOHOLS; DISPERSIONS; ENERGY; EQUIPMENT; ETHERS; FLUIDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; MATHEMATICS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT; REACTION KINETICS; STATISTICS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: This paper reports the kinetics of the liquid phase catalytic dehydration of methanol to dimethyl ether investigated. The experiments were carried out under low concentrations of feed in a 1-L stirred autoclave, according to a statistical experimental design. The inert liquid phase used for this investigation was a 78:22 blend of paraffinic and naphthenic mineral oils. A complete thermodynamic analysis was carried out in order to determine the liquid phase concentrations of the dissolved species. A global kinetic model was developed for the rate of dimethyl ether synthesis in terms of the liquid phase concentration of methanol. The activation energy of the reaction was found to be 18,830 cal/gmol. Based on a step-wise linear regression analysis of the kinetic data, the order of the reaction which gave the best fit was 0.28 with respect to methanol.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fuel Science and Technology International; (USA); Journal Volume: 8:6

TITLE: Carbon monoxide cleavage by (silox) sub 3 Ta (silox = sup t Bu sub 3 SiO sup minus ): Physical, theoretical, and mechanistic investigations
AUTHORS: Neithamer, D R; LaPointe, R E; Wheeler, R A; Richeson, D S; Van Duyne, G D; Wolczanski, P T
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; CLEAVAGE; CATALYSIS; DATA ANALYSIS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MEASURING METHODS; SILANES; SYNTHESIS GAS; TANTALUM; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; DATA; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; METALS; MICROSTRUCTURE; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC SILICON COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 400000* - Chemistry; 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Reduction of (silox){sub 3}TaCl{sub 2} (1, silox = {sup t}Bu{sub 3}SiO{sup {minus}}) with Na/Hg in THF leads to a three-coordinate, Ta(III) siloxide, (silox){sub 3}Ta (2). Derivatization of 2 with excess O{sub 2} or H{sub 2} provides (silox){sub 3}Ta = O (3) and (silox){sub 3}TaH{sub 2} (4), respectively. At 25{degree}C, carbonylation of 2 (0.1-1.0 atom) generates {1/2}{sup 3} and {1/4}((silox){sub 3}Ta){sub 2}({mu}-C{sub 2}) (5), consistent with a CO uptake of 0.47 equiv. X-ray (P{bar 1}, R = 9.6%) structural, IR, and Raman studies of dicarbide 5 manifest a near-linear {mu}-C{sub 2} bridge (TaCC = 173 (3){degree}), a C=C double bond (1.37 (4) {angstrom}, v(C=C) = 1617 cm{sup {minus}1}) and typical TaC double bonds (1.95 (2) {angstrom}, v(Ta=C) = 709 cm{sup {minus}1}), respectively. EHMO calculations of a linear {mu}-C{sub 2}-bridged D{sub 3d}5 indicate that the e{sub g}{sup 2} HOMO ({sup 3}A{sub 2g}, {sup 1}E{sub g}, {sup 1}A{sub 1g}) is {approx} 80% Ta (d{sub xx}, d{sub yz}) and {approx} 20% C (p{sub x}, p{sub y}). Magnetic susceptibility measurements of 5 from 2 to 300 K reveal a large temperature-independent susceptibility (25{degree}C, {mu}{sub eff} = 1.93{mu}{sub B}) and a singlet ground state, either {sup 1}E{sub g}, {sup 1}A{sub 1g} (D{sub 3d}) or one arising from a Jahn-Teller distortion of the {sup 1}E{sub g} level.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the American Chemical Society; (USA); Journal Volume: 111:25

TITLE: Concerning the heat of formation of the isopropyl radical
AUTHORS: Tschuikow-Roux, E; Chen, Yonghua
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ISOPROPYL RADICALS; FORMATION HEAT; DATA ANALYSIS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MEASURING METHODS; REACTION KINETICS; ALKYL RADICALS; DATA; ENTHALPY; INFORMATION; KINETICS; NUMERICAL DATA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RADICALS; REACTION HEAT; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 400000* - Chemistry; 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The heat of formation of the isopropyl radical has been reevaluated using the third-law method and kinetic data for the reactions i-C{sub 3}H{sub 7} {r equilibrium} C{sub 3}H{sub 6} + H and 2i-C{sub 3}H{sub 7} {r equilibrium} 2,3-DMB. The result of {Delta}H{sub f}{sup 0}{sub 298} (i-C{sub 3}H{sub 7}) = 21.0 {plus minus} 0.5 kcal mol{sup {minus}1} agrees with a recent bromination equilibrium study and is consistent with a small barrier ({approx} 1 kcal mol{sup {minus}1}) for internal rotation for each of the two CH{sub 3} groups as found in an ab initio geometry optimization study.

TITLE: Case history of an ethylene tank car explosion
AUTHORS: Vanderwater, R G
SUBJECT: 33 ADVANCED PROPULSION SYSTEMS; 42 ENGINEERING; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ETHYLENE; TANKS; FUELS; SAFETY; RUPTURES; EXPLOSIONS; MOTOR VEHICLE ACCIDENTS; RECOMMENDATIONS; STORAGE FACILITIES; ACCIDENTS; ALKENES; CONTAINERS; FAILURES; HYDROCARBONS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; 330800* - Emission Control- Alternative Fuels; 420205 - Engineering- Transport & Storage Facilities- (1980-); 100600 - Synthetic Fuels- Health & Safety- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: This article discusses the explosion of an ethylene oxide (EO) tank car while it was in storage at a cleaning facility. The results of the investigation into the explosion are presented and discussed in details. Recommendations are made for preparing a tank car for servicing to avoid future accidents.
