TITLE: Diffusion limitations in Fischer-Tropsch catalysts
AUTHORS: Post, M F.M.; Van'tHoog, A C; Minderhoud, J K; Sie, S T
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CATALYSTS; PARTICLE SIZE; POROSITY; COBALT; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; FISCHER-TROPSCH SYNTHESIS; HYDROCARBONS; IRON; SYNTHESIS GAS; CATALYTIC CONVERTERS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMICAL REACTORS; DIFFUSION; ENERGY CONVERSION; VARIATIONS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONVERSION; ELEMENTS; EQUIPMENT; FLUIDS; GASES; KINETICS; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT; REACTION KINETICS; SIZE; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The extent of diffusion limitations in the catalytic conversion of synthesis gas to hydrocarbons by the Fischer-Tropsch reaction has been established for a number of iron- and cobalt-based catalysts. The studies were performed in a fixed-bed microreactor system at temperatures in the range 473-523 {Kappa}. Variation of catalyst particle size in the range 0.2.-2.6 mm shows that the conversion of synthesis gas decreases considerably when the average particle size is increased. The effects of variation of particle size and pore diameter have been quantified with the Thiele model for diffusion limitations. Evidence has accumulated that the limited mobility of reactant molecules in the liquid-filled pores of Fischer-Tropsch catalysts is the main cause of retardation of the reaction rates. The experimentally determined reaction rates with various catalysts operated under different conditions show an excellent fit with the theoretical model.
RELATION: Journal Name: A.I.Ch.E. Journal (American Institute of Chemical Engineers); (USA); Journal Volume: 35:7
JOURNAL_NAME: A.I.Ch.E. Journal (American Institute of Chemical Engineers); (USA)

TITLE: New trends in the rate behavior of rhodium-catalyzed carbonylation of methanol
AUTHORS: Dake, S B; Jaganathan, R; Chaudhari, R V
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; METHANOL; CARBONYLATION; RHODIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; ACETIC ACID; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; CARBON MONOXIDE; CATALYTIC CONVERTERS; PARTIAL PRESSURE; ALCOHOLS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CARBOXYLIC ACIDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; DISPERSIONS; ELEMENTS; EQUIPMENT; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; METALS; MIXTURES; MONOCARBOXYLIC ACIDS; ORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT; SOLUTIONS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The kinetics of the carbonylation of methanol to acetic acid using homogeneous rhodium complex catalysts was studied in aqueous and acetic acid media. In aqueous media, the rate was found to be dependent on carbon monoxide and methanol concentrations. The rate was 0.64th order with respect to methanol concentration. However, with respect to carbon monoxide concentration, the rate was first order at low partial pressures of CO and zero order at higher partial pressures. In acetic acid media, the rate showed a zero-order dependence with respect to methanol concentration, while the rate dependence with respect to carbon monoxide partial pressure was similar to that in aqueous medium. A rate equation is proposed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research; (USA); Journal Volume: 28:7

TITLE: Emissions from IC engines fueled with alcohol-gasoline blends; A literature review
AUTHORS: Beta, R M; Elrod, A C; Rice, R E
SUBJECT: 33 ADVANCED PROPULSION SYSTEMS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALCOHOL FUELS; MIXTURES; AUTOMOTIVE FUELS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; GASOLINE; INTERNAL COMBUSTION ENGINES; AIR POLLUTION CONTROL; COMBUSTION PRODUCTS; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; ENERGY SOURCES; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; FUEL SUBSTITUTION; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; CONTROL; DISPERSIONS; EFFICIENCY; ENGINES; FUELS; HEAT ENGINES; LIQUID FUELS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; POLLUTION CONTROL; SYNTHETIC FUELS; 330700* - Advanced Propulsion Systems- Emission Control; 330800 - Emission Control- Alternative Fuels; 100900 - Synthetic Fuels- Environmental Aspects- (1990-); 100400 - Synthetic Fuels- Combustion- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Since air pollution by automotive exhaust gases is of increasing concern around the world, an examination of the work that has been done with regard to evaluating and reducing it can help focus future efforts in dealing with it. Alcohol-containing fuels not only have been shown to have the potential to produce less of many of the polluting gases, but they also constitute a viable alternative to gasoline from the standpoint of efficiency and reducing dependence on the rapidly dwindling supply of petroleum fuel. This report provides a survey of the literature concerning research reported since 1975 on emissions from IC engines operating on alcohol-gasoline fuel blends. The effects of alcohol on the exhaust emissions (carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons (HC), nitrogen oxides (NO{sub x}), and the aldehydes (CHO)) are reviewed. A comparison is made of the emissions benefits achieved when methanol or ethanol is used either in neat form or as the blending agent with gasoline. The primary dependent variable considered is emission level (reported on various bases) with the main independent variables being fuel composition, equivalence ratio, and ignition timing. Brief mention is also made of the potential emissions reduction that may be achieved by using dissociated methanol.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power; (USA); Journal Volume: 111:3
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power; (USA)

TITLE: Effects of ethanol and/or methanol in alcohol-gasoline blends on exhaust emissions
AUTHORS: Beta, R M; Roan, V P
SUBJECT: 33 ADVANCED PROPULSION SYSTEMS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; AUTOMOTIVE FUELS; COMBUSTION KINETICS; ETHANOL FUELS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; GASOLINE; ADDITIVES; METHANOL FUELS; AIR POLLUTION CONTROL; ALDEHYDES; CARBON DIOXIDE; CARBON MONOXIDE; EXHAUST GASES; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; FUEL SUBSTITUTION; FUEL-AIR RATIO; HYDROCARBONS; ALCOHOL FUELS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CONTROL; DATA; FLUIDS; FUELS; GASEOUS WASTES; GASES; INFORMATION; KINETICS; LIQUID FUELS; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; POLLUTION CONTROL; REACTION KINETICS; SYNTHETIC FUELS; WASTES; 330800* - Emission Control- Alternative Fuels; 100900 - Synthetic Fuels- Environmental Aspects- (1990-); 330700 - Advanced Propulsion Systems- Emission Control; 540120 - Environment, Atmospheric- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The authors discuss the effect on exhaust gas emissions (carbon monoxide, CO, hydrocarbons, HC, and aldehydes, CHO) resulting from mixing methanol and/or ethanol with gasoline for automotive fuels studied experimentally. Tests were conducted on an OEM four-cylinder engine running at different conditions of equivalence ratio and spark timing. Fuel blends with different percentages of alcohol content and different ratios of methanol to ethanol in the alcohol mixture were tested. Results of this investigation indicate that the presence of either or both of the alcohols in fuel blends significantly reduced the concentration of carbon monoxide in the exhaust emissions (up to 40-50 percent compared to pure gasoline only), with methanol slightly more effective than ethanol. Hydrocarbon emissions were also decreased by increasing the alcohol content of the fuel, with minimum hydrocarbon production occurring at percent alcohol-gasoline blends in conjunction with near-stoichiometric air-fuel ratios. However, aldehyde emissions were found to be markedly higher with alcohol-gasoline blends. The 10 percent alcohol-gasoline blends were found to produce about 50 percent more aldehyde emissions than pure gasoline.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power; (USA); Journal Volume: 111:3
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power; (USA)

TITLE: Non-faradaic electrochemical modification of catalytic activity. 2. The case of methanol dehydrogenation and decomposition on Ag
AUTHORS: Neophytides, S; Vayenas, C G
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; METHANOL; DEHYDROGENATION; SILVER; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CARBON MONOXIDE; CATALYSIS; CHEMISORPTION; DECOMPOSITION; ELECTROCHEMICAL COATING; FORMALDEHYDE; METHANE; OXYGEN; SOLID ELECTROLYTES; SURFACE PROPERTIES; SYNTHESIS; ZIRCONIUM OXIDES; ALCOHOLS; ALDEHYDES; ALKANES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL COATING; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; DEPOSITION; ELECTROLYTES; ELEMENTS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; METALS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SORPTION; SURFACE COATING; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; ZIRCONIUM COMPOUNDS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: It was found that the catalytic activity and selectivity of polycrystalline Ag for the dehydrogenation and decomposition of CH{sub 3}OH can be markedly affected by electrochemically pumping oxygen anions from the catalyst surface via stabilized zirconia solid electrolyte cells. The steady-state increases in catalytic rates are typically a factor of 20 higher than the rate of O{sup 2{minus}} transfer from the catalyst surface. Oxygen anion pumping causes up to sixfold increases in the rates of production of H{sub 2}CO, CO, and CH{sub 4} and induces significant changes in product selectivity. Over a wide range of conditions the rates of the catalytic reactions increase exponentially with catalyst-solid electrolyte interface overpotential {eta}, which is proportional to the induced change in catalyst work function. The phenomena are reversible and show that catalyst work function and catalytic activity and selectivity can be varied deliberately by adjusting the catalyst potential. The observed non-Faradaic rate enhancement for this catalytic system can be interpreted by taking into account the decrease in catalyst work function with decreasing catalyst potential and the consequent changes in the strength of chemisorptive bonds.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 118:1

TITLE: High-activity methanol synthesis catalysts derived from rare-earth/copper precursors: Genesis and deactivation of the catalytic system
AUTHORS: Nix, R M; Judd, R W; Lambert, R M; Jennings, J R; Owen, G
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL ACTIVATION; COPPER; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; METHANOL; SYNTHESIS; BIMETALS; CARBON DIOXIDE; CERIUM; CHROMATOGRAPHY; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; DEACTIVATION; HIGH TEMPERATURE; HYDROGEN; NEODYMIUM; NITROUS OXIDE; OXIDATION; POISONING; STABILITY; SURFACE AREA; SYNTHESIS GAS; ALCOHOLS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; METALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN OXIDES; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RARE EARTHS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SURFACE PROPERTIES; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The activation of CeCu{sub 2} and NdCu intermetallic precursors to yield highly active methanol synthesis catalysts has been investigated using microreactor techniques under pressures of 10-15 bar. Activation procedures using synthesis gas alone and using hydrogen pretreatment with subsequent oxidation in either syngas or N{sub 2}O are evaluated and compared. Reactive frontal chromatography was employed to perform in situ measurements of the specific copper surface area: values for active catalysts are typically less than 0.5 m{sup 2}/g and do not correlate with the synthesis activity. The thermal stability and resistance to poisoning of these materials was also studied. They exhibit irreversible deactivation at temperatures greater than 523 K and the activity of oxidized catalysts cannot be fully regenerated on reduction. Exposure of the active catalysts to CO{sub 2} leads to complete loss of synthesis activity at 473 K and results in the formation of a strongly bound CO{sub 2} complex. This CO{sub 2} cannot be fully desorbed below the thermal sintering temperatures of the catalysts. These data and earlier results are rationalized on the basis of an active site for methanol synthesis which involves Cu entities intimately associated with the rare-earth-oxide phase that is generated during activation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 118:1

TITLE: Catalytic behavior and surface chemistry of the ZnO/Al sub 2 O sub 3 system for the decomposition of 2-propanol
AUTHORS: Pepe, F; Angeletti, C; de Rossi, S
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; PROPANOLS; DECOMPOSITION; ZINC OXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; SURFACE PROPERTIES; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CALCINATION; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; DEHYDRATION; DEHYDROGENATION; OXIDATION; QUANTITY RATIO; REDUCTION; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALCOHOLS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PYROLYSIS; SYNTHESIS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; ZINC COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Samples of zinc oxide supported on {gamma}-Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} (5, 15, 30, and 36 Zn atoms per 100 Al atoms) have been calcined at different temperatures and subjected to oxidation-reduction treatments in order to investigate the type and the extent of the metal-support interaction and the defect state of the surface. The samples were then tested as catalysts in the decomposition of 2-propanol. They were found to give both the dehydrogenation and dehydration. The dehydrogenation reaction is due to free zinc oxide present on the surface of the support, whereas the dehydration is due to the support. The effect of the calcination temperature on the formation of a surface spinel and of the redox pretreatments on the activity and selectivity are also discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 118:1

TITLE: Mixed ruthenium-tin boride catalysts for selective hydrogenation of fatty esters to fatty alcohols
AUTHORS: Narasimhan, C S; Deshpande, V M; Ramnarayan, K
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; ALCOHOLS; SYNTHESIS; ESTERS; ENERGY CONVERSION; RUTHENIUM BORIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; TIN BORIDES; CARBONYLS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL REACTION YIELD; HYDROGENATION; BORIDES; BORON COMPOUNDS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONVERSION; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; REFRACTORY METAL COMPOUNDS; RUTHENIUM COMPOUNDS; TIN COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; YIELDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: A new catalyst system, ruthenium-tin boride, was developed for the selective hydrogenation of fatty acid esters to fatty alcohols at 270 {degrees}C and a pressure of 640 psi of H{sub 2}. The yields of fatty alcohols from various long-chain fatty acid esters varied from 70% to 89%. The catalyst had an atomic ratio of ruthenium to tin of 1:1 and could be unsupported or supported on {gamma}-AI{sub 2}O{sub 3}. The importance of the method of preparation using sodium borohydride as the reductant is demonstrated. A tentative mechanism for the selective activation of the ester carbonyl by the new catalyst system is proposed, based on the surface characterization of the catalysts reported elsewhere.
RELATION: Journal Name: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research; (USA); Journal Volume: 28:7
OTHER_IDENTIFIER: Journal ID: ISSN 0888-5885; CODEN: IECRE; TRN: 90-010849

TITLE: Kinetics of toluene alkylation with methanol on HZSM-8 zeolite catalyst
AUTHORS: Bhat, Y S; Halger, A B; Prasada Rao, T S.R.
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; TOLUENE; ALKYLATION; ZEOLITES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMICAL REACTORS; ENERGY CONVERSION; EQUATIONS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; PACKED BED; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; REGRESSION ANALYSIS; ALKYLATED AROMATICS; AROMATICS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONVERSION; DATA; HYDROCARBONS; INFORMATION; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; KINETICS; MATERIALS; MATHEMATICS; MINERALS; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; STATISTICS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: A detailed kinetic study of the alkylation of toluene with methanol on HZSM-8 zeolite was carried out in a fixed bed reactor. The catalyst showed high activity, selectivity, and stability. An attempt has been made to relate the overall changes taking place during the reaction. The experimental data are analyzed, and a reaction mechanism proposed based on the product pattern. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson model with dual-site mechanism was used to derive the rate equation. The unknown parameters in the rate equations are estimated by a nonlinear regression method. The kinetic model based on the proposed reaction mechanism has predicted the conversion values, which are in close agreement with the experimentally observed values.
RELATION: Journal Name: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research; (USA); Journal Volume: 28:7

TITLE: Gas-liquid phase-transfer catalysis; A new continuous-flow method in organic synthesis
AUTHORS: Tundo, P; Moraglio, G; Trotta, F
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; ANISOLE; SYNTHESIS; ESTERS; ACETONITRILE; ARYL RADICALS; CATALYTIC CONVERTERS; GASES; LIQUIDS; MALONIC ACID; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; PHENOLS; AROMATICS; CARBOXYLIC ACIDS; DICARBOXYLIC ACIDS; EQUIPMENT; ETHERS; FLUIDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; NITRILES; ORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT; RADICALS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: A synthetic method, gas-liquid phase-transfer catalysis (GL-PTC0), is described. GL-PTC is a continuous-flow procedure where gaseous reagents flow through a molten phase-transfer (PT) catalyst supported on a solid; no solvent is used. Reactions may develop through new mechanistic pathways compared with those of classical conditions; moreover, the reactions often occur in very selective ways. Some typical syntheses carried out under GL-PTC conditions are described in detail. They include syntheses of 2-alkylmalonic acid esters from the corresponding malonic acid esters and primary alkyl halides from primary alkyl alcohols and the reactions of dimethyl carbonate, which give N-methylanilines from anilines, anisoles from phenols, and 2-arylpropionitriles from aryl-acetonitriles.
RELATION: Journal Name: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research; (USA); Journal Volume: 28:7

TITLE: Combustion phenomena of alcohols in C. I. engines
AUTHORS: Saeed, M N; Henein, N A
SUBJECT: 33 ADVANCED PROPULSION SYSTEMS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; DIESEL ENGINES; FUEL INJECTION SYSTEMS; DIESEL FUELS; ADDITIVES; ETHANOL FUELS; COMBUSTION KINETICS; ACTIVATION ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; FUEL SUBSTITUTION; FUEL-AIR RATIO; PROPANOLS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; ALCOHOL FUELS; ALCOHOLS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; ENERGY; ENGINES; FUEL SYSTEMS; FUELS; HEAT ENGINES; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INTERNAL COMBUSTION ENGINES; KINETICS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; REACTION KINETICS; SYNTHETIC FUELS; 330800* - Emission Control- Alternative Fuels; 100400 - Synthetic Fuels- Combustion- (1990-); 330102 - Internal Combustion Engines- Diesel; 320301 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Industrial & Agricultural Processes- Energy Sources
DESCRIPTION: A study was conducted on a direct-injection, single-cylinder, research-type diesel engine to determine the effect of adding ethanol or isopropanol to diesel fuel on the ignition delay period. The test parameters were alcohol content, intake-air properties, and fuel-air ratio. It was found that the ignition delay of alcohol-diesel blends is prolonged as the alcohol content is increased. Ehthanol-diesel blends developed longer ignition delays than those developed by isopropanol-diesel blends. The results show that ignition delay of alcohol-diesel blends can be effectively shortened using intake-air preheating and/or supercharging. The high activation energy of alcohols with respect to diesel fuel is believed to be responsible for the long ignition delays associated with the use of alcohols as alternate fuels in compression ignition engines.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power; (USA); Journal Volume: 111:3
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power; (USA)

TITLE: Second vital coefficients of aqueous alcohols at elevated temperatures: A calorimetric study
AUTHORS: Archer, D G
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALCOHOLS; THERMODYNAMIC ACTIVITY; VIRIAL EQUATION; CALORIMETRY; CYCLOHEXANOL; DATA ANALYSIS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; FREE ENERGY; HIGH TEMPERATURE; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MEASURING METHODS; DATA; ENERGY; EQUATIONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 400000 - Chemistry; 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Enthalpies of dilution of cyclohexanol (aq) to 448 K and of myo-inositol (aq) and of cyclohexanol + myo-inositol (aq) to 398 K are reported. These results, along with enthalpies of dilution for 1-butanol (aq) to 448 K and for 2-methyl-2-propanol (aq) to 423 K, were combined with freezing point depression measurements and ambient-temperature enthalpy of dilution and heat capacity measurements in order to provide the excess Gibbs energy for the aqueous solutes from 273 to 523 K. These excess Gibbs energies were then used to provide parameters for an additivity scheme that permits an approximation of the excess Gibbs energy, and thus the solute and solvent activity coefficients, for dilute aqueous alcohols for which high-temperature data do not exist. These excess Gibbs energies were also used to estimate the aqueous-solution second virial coefficients of the alcohols and of cyclohexane (aq), 1-butane (aq), and 2-methylpropane (aq) in the McMillan-Mayer convention. These virial coefficients for the aqueous hydrocarbons, when compared to gas-phase virial coefficients for the hydrocarbons, suggest that the effect of low-temperature (298 K) water is to lessen the pairwise attraction of aqueous hydrocarbon over that found in the gas phase at the same temperature and that this lessening of the pairwise attraction diminishes at higher temperatures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Physical Chemistry; (USA); Journal Volume: 93:13

TITLE: Adsorption of CO and CO sub 2 on clean and cesium-covered Cu(110)
AUTHORS: Rodriguez, J A; Clendening, W D; Campbell, C T
SUBJECT: 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; COPPER; ADSORPTION; CARBON DIOXIDE; CARBON MONOXIDE; CATALYSTS; CESIUM; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MEASURING METHODS; PHOTOELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; ALKALI METALS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; DATA; ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; ELEMENTS; INFORMATION; METALS; NUMERICAL DATA; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SORPTION; SPECTROSCOPY; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 360603* - Materials- Properties; 400000 - Chemistry; 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The interactions of Cs with Cu(110) and the coadsorption of CO and CO{sub 2} with Cs on Cu(110) have been studied with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Auger electron spectroscopy, work function measurements, and thermal desorption mass spectroscopy (TDS). Cesium adsorbs in relatively cationic form at low coverages, depolarizing to relatively neutral, bulklike Cs by one close-packed monolayer ({theta}{sub Cs}* = 1.0). At low {theta}{sub Cs}*, indirect interactions stabilize CO{sub a} by {approximately} 15% relative to its desorption temperature ({approximately} 220 K) from clean Cu(110). For {theta}{sub Cs}* > 0.5, a CO{sub a}-Cs{sub a} complex appears, which decomposes at 400-500 K with simultaneous Cs and CO evolution in TDS. For a fixed CO dose, the concentration of this complex increases with {theta}{sub Cs}*, reaches a maximum at {theta}{sub Cs}* {congruent} 1.1, and decreases rapidly to zero at {theta}{sub Cs}* = 2.0. No CO will adsorb on Cs multilayers at 110 K. No CO{sub 2} adsorption could be detected on clean Cu(11) at 110 K. A cesium/carbonate surface complex is formed already from the lowest Cs coverages and all higher Cs coverages below 180 K via 2CO{sub 2g} + Cs{sub a} {yields} CO{sub a} = Cs {times} CO{sub 3,a} (perhaps through an O{sub a} or oxalate intermediate). Weakly adsorbed CO{sub 2} is also seen when Cs{sub a} is present, desorbing at {approximately} 130 K. The Cs {times} CO{sub 3,a} complex decomposes in a complex TDS spectrum at 500-700 K via Cs {times} CO{sub 3,a} {yields} Cs{sub a} + CO{sub 2,g} + O{sub a}. Cs{sub a} then desorbs at high coverages simultaneous to CO{sub 2} evolution. The implications of these results to Cs promotion of catalytic water-gas shift and methanol synthesis over Cu are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Physical Chemistry; (USA); Journal Volume: 93:13

TITLE: Surface-mediated isomerization and oxidation of allyl alcohol on Cu(110)
AUTHORS: Brainard, R L; Peterson, C G; Madix, R J
SUBJECT: 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALCOHOLS; ISOMERIZATION; OXIDATION; COPPER; DATA ANALYSIS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; HYDROGEN; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MEASURING METHODS; SURFACE PROPERTIES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; DATA; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; METALS; NONMETALS; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 360603* - Materials- Properties; 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Allyl alcohol reacts with clean and oxygen-covered Cu(110) surfaces to produce propanal, acrolein, n-propyl alcohol, and hydrogen under ultrahigh-vacuum conditions. Very small amounts of propylene and water are also formed. This pattern of reactivity contrasts sharply to the selective oxidation to acrolein observed on Ag(110). On the clean Cu(110) surface allyl alcohol undergoes O-H cleavage to form the surface alkoxide CH{sub 2}{double bond}CHCH{sub 2}O{sub (a)} and H{sub (a)}. The results suggest that the olefin in this species undergoes partial hydrogenation to the surface-bound oxametallacycles ({minus}CH{sub 2}CH{sub 2}CH{sub 2}O-){sub (a)} and ({minus}CH-(CH{sub 3})CH{sub 2}O-){sub (a)} and complete hydrogenation to CH{sub 3}CH{sub 2}CH{sub 2}O{sub (a)}. Propanal forms at 320 K via further reaction of these oxametallacycles. Evidence for a {pi}-bonded allyl oxide CH{sub 2}{double bond}CHCH{sub 2}O{sub (a)}, which is more stable than n-propoxide (CH{sub 3}CH{sub 2}CH{sub 2}O{sub (a)}) toward {beta}-hydride elimination, is presented. This allyl oxide decomposes at 370 K to form acrolein. The interaction of the double bond with the surface apparently restricts the interaction of the {beta}-C-H bond with the surface and increases the stability of this species. Propanal, acrolein, and H{sub 2} are formed at 435 K by a process thought to involve the thermal decomposition of ({minus}CH{sub 2}CH{sub 2}CH{sub 2}O-){sub (a)} by a {beta}-hydride elimination pathway. This dehydrogenation pathway exhibits an activation energy 8 kcal/mol greater than for acyclic alkoxides. The conversion of allyl alcohol to propanal and propyl alcohol obviously involves the hydrogenation of the double bond which, by comparison, does not occur for propylene coadsorbed with hydrogen under similar conditions on this surface.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the American Chemical Society; (USA); Journal Volume: 111:13
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of the American Chemical Society; (USA)

TITLE: Ion-molecule chemistry within triply charged ammonia clusters
AUTHORS: Peifer, W R; Coolbaugh, M T; Garvey, J F
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; AMMONIA; IONIZATION; CLUSTER MODEL; DATA ANALYSIS; ELECTRON BEAMS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MEASURING METHODS; BEAMS; DATA; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; LEPTON BEAMS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NUCLEAR MODELS; NUMERICAL DATA; PARTICLE BEAMS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The authors present in this communication the first observation of intramolecular ion-molecule reactions within triply charged clusters produced via electron impact ionization of neat beams of ammonia molecules. The fragmentation pattern strongly suggests that reactions occurring within these triply charged clusters are similar to those previously observed for singly and doubly charged ammonia clusters. This behavior implies that these cluster ions consist of three singly charged ammonia cations which react separately within the bulk neutral cluster. That is, either one, two, three, or none of the ammonia cations may react with the solvating neutrals within the cluster. We also report for singly charged ammonia clusters the observation that extensive fragmentation can occur within the cluster producing ions with the empirical formulas of (NH{sub 3}){sub n-1}N{sup +} and (NH{sub 3}){sub n-1}NH{sup +}.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Physical Chemistry; (USA); Journal Volume: 93:12

TITLE: Ab initio studies of the C sub 3 H sub 4 surface. 3. Thermal isomerization
AUTHORS: Yoshimine, M; Pacansky, J; Honjou, N
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CYCLOALKANES; ISOMERIC TRANSITIONS; ALLENE; CALCULATION METHODS; DATA ANALYSIS; HYDROCARBONS; ISOMERIZATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; ALKANES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; DIENES; ENERGY-LEVEL TRANSITIONS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; POLYENES; 400000* - Chemistry; 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: SCF, MCSCF, and CI calculations have been carried out to study thermal interconversions occurring on the singlet C{sub 3}H{sub 4} surface. Transition states and reaction paths between the pairs of possible isomers, methylacetylene, allene, cyclopropene, propenylidene, vinylmethylene, and cyclopropylidene were determined. In addition, the zero-point energies were calculated, and the activation energies for pertinent reactions were evaluated. The thermal rearrangement of allene to methylacetylene was found to proceed in four steps via vinylmethylene, cyclopropene, and propenylidene with the activation energy of 65.8 kcal/mol, which is in good agreement with the observed values of 60.5 and 63.8 kcal/mol. The same reaction paths can also apply to pyrolysis of cyclopropene, in which it undergoes conversion to methylacetylene via propenylidene more easily than to allene via vinylmethylene; the calculated activation energies are 38.1 and 43.4 kcal/mol, respectively. These are again in excellent agreement with the observed values of 37.5 and 43.3 kcal/mol. The activation energies for the allene to cyclopropylidene and the reverse conversions were calculated to be 72.2 and 10.2 kcal/mol. This indicates that cyclopropylidene may not be involved in the interconversion of allene, cyclopropene, and methylacetylene. One of the significant findings in this study is the reaction path for the cyclopropene to methylacetylene conversion via propenylidene, which is less energy demanding than that via vinylmethylene. This made the calculated mechanisms in accord with the experimental data. Furthermore, we will present and discuss reaction mechanisms for pyrolysis of singly and doubly substituted cyclopropene in which this particular reaction path is expected to play a dominant role.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the American Chemical Society; (USA); Journal Volume: 111:12
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of the American Chemical Society; (USA)

TITLE: NO/sub x/ formation from the combustion of monodisperse n-heptane sprays doped with fuel-nitrogen additives
AUTHORS: Sarv, H; Cernansky, N P
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; FLAMES; LAMINAR FLOW; HEPTANE; COMBUSTION KINETICS; NITROGEN OXIDES; EMISSION; SYNTHETIC FUELS; ADDITIVES; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CALCULATION METHODS; COMBUSTION PRODUCTS; COMPUTER CODES; DROPLETS; GAS FUELS; OXIDATION; OXYGEN; PYRIDINE; PYRROLES; SIZE; STOICHIOMETRY; ALKANES; AZINES; AZOLES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; FLUID FLOW; FUELS; HETEROCYCLIC COMPOUNDS; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PARTICLES; PYRIDINES; REACTION KINETICS; 400800* - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 090110 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A series of experiments with simulated synthetic fuels were conducted in order to investigate the effect of droplet size on the conversion of fuel-nitrogen to NO/sub x/. Pyridine and pyrrole were added to n-heptane as nitrogen-containing additives and burned as monodisperse fuel droplets under various operating conditions in a spray combustion facility. The experimental results indicate that under stoichiometric and fuel-rich conditions, reducing the droplet size increases the efficiency of fuel-N conversion to NO/sub x/. This observation is associated with improved oxidation of the pyrolysis fragments of the additive by better oxygen penetration through the droplet flame ozone. The dominant reactions by which fuel-N is transformed to NO/sub x/ were also considered analytically by a premixed laminar flame code. The calculations are compared to the small droplet size results.
RESEARCH_ORG: Drexel Univ., Philadelphia, PA (USA). Dept. of Mechanical Engineering

TITLE: The influence of catalytic activity on the ignition of boundary layer flows
AUTHORS: Pfefferle, L D; Griffin, T A; Winter, M; Crosley, D R; Dyer, M J
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ETHANE; COMBUSTION KINETICS; GAS FUELS; IGNITION; PLATINUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; AIR; BOUNDARY LAYERS; FUEL-AIR RATIO; HYDROXYL RADICALS; QUARTZ; VERY HIGH TEMPERATURE; ALKANES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; FUELS; GASES; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; LAYERS; METALS; MINERALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDE MINERALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; RADICALS; REACTION KINETICS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 400800* - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 090110 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The effect of catalytic activity on gas phase ignition in an ethane-air boundary layer was investigated by measuring OH concentration profiles over heated platinum and quartz surfaces. Platinum's catalytic influence on gas phase ignition was found to depend strongly on the fuel-air ratio. Experiments were performed in a flat plate boundary layer configuration at 1 atm pressure and surface temperatures of 1200-1650 K. The hydroxyl measurements were made by planar and pointwise laser-induced fluorescence. Inhibition of ethane-air ignition was observed at equivalence ratios greater than 0.35, with enhancement seen below this value. Depletion of fuel near the catalytic surface by mass transfer-limited oxidation reactions can account for the catalyst's inhibition effect. Catalytic promotion of gas phase ignition was evidenced by significantly higher OH concentration levels over platinum plates (as compared to quartz) for the leanest equivalence ratio tested. The results indicate that catalytic surface-induced production of active intermediates can promote gas phase ignition and offset the effect of reactant depletion near the surface.
RESEARCH_ORG: Yale Univ., New Haven, CT (USA). Dept. of Chemical Engineering; SRI International, Menlo Park, CA (USA). Molecular Physics Lab.
RELATION: Journal Name: Combust. Flame; (United States); Journal Volume: 76:3

TITLE: Electrochemical and surface studies of carbon dioxide reduction to methane and ethylene at copper electrodes in aqueous solutions
AUTHORS: DeWulf, D W; Jin, T; Bard, A J
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 30 DIRECT ENERGY CONVERSION; CARBON DIOXIDE; REDUCTION; ETHYLENE; SYNTHESIS; METHANE; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; COPPER; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; ELECTRODES; FORMALDEHYDE; GRAPHITE; METHANOL; ALCOHOLS; ALDEHYDES; ALKANES; ALKENES; CARBON; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHEMISTRY; DISPERSIONS; ELEMENTAL MINERALS; ELEMENTS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; METALS; MINERALS; MIXTURES; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; SOLUTIONS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400400 - Electrochemistry; 300504 - Fuel Cells- Applications; 300505 - Fuel Cells- Electrochemistry, Mass Transfer & Thermodynamics
DESCRIPTION: The authors describe the electrochemical reduction of CO/sub 2/ to CH/sub 4/ and C/sub 2/H/sub 4/ in aqueous alkaline solutions at Cu electrodes. The current at the Cu electrodes and the rate of hydrocarbon formation were monitored as a function of time over a temperature range from 0 to 48%C. Solutions of formate, formaldehyde, and methanol, possible intermediates in the reduction process, were also electrolyzed. Surface analyses (XPS and AES) were also performed on the Cu electrodes following electrolysis to identify surface intermediates. In addition to hydrocarbon formation, a poisoning process occurred, causing a deposit of a black film on the surface of the Cu cathode. XPS and AES studies indicated that the black film was graphitic carbon, probably the result of a side reaction, the reduction of CO/sub 2/ through formate to graphite. A tentative reaction mechanism for CO/sub 2/ reduction, based upon the data here and those of previous investigators, involving the reaction path CO/sub 2/{yields}CO{yields} surface-bound formyl (Cu-HCO){yields} surface-bound methylene (Cu-CH/sub 2/){yields} hydrocarbon products, is proposed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the Electrochemical Society; (USA); Journal Volume: 136:6

TITLE: Fischer-Tropsch reaction mechanisms and a posteriori probabilistic treatment of product distribution
AUTHORS: Basini, L
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; FISCHER-TROPSCH SYNTHESIS; CHEMICAL REACTION YIELD; ALCOHOLS; ALKANES; ALKENES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; YIELDS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Fischer-Tropsch synthesis can be considered a structure-sensitive polymerization process over solid surfaces and its product distributions can be described by adopting a statistical approach. This is done here assuming that common intermediates originate three classes of compounds: alcohols, alkanes, and alkenes. A break zone instead of a sharp break in Anderson-Shultz-Flory plots in considered and is represented as the result of competition between two different reaction mechanisms. Growth and termination probabilities for the intermediates are defined and related to the experimental molar fractions of the products.
RELATION: Journal Name: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research; (USA); Journal Volume: 28:6

TITLE: Promotion of iron-group catalysts by a calcium salt in hydrogasification of coal chars
AUTHORS: Haga, T; Nishiyama, Y
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CATALYSTS; PERFORMANCE; CHARS; ENERGY CONVERSION; COAL GASIFICATION; CALCIUM; CATALYTIC CONVERTERS; IRON; ISOTHERMAL PROCESSES; NICKEL; ALKALINE EARTH METALS; CONVERSION; ELEMENTS; EQUIPMENT; GASIFICATION; METALS; POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT; PYROLYSIS PRODUCTS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 010404* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Gasification; 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The effects of Fe + Ca and Ni + Ca dual catalysts on hydrogasification of coal char were studied between 1 and 30 atm and between 750 and 900{degrees}C. Promotions of Fe- and Ni-catalyzed reactions by added Ca were observed in the reactions of all coal chars used. The degree of promotion increased with increases in the amount of added Ca, temperature, and pressure. The initial surface area of coal char was found to greatly affect the activities of dual catalysts, probably due to different dispersions of catalyst particles at the stage of impregnation. The rate of Ni-catalyzed gasification increased with time during the isothermal mode, and the added Ca accelerated the rate increase. The results are discussed in comparison with the authors previous study using model carbons.
RELATION: Journal Name: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research; (USA); Journal Volume: 28:6

TITLE: Effects of periodic variations of reactant influxes on the combustion of methane in power production
AUTHORS: Hjelmfelt, A; Ross, J
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; HEAT ENGINES; EFFICIENCY; METHANE; COMBUSTION; CARNOT CYCLE; COMBUSTION PRODUCTS; FUEL CONSUMPTION; HEAT LOSSES; OXYGEN; POWER GENERATION; ALKANES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; ENERGY LOSSES; ENGINES; HYDROCARBONS; LOSSES; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDATION; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; THERMODYNAMIC CYCLES; 400800* - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 090100 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Periodic variations are applied to the influxes of oxygen and methane entering a reaction vessel in which takes place a combustion reaction. We measure the temperature and chemical responses of the system as we change the forcing amplitudes, periods, and equivalence ratios. Using a simple model of a Carnot engine we calculate efficiency changes in an externally varied flux mode (VFM) of operation relative to the constant flux mode (CFM) of operation. We find increases and decreases in the average temperature, efficiency, and unburnt fuel concentrations in the VFM relative to the CFM. For certain constraints we find regions where the average temperature in the VFM is less than that of the CFM and there is an efficiency increase. We find other regions where the entire temperature response in the VFM is greater than that of the CFM and this also can lead to an efficiency increase which is due to changes in extent of combustion and heat losses. The effects of forcing amplitudes, periods, and equivalence ratios on the system are explored, and predictions of numerical calculations agree with much of the data. A simple model of the reaction limited by one reagent, and the absorption of heat by the products and the other reagent predicts for variations of one reagent the number of maxima in the response, and phase relations of external variations and the response.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, California 94305
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Chem. Phys.; (United States); Journal Volume: 90:10

TITLE: Study targets refiners' surplus normal butane
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; BUTANE; COMBUSTION PROPERTIES; USA; PETROLEUM REFINERIES; BY-PRODUCTS; EPRI; GAS TURBINES; GASOLINE; PROCESSING; ALKANES; FUELS; HYDROCARBONS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; LIQUID FUELS; MACHINERY; NORTH AMERICA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 020500* - Petroleum- Products & By-Products; 020400 - Petroleum- Processing; 090110 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989); 025000 - Petroleum- Combustion
DESCRIPTION: Effects of changing U.S. gasoline-volatility requirements continue to ripple through the processing industry. One significant effect is that gasoline-production economics and environmental regulations are expected to leave many U.S. refiners awash in normal butane during summer months. To explore one possible outlet for this butane, the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) has announced a feasibility study of converting utility peaking gas-turbine generators from kerosine or No. 2 fuel oil to refinery-produced normal butane. The EPRI study centers on converting 900 mw of Public Service Electric and Gas Co. (PSE and G), N.J., combustion turbines adjacent to Exxon Co.'s Bayway, N.J., refinery. Members of the study group are PSE and G, Exxon Co. U.S.A., EPRI and United Technologies (Turbo Power and Machinery).
RELATION: Journal Name: Oil Gas J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 87:19

TITLE: Heat transfer in fixed catalytic-bed chemical reactors operating under unsteady-state conditions
AUTHORS: Kantorovich, I I; Sevruk, V M
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 42 ENGINEERING; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; CHEMICAL REACTORS; HEAT TRANSFER; METHANOL; SYNTHESIS; CATALYTIC CRACKING; TIME DEPENDENCE; ALCOHOLS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CRACKING; DECOMPOSITION; ENERGY TRANSFER; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PYROLYSIS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 420400 - Engineering- Heat Transfer & Fluid Flow; 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: A technique is developed for solving the inverse unsteady-state problem of heat transfer in heterogeneous catalytic reactors allowing one to find heat transfer coefficients, errors of their determination and correlations between the coefficients on the basis of experimental information about the time-dependence of the temperature at separate points in the reactor. The values of the heat transfer coefficients in a tubular heterogeneous reactor with the methanol-synthesis catalyst are assessed experimentally.
RELATION: Journal Name: Heat Transfer - Soviet Research; (USA); Journal Volume: 21:3

TITLE: The multi-lobed tank
AUTHORS: Stannard, Jr, J H
SUBJECT: 42 ENGINEERING; 03 NATURAL GAS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ETHANE; MARITIME TRANSPORT; METHANE; TANKS; DESIGN; BUTANE; CYLINDRICAL CONFIGURATION; LIQUEFIED GASES; LIQUEFIED NATURAL GAS; PROPANE; TUBES; ALKANES; CONFIGURATION; CONTAINERS; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; HYDROCARBONS; NATURAL GAS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; TRANSPORT; 420205* - Engineering- Transport & Storage Facilities- (1980-); 035000 - Natural Gas- Storage- (1989-); 090110 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989); 032000 - Natural Gas- Transport, Handling, & Storage
DESCRIPTION: During the 1970s and early '80s, there was a dramatic increase in the international and marine movement of gaseous fuels in the liquid state. The commodities ranged from methane as liquefied natural gas (LNG) to propane and butanes as both refrigerated and non-refrigerated products. Liquefaction by refrigeration can be an expensive process. Therefore, from a process standpoint, there was a significant incentive to conceive a viable form of semi-refrigerated marine transport - particularly for the higher gases such as methane and ethane. The use of multiple cylindrical vessels can improve the space utilization and reduce the individual vessel wall thicknesses to manageable levels. However the complexity of the necessary piping required to interconnect the vessels negates many of the advantages of the multiple vessel concept. At the same time, the installation of large-volume transfer pumps in a multiple tank array could present many formidable problems.
RESEARCH_ORG: National Fire Protection Assoc's Liquefied Natural Gas Committee (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: Butane-Propane News; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:5

TITLE: Changes in demethanizer reboiler solve efficiency problems
AUTHORS: Pattinson, S
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 02 PETROLEUM; ETHANE; CHEMICAL PLANTS; CANADA; CHEMICAL REACTION YIELD; DESIGN; EFFICIENCY; GASES; HEAT EXTRACTION; LIQUIDS; METHANE; MIXTURES; SPECIFICATIONS; THERMOSYPHONS; ALKANES; DISPERSIONS; FLUIDS; HYDROCARBONS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; NORTH AMERICA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; YIELDS; 090120* - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Preparation- (1976-1989); 020500 - Petroleum- Products & By-Products
DESCRIPTION: Modifications to three vertical shell-and-tube thermosyphon reboilers at Amoco Canada's ethane-extraction plant in Edmonton have brought plant performance up to design levels and allowed it to meet product specifications. The reboilers, which are used in a demethanizer-reboiler service, were originally installed in 1986 to replace a brazed aluminum plate-fin exchanger that had failed. When the new reboilers were put in service, it was found that they worked at less than 30% of design efficiency. Very little heat was being added to the bottom of the tower and to the bottom product which was a C/sub 2/ + mixture containing high amounts of methane. This resulted in the ethane product being off specification quality. These exchangers act as reboilers for the demethanizer tower by vaporizing the methane out of a liquid C/sub 2/ + mixture. The liquid is taken from a seal pan situated below the bottom tray of the tower and enters the bottom of each reboiler. The bubble point liquid is partially vaporized through heat exchange with inlet gas. The two-phase mixture separates in the bottom of the tower with vapor phase rising and supplying heat to the bottom trays and the liquid phase accumulating in the bottom of the tower prior to further fractionation in the de-ethanizer.
RESEARCH_ORG: Amoco Canada Petroleum Co. Ltd., Edmonton (CA)
RELATION: Journal Name: Oil Gas J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 87:18

TITLE: Catalyst evaluation and kinetic study for ethylene production
AUTHORS: Lemonidou, A A; Vasalos, I A; Hirschberg, E J; Bertolacini, R J
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; CATALYSTS; EVALUATION; ETHYLENE; CATALYTIC CRACKING; HEXANE; PYROLYSIS; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CALCIUM OXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; MAGNESIUM OXIDES; MANGANESE OXIDES; PACKED BED; POTASSIUM OXIDES; STRONTIUM OXIDES; THERMAL CRACKING; TITANIUM OXIDES; ZIRCONIUM OXIDES; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKANES; ALKENES; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CRACKING; DECOMPOSITION; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; MANGANESE COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; STRONTIUM COMPOUNDS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TITANIUM COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; ZIRCONIUM COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: The need to produce olefins via catalytic cracking has attracted increased attention in recent years. In this paper results are presented with catalysts composed of two or more of the following metal oxides: CaO, Al/sub 2/O/sub 3/, SrO, MgO, TiO/sub 2/, MnO/sub 2/, ZrO/sub 2/, and K/sub 2/O. A fixed bed reactor system was used to evaluate the catalysts with n-hexane as feedstock. The best results were obtained with calcium aluminate based catalysts. The higher olefins yields obtained with the new catalysts compared with {alpha}-Al/sub 2/O/sub 3/ are explained by the higher conversion obtained at the same process conditions. The kinetics of the pyrolysis of n-hexane was also studied. The overall decomposition reaction is first order both for thermal cracking and for cracking in the presence of catalyst 12CaO.7Al/sub 2/O/sub 3/.
RELATION: Journal Name: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research; (USA); Journal Volume: 28:5

TITLE: Optimal design and synthesis of homogeneous azeotropic distillation sequences
AUTHORS: Knight, J R; Doherty, M F
SUBJECT: 09 BIOMASS FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ETHANOL; SEPARATION PROCESSES; WATER; AZEOTROPE; CHEMICAL REACTORS; DESIGN; DISTILLATION EQUIPMENT; OPTIMIZATION; POLYETHYLENE GLYCOLS; ALCOHOLS; EQUIPMENT; GLYCOLS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC POLYMERS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POLYMERS; 090900* - Biomass Fuels- Processing- (1990-); 400105 - Separation Procedures; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: A systematic procedure for optimizing homogeneous azeotropic separation sequences has been developed. The procedure uses an explicit design technique which eliminates the need for recycle convergence schemes. The separation of ethanol from water using ethylene glycol as the entrainer is used to illustrate the optimization procedure. Comparisons are made with competing designs from the literature, illustrating the need to properly optimize flow sheets before drawing conclusions on the relative merits of various separation technologies.
RELATION: Journal Name: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research; (USA); Journal Volume: 28:5

TITLE: The peak boiling heat flux in saturated ethanol-water mixtures
AUTHORS: Reddy, R P; Lienhard, J H
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 42 ENGINEERING; ETHANOL; SUBCOOLED BOILING; BOILING; BURNOUT; DATA; HEAT FLUX; MIXTURES; WATER; ALCOHOLS; DISPERSIONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 420400 - Engineering- Heat Transfer & Fluid Flow
DESCRIPTION: The present work provides original measurements of the burnout heat flux in saturated ethanol-water mixtures, over the full range of concentrations. These data were obtained at atmospheric pressure on horizontal cylinders, ranging from 0.51 to 2.16 mm in diameter. They reveal significant improvements of the peak heat flux for mixtures, over that which would be expected from pure fluids with the properties of the mixture. This improvement is most pronounced at low ethanol mass fractions. McEligot has suggested that the improved heat flux results from a subcooling created by selective distillation at the liquid-vapor interface. Combining this idea with a recent correlation of subcooled burnout, the authors estimate the extent of the effective subcooling qualitatively and discuss the use of this estimate to correlate burnout in binary mixtures. Two dimensionless groups are proposed to characterize this effective subcooling, both based on appropriate characterizations of the phase equilibrium diagram.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Heat Transfer (Transactions of the ASME (American Society of Mechanical Engineers), Series C); (United States); Journal Volume: 111:2
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Heat Transfer (Transactions of the ASME (American Society of Mechanical Engineers), Series C); (United States)

TITLE: A controlled atmosphere in situ X-ray diffraction study of the activation and performance of ammonia synthesis catalysts derived from CeRu sub 2 , CeCo sub 2 , and CeFe sub 2
AUTHORS: Walker, A P; Rayment, T; Lambert, R M
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; AMMONIA; SYNTHESIS; CERIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; BIMETALS; CARBON MONOXIDE; CATALYSTS; CERIUM HYDRIDES; CERIUM OXIDES; CHEMICAL ACTIVATION; COBALT; HYDROGEN; IRON; NITROGEN; RUTHENIUM; TRANSITION ELEMENT ALLOYS; X-RAY DIFFRACTION; ALLOYS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CERIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; COHERENT SCATTERING; DIFFRACTION; ELEMENTS; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; METALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NONMETALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; RARE EARTH COMPOUNDS; RARE EARTHS; SCATTERING; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: High active ammonia synthesis catalysts derived from cerium intermetallic alloy precursors CeRu{sub 2}, CeCo{sub 2}, and CeFe{sub 2} have been studied by in situ powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) with concurrent analysis of catalytic activity. The reaction was investigated at pressures of up to 50 bar and at temperatures up to 550{degree}C. Precursor activation was carried out in pure hydrogen, N{sub 2}/H{sub 2}, and CO/H{sub 2} under various regimes of temperature and pressure. It is found that the formation of active catalysts depends upon the presence of cerium hydride and transition metal crystallites in the ultimate material, although there is no correlation between XRD-derived metal areas and chemical rates. The corresponding transition metal/cerium dioxide catalysts have a much lower activity for ammonia synthesis. The special activity of the hydride-based catalysts may arise from an intimate interaction between the support phase and the ultradispersed transition metal particles.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 117:1

TITLE: Silicon-rich H-ZSM-5 catalyzed conversion of aqueous ethanol to ethylene
AUTHORS: Moser, W R; Thompson, R W; Chiang, C C; Tong, H
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ETHANOL; CATALYTIC REFORMING; ETHYLENE; SYNTHESIS; ZEOLITES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; ALUMINIUM; CATALYSIS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; ENRICHMENT; QUANTITY RATIO; SILICON; ALCOHOLS; ALKENES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; KINETICS; MATERIALS; METALS; MINERALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; REFORMER PROCESSES; SEMIMETALS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: A study of the H-ZSM-5 catalysis of the conversion of aqueous ethanol solutions to ethylene was carried out using zeolites having Si/Al atom ratios of 35 to 15,000. Rates of ethanol conversion dropped sharply as expected until a Si/Al ratio of about 500; at higher ratios the activity was maintained at a nearly constant level. All of the synthesized zeolites afforded 100% conversion of 20% aqueous ethanol when examined at 400{degree}C and space velocities (WHSV) of 3.4 hr{sup {minus}1} (based on the ethanol component). The ethylene selectivities steadily increased with the Si/Al ratio and reached a maximum of 99.6% using the silicon-rich H-ZSM-5 zeolites. The unusually high catalytic activity observed for the silicon-rich materials was attributed to especially reactive clusters of hydrogen-bonded silanols and was shown to be independent of the aluminum concentration.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 117:1

TITLE: Analysis of the structure and mechanisms of extinction of a counterflow methanol-air diffusion flame
AUTHORS: Seshadri, K; Trevino, C; Smooke, M D
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; FLAMES; CALCULATION METHODS; METHANOL; AIR; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; COMBUSTION PROPERTIES; DIFFUSION; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; PYROLYSIS; ALCOHOLS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; DECOMPOSITION; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; 400800* - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 090210 - Alcohol Fuels- Properties- (1976-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Numerical calculations were performed to determine the structure and to clarify the extinction mechanisms of diffusion flames stabilized between counterflowing streams of methanol and air. The calculations were performed at a value of the thermodynamic pressure equal to 1 atmosphere, with different values for the rate of strain and with two different chemical kinetic mechanisms, mechanism a and mechanism b. Mechanism a and mechanism b have the same set of elementary reactions, but the rate constants for these elementary reactions were obtained from two different references. If mechanism a is used, the authors conclude that at low rates of strain the concentration of CH/sub 2/OH and HCO are in steady state and, if partial equilibrium is assumed for certain reactions, there exist algebraic relations among the concentrations of the radicals OH, H, and O. As the rate of strain is increased, HCO is no longer in steady state and no solution was obtained for a strain rate greater than 521 s/sup -1/. However, if mechanism b is used, the concentration of HCO alone is in steady state, and there also exist algebraic relations among the concentrations of the radicals OH, H, and O. As the rate of strain is increased, no solution was obtained for a strain rate greater than 168 s/sup -1/, and the authors speculate that extinction of the flame is due to a large value of the activation energy for a reaction controlling the pyrolysis of CH/sub 2/OH to CH/sub 2/O.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Applied Mechanics and Engineering Sciences/Chemical Engineering, Univ. of California, San Diego, La Jolla, CA (US); Division de Ing. Mecanica y Electrica, Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico (MX); Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Yale Univ., New Haven, CT (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: Combust. Flame; (United States); Journal Volume: 76:2

TITLE: Steady-state isotopic transient-kinetic analysis of iron-catalyzed ammonia synthesis
AUTHORS: Nwalor, J U; Goodwin, Jr, J G; Biloen, P
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; AMMONIA; SYNTHESIS; IRON; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CATALYSIS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMISORPTION; HIGH TEMPERATURE; HYDROGEN; LOW PRESSURE; NITROGEN; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; STEADY-STATE CONDITIONS; SURFACE PROPERTIES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; METALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NONMETALS; REACTION KINETICS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SORPTION; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Steady-state isotopic transient-kinetic analysis of ammonia synthesis catalysis has been conducted over a commercial Fe catalyst (Haldor Topsoe KMIR) permitting, for the first time, direct determinations of coverages in reactive intermediates of the working catalyst surface and assessments of the reaction mechanism and surface heterogeneity at steady-state reaction conditions. The reaction was studied in the temperature range 623-773 K, at a total pressure of 204 or 513 kPa, and for a H{sub 2}/N{sub 2} ratio of 3. Dinitrogen chemisorption in the absence of H{sub 2} was also measured at 773 K by the transient kinetic technique. The results suggest that N is the most abundant reactive intermediate. It may be inferred, as expected, that a kinetically significant reaction step exists on the reaction path followed by nitrogen. Hydrogen appears to enhance this step which seems to involve dinitrogen dissociation. The working surface was observed to be heterogeneous with respect to the synthesis reaction. The steady-state isotopic transient curves, at 204 kPa and temperatures of 623 and 673 K, indicate one main pool of nitrogen-containing surface intermediates. At 723 and 773 K, a second less reactive pool of intermediates developed due, perhaps, to the activation of previously dormant or saturated sites or to possible contributions from bulk-phase nitrogen species. Both pools of N-intermediates were kinetically nonuniform. This investigation provides significant new insight into ammonia synthesis catalysis.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 117:1

TITLE: Mechanism of the lanthanum bromide assisted electrochemical aldolization of. alpha. -bromo ketones
AUTHORS: Fry, A J; Susla, M
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; BENZALDEHYDE; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; KETONES; REDUCTION; LANTHANUM BROMIDES; ORGANIC BROMINE COMPOUNDS; PROPANOLS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; DEHYDROCYCLIZATION; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; ELECTROLYSIS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; ISOMERS; STEREOCHEMISTRY; VOLTAMETRY; ALCOHOLS; ALDEHYDES; BROMIDES; BROMINE COMPOUNDS; CHEMISTRY; DATA; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; LANTHANUM COMPOUNDS; LYSIS; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; RARE EARTH COMPOUNDS; SYNTHESIS; 400500* - Photochemistry; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Linear sweep voltammetry, preparative electrolyses under a variety of experimental conditions, and trapping experiments have been used to explore the mechanism of the formation of the aldol 2-benzoyl-1-phenylpropanol by electrochemical reduction of {alpha}-bromopropiophenone in the presence of benzaldehyde and lanthanum bromide. The aldol condensation occurs by reaction of the free (lithio) enolate with a lanthanum bromide-benzaldehyde-tetrahydrofuran complex. Electrochemical reduction of the bromo ketone forms the Z enolate highly stereospecifically. The erythro aldol is formed stereoselectively initially, but the condensation is reversible, and the equilibrium mixture of aldols, containing mostly the threo isomer, is isolated from the electrolysis.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the American Chemical Society; (USA); Journal Volume: 111:9

TITLE: Borohydride B-H activation and dimerization by a doubly bonded, early-transition-metal organodimetallic complex. Ditantalladiborane syntheses as models for dehydrodimerization of methane to ethene
AUTHORS: Ting, Ching; Messerle, L
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; BORANES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ETHANE; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; METHANE; ORGANOMETALLIC COMPOUNDS; TANTALUM COMPOUNDS; DIMERIZATION; DOUBLE BONDS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; LIGANDS; ALKANES; BORON COMPOUNDS; CHEMICAL BONDS; DATA; HYDROCARBONS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; POLYMERIZATION; REFRACTORY METAL COMPOUNDS; SYNTHESIS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: There is considerable interest in hydrocarbon C-H activation from the theoretical and organometallic perspectives, particularly in discovering activation/functionalization pathways and bonding models for catalyst surface intermediates. The isoelectronic relationships between hydrocarbons and boranes have led to studies of metallaboranes as hydrocarbon-metal analogues, for example, distorted BH{sub 4}{sup {minus}} complexes are models for CH{sub 4} coordination in the transition state for C-H activation. Their discovery of vinylic C-H activation by the Ta{double bond}Ta complexes (C{sub 5}Me{sub 4}R){sub 2}Ta{sub 2}({mu}-X){sub 4} led them to examine reactivity toward B-H bonds. The reactions of BH{sub 4}{sup {minus}} with multiply bonded M-M compounds are unstudied, particularly for the early transition metals, hydroboration of M-C multiple bonds, but not M-M multiple bonds, has been reported. They wish to report new complexes with hexahydridodiborate (diborane(2-), unknown as a free species) ligands derived from BH{sub 4}{sup {minus}} B-H activation and dehydrodimerization by a M{double bond}M group.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the American Chemical Society; (USA); Journal Volume: 111:9
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of the American Chemical Society; (USA)

SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; BY-PRODUCTS; MIXTURES; CHEMICAL REACTORS; DESIGN; PETROCHEMICALS; MANUFACTURING; ACETIC ACID; CARBON MONOXIDE; COST; FOAMS; FORMIC ACID; HYDROGEN; METHANOL; PLASTICS; ALCOHOLS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CARBOXYLIC ACIDS; CHALCOGENIDES; COLLOIDS; DISPERSIONS; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; MATERIALS; MONOCARBOXYLIC ACIDS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; SYNTHETIC MATERIALS; 020500* - Petroleum- Products & By-Products; 020700 - Petroleum- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 090100 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Phosgene, polycarbonates, formic acid, acetic acid, methanol, oxo-alcohols and intermediates for polyurethane foam plastics are some of the chemicals made from CO or a mixture of H/sub 2/ + CO. As much as 80% of the manufacturing cost of some chemicals is determined by the manufacturing cost of CO or H/sub 2/ + CO. Thus, it is important to know the factors that influence the cost of these gases and to make early design decisions that have the most influence on their manufacturing costs. This paper reviews how relative costs for H/sub 2//CO ratios are determined.

TITLE: Compressibility factors, densities, and residual thermodynamic properties for methane-water mixtures
AUTHORS: Joffrion, L L; Eubank, P T
SUBJECT: 09 BIOMASS FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 03 NATURAL GAS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; METHANE; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; WATER VAPOR; ADSORPTION; COMPRESSIBILITY; DATA ANALYSIS; DENSITY; ENTHALPY; MEASURING METHODS; MIXTURES; PHASE DIAGRAMS; ALKANES; DIAGRAMS; DISPERSIONS; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROCARBONS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SORPTION; VAPORS; 091000* - Biomass Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 033000 - Natural Gas- Properties & Composition; 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Smoothed compressibility factors and residual thermodynamic properties for mixtures of 50, 25, and 10 mol% water vapor in methane are presented along with experimental densities. Pressure-enthalpy diagrams for the three mixtures are also provided. The measured densities cover a temperature range of 498.15-398.15{Kappa} and a pressure range of 72 kPa to 12 MPa. These densities were measured by use of a Burnett-isochoric (B-I) apparatus and are accurate to +-0.08%. The adsorption phenomenon normally present in vapor measurements of polar components was taken into account during the B-I data analysis. Thus the densities, and therefore the residual properties, presented here are free of the errors caused by the adsorption process.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Chemical and Engineering Data; (USA); Journal Volume: 34:2

TITLE: Liquid-liquid extraction of ethanol from aqueous solutions with amyl acetate, benzyl alcohol, and methyl isobutyl ketone at 298. 15. Kappa
AUTHORS: Solimo, H N; Martinez, H E; Riggio, R
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 09 BIOMASS FUELS; ACETATES; SOLVENT PROPERTIES; BENZYL ALCOHOL; ETHANOL; SOLVENT EXTRACTION; METHYL ISOBUTYL KETONE; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; LIQUIDS; MIXTURES; PHASE DIAGRAMS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SOLUBILITY; ALCOHOLS; AROMATICS; CARBOXYLIC ACID SALTS; DATA; DIAGRAMS; DISPERSIONS; EXTRACTION; FLUIDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; KETONES; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; SOLUTIONS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 090900 - Biomass Fuels- Processing- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Experimental mutual solubility and tie-line data were determined for three ternary liquid-liquid systems containing water, ethanol, and amyl acetate, benzyl alcohol, and methyl isobutyl ketone at 298.15{Kappa} in order to obtain their complete phase diagrams and to determine which is the most suitable solvent for extraction of ethanol from aqueous solutions. Tie lines were determined correlating the density of the binodal curve as a function of composition and the plait points using the Othmer and Tobias method. The experimental data were also correlated with the UNIFAC group contribution method. A qualitative agreement was obtained. Experimental results show that amyl acetate is a better solvent than methyl isobutyl ketone and benzyl alcohol.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Chemical and Engineering Data; (USA); Journal Volume: 34:2

TITLE: Synthesis of highly calorific gaseous fuel from syngas on cobalt-manganese-ruthenium composite catalysts
AUTHORS: Inui, T; Sakamoto, A; Takeguchi, T; Ishigaki, Y
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; GAS FUELS; SYNTHESIS; SYNTHESIS GAS; CONVERSION; ALKANES; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CHEMICAL REACTORS; COBALT; FLUIDIZED-BED COMBUSTION; MANGANESE; METHANE; NICKEL; PERFORMANCE; PILOT PLANTS; RUTHENIUM; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COMBUSTION; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; FUELS; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; GASES; HYDROCARBONS; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDATION; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 090121* - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Chemical Synthesis- (1976-1989); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-)
DESCRIPTION: To synthesize a highly calorific gaseous fuel from syngas, a composite catalyst system of Co-Mn-Ru supported on alumina calcined at 1060/sup 0/C was investigated by a continuous flow reactor under a pressure of 10 kg/cm/sup 2/. In contrast to the Ni-based composite catalyst, the Co-Mn/sub 2/O/sub 3/-Ru catalyst converts syngas to a methane-rich gas containing significant concentrations of C/sub 2/-C/sub 4/ paraffins. Consequently, the Co-based catalyst yielded a highly calorific gaseous fuel directly from a coke oven gas. The pilot plant test was conducted by using a fluidized bed and confirmed satisfactory performance for more than 3000 h.

TITLE: Synergistic hypergolic ignition of blends of dienes and dienophiles with red fuming nitric acid as oxidizer
AUTHORS: Panda, S P; Kulkarni, S G; Prabhakaran, C
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; LIQUID FUELS; COMBUSTION; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; DIENES; FURFURAL; MIXTURES; NITRIC ACID; THERMAL CRACKING; ALDEHYDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CRACKING; DECOMPOSITION; DISPERSIONS; FUELS; FURANS; HETEROCYCLIC COMPOUNDS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDATION; POLYENES; PYROLYSIS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; 400800* - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 090100 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Synergistic hypergolic ignition of several fuel blends and mixtures with red fuming nitric acid (RFNA) as oxidizer has been reported previously. The liquid fuels consisted of blends of 3-carene, cyclopentadiene, or norbornadiene with cardanol in the weight ratio 70:30 for the first two and 85:15 for norbornadiene. In all these cases, synergism in ignition was believed to be due to the fast and exothermic oligomerization of 3-carene, cyclopentadiene, and norbornadiene in the presence of acid. The exothermicity of the systems was enhanced by the addition of cardanol to the unsaturation of oligomers, leading to the formation of highly oxidizable phenolic ethers. Two more important reactions at the preignition stage were nitration and oxidation of the ethers leading to the production of gaseous combustibles and heat. In this case, an attempt has been made to extend the range of possible preignition reactions by introducing diene-dienophile Diels-Alder cycloaddition with low activation energy by replacing cardanol with furfuryl alcohol or furfurylideneacetone having a furan ring to behave as acid polymerizable dienes in the above systems.
RESEARCH_ORG: Institute of Armament Technology, Girinagar, Pune (IN)
RELATION: Journal Name: Combust. Flame; (United States); Journal Volume: 76:1

SUBJECT: 09 BIOMASS FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ETHANE; SOLUBILITY; PARAFFIN; SOLVENT PROPERTIES; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; EQUATIONS; ISOTHERMAL PROCESSES; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; PRESSURE EFFECTS; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; ALKANES; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OTHER ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; WAXES; 091000* - Biomass Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100300 - Synthetic Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-)

Measurements were made over the temperature range from 348 to 423{Kappa} (167-302 {sup 0}F) at pressures up to 7.8 MPa (1127 psia). The data can be described with average deviations of less than 0.003 mole fraction by the Soave-Redlich-Kwong or Peng-Robinson equation when two interaction parameters per isotherm are used in the equation.
