TITLE: Differences in the promotional effect of the group IA elements on unsupported copper catalysts for carbon monoxide hydrogenation
AUTHORS: Sheffer, G R; King, T S
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; METHANATION; CESIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; COPPER; LITHIUM; POTASSIUM; RUBIDIUM; SODIUM; ACTIVATION ENERGY; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; HIGH TEMPERATURE; HYDROGENATION; KINETIC EQUATIONS; MEDIUM PRESSURE; METHANOL; PHOTOELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; PROMOTERS; QUANTITY RATIO; SCANNING ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; SURFACE AREA; SYNTHESIS; SYNTHESIS GAS; X-RAY SPECTROSCOPY; ALCOHOLS; ALKALI METALS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; ELEMENTS; ENERGY; EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; METALS; MICROSCOPY; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; SPECTROSCOPY; SURFACE PROPERTIES; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The differences in promotional effect of the Group IA elements on unsupported copper catalysts for carbon monoxide hydrogenation have been examined. Methanol was selectivity produced on all catalysts at 523 K, 5 MPa, and with a feed gas of molar composition H{sub 2}/CO = 2. When normalized with respect to surface area, the methanol synthesis rate was found to increase by an order of magnitude from Li to Cs with the majority of the increase occurring from Na to K. On the basis of apparent activation energy measurements, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and scanning electron microscopy results, activity differences were attributed to differences in the concentration of Cu{sup +} species at the surface and not to electronic effects. Alkali-cuprates, for example LiCuO, were determined not to be the active phase responsible for Cu{sup +} stabilization. Under conditions more favorable for higher alcohol synthesis, 573 K and H{sub 2}/CO = 1, little change in selectivity was observed for the Na-, K-, Rb-, and Cs-promoted catalysts. However, the lithium-promoted catalyst produced an equimolar mixture of normal alcohols and hydrocarbons. Both product distributions were found to give linear Flory plots with propagation constants of 0.3 for alcohols and 0.5 for hydrocarbons.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 116:2

TITLE: Ignition behavior of a multicomponent fuel spray
AUTHORS: Aggarwal, S K
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; IGNITION; PHASE STUDIES; LIQUID FUELS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; DIFFUSION; DROPLETS; EQUATIONS; HEAT FLUX; SPRAYS; FUELS; KINETICS; PARTICLES; REACTION KINETICS; 400800* - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 090500 - Liquid Waste Fuels- (-1989); 090100 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Ignition characteristics of multicomponent fuel sprays are studied. Three subsets of equations, the gas-phase, the liquid-phase, and the droplet equations, are solved by a hybrid Eulerian-Lagrangian, explicit-implicit method. Major features of the ignition model are that a zero heat-flux criterion is used to define ignition, a global one-step reaction scheme with nonunity exponents of fuel and oxygen is employed for a multifuel system, and the transient thermal and composition fields inside the droplet are resolved via a diffusion-limit model. Monodisperse and polydisperse size distributions are considered. The results are presented for a bicomponent fuel spray. The ignition behavior exhibits a strong sensitivity to the initial fuel composition. The presence of a volatile component, even in small amounts, can greatly improve the ignitability of nonvolatile fuel sprays. The relative enhancement in ignitability depends strongly on the droplet size, volatility differential, hot wall temperature, and, to a lesser degree, on the equivalence ratio. The results are significant from a practical point of view as the concept may be used to improve the ignitability of liquid fuel sprays.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Univ. of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: Combust. Flame; (United States); Journal Volume: 76:1

TITLE: Electrocatalytic reduction of nitrite and nitric oxide to ammonia with iron-substituted polyoxotungstates
AUTHORS: Toth, J E; Anson, F C
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; AMMONIA; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; IRON COMPOUNDS; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; NITRIC OXIDE; REDUCTION; NITRITES; TUNGSTATES; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; CATALYSIS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; ELECTROCATALYSTS; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; PH VALUE; VOLTAMETRY; CATALYSTS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHEMISTRY; DATA; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; KINETICS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NITROGEN OXIDES; NUMERICAL DATA; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; SPECTROSCOPY; SYNTHESIS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400400 - Electrochemistry
DESCRIPTION: Heteropolytungstates in which one of the positions normally occupied by a tungsten cation is occupied instead by an iron cation are shown to be catalysts for the electroreduction of nitrite to ammonia. The lacunary derivatives in which the empty tungsten site is unoccupied show no catalytic activity. The catalytic mechanism involves the intermediate formation of a nitrosyl complex of the Fe(II) form of the catalyst. The pH dependence of the rate of formation of the nitrosyl complex shows that nitrous acid is the reactive form of nitrite between pH 2 and 8. The catalyzed reduction does not produce hydroxylamine as an intermediate and appears to depend upon the ability of the multiply reduced heteropolytungstates to deliver electrons to the NO group bound to the iron center in a concerted, multiple-electron step. The iron-substituted heteropolytungstates are not degraded by repeated cycling between their oxidized and reduced states. A particularly valuable feature of the heteropolytungstate is the ease with which the formal potentials of the several redox couples they exhibit may be shifted by changing the identity of the central heteroatom. Exploitation of this feature provides diagnostic information that can be decisive in establishing the mechanism of electrocatalytic processes.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of the American Chemical Society; (USA); Journal Volume: 111:7
JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of the American Chemical Society; (USA)

TITLE: Electrocatalytic reduction of nitrate in sodium hydroxide solution in the presence of low-valent cobalt-cyclam species
AUTHORS: Li, Hulin; Anderson, W C; Chambers, J Q; Hobbs, D T
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; AMMONIA; PRODUCTION; COBALT COMPLEXES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CYCLOALKANES; HYDROXYLAMINE; NITRATES; REDUCTION; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; ELECTROLYSIS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; SODIUM HYDROXIDES; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKANES; AMINES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COMPLEXES; DATA; DISPERSIONS; HYDRIDES; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXIDES; INFORMATION; LYSIS; MIXTURES; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SOLUTIONS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPLEXES; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: In concentrated NaOH solution nitrate and nitrite ions are efficiently reduced to a mixture of products including hydroxylamine and ammonia via an electrocatalytic process in the presence of cobalt complexes of 1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane (cyclam). A key mechanistic role is proposed for Co{sup I}(cyclam)NO{sub 3}, which is generated in the diffusion layer at ca. -1.3 V vs SCE. The lack of dependent on pH of either the catalytic peak potential or the peak current indicates that metal hydride intermediate species are not involved in the initial steps of the reduction process. Both Co{sup I} and Co{sup III} intermediates in the nitrate reduction are detected in collection experiments with a gold ring-disk electrode. 18 refs., 8 figs., 2 tabs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Inorganic Chemistry; (USA); Journal Volume: 28:5

TITLE: Translational-rotational coupling parameters for mutual diffusion in n-octane
AUTHORS: Erkey, C; Akgerman, A
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ETHANE; DIFFUSION; HEPTANE; METHANE; PROPANE; CALCULATION METHODS; COUPLING; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; OCTANE; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; SOLUTES; SOLVENTS; THEORETICAL DATA; THERMODYNAMICS; ALKANES; DATA; HYDROCARBONS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; 090110* - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The infinite dilution diffusion coefficients of methane, ethane, n-propane, n-pentane, n-heptane, n-decane, n-dodecane, and n-tetradecane have been measured in n-octane using the Taylor dispersion technique in the temperature range 304-435 at 1.72 x 10/sup 6/ N/m/sup 2/. Using the framework of the rough hard sphere theory, the values of the translational-rotational coupling parameter have been determined for each solute-solvent pair at each temperature. The coupling parameter was found to be independent of temperature over the entire temperature range of the experiments performed and it has the same value for solutes ranging from n-pentane to n-tetradecane. A calculation scheme is presented for accurate determination of infinite dilution diffusion coefficients for a wide range of solutes in n-octane at a wide temperature range.
RESEARCH_ORG: Texas A and M Univ., College Station, TX (USA). Dept. of Chemical Engineering
RELATION: Journal Name: A.I.Ch.E. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 35:3

TITLE: Catalytic cracking kinetic models
AUTHORS: Oliveira, L L; Biscaia, E C
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMICAL REACTORS; COKING; GASOLINE; CATALYTIC CRACKING; COKE; EVALUATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; CARBONIZATION; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CRACKING; DECOMPOSITION; FUELS; KINETICS; LIQUID FUELS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; PYROLYSIS; REACTION KINETICS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; 020400* - Petroleum- Processing; 090121 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Chemical Synthesis- (1976-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Four kinetic models for catalytic cracking of gasoline are proposed based on catalytic cracking and catalyst deactivation models presented in the literature. In three of them, it is assumed that activity decayed with catalyst time-on-stream; in the last model, the decay in activity was related to the amount of coke deposited on the catalyst. Experiments for estimating the parameters of the models were performed in a bench-scale fixed bed reactor. One of the kinetic models was selected as the one that best describes the catalytic cracking of gasoline. The selected model was further incorporated into a gas oil range paraffinic compounds cracking model, which also had its parameters estimated. Finally, some coke-on-catalyst profiles along the axial direction of a fixed bed reactor during the catalytic cracking of gas oil range paraffinic compounds are predicted.
RESEARCH_ORG: PETROBRAS, Rio de Janeiro, RJ (Brazil); COPPE, UFRJ, Ilha do Fundao, Centro de Tecnologia, Bloco G, 21945 Rio de Janeiro (BR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Ind. Eng. Chem. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 28:3

TITLE: Criteria for spontaneous ignition in exothermic, autocatalytic reactions
AUTHORS: Snee, T J; Griffiths, J F
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 42 ENGINEERING; AIR; COMBUSTION KINETICS; CYCLOHEXANE; FLAMES; COMBUSTION PRODUCTS; FUELS; ISOTHERMAL PROCESSES; ACTIVATION ENERGY; CLOSED-CYCLE SYSTEMS; CRITICALITY; HEAT LOSSES; MIXTURES; NATURAL CONVECTION; OXIDATION; SCALING LAWS; SUPERCRITICAL STATE; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; ALKANES; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONVECTION; CYCLOALKANES; DISPERSIONS; ENERGY; ENERGY LOSSES; ENERGY TRANSFER; FLUIDS; GASES; HEAT TRANSFER; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; LOSSES; MASS TRANSFER; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; 090110* - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989); 400800 - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 420400 - Engineering- Heat Transfer & Fluid Flow
DESCRIPTION: The combustion of fuel-rich hydrocarbon + air mixtures constitutes an autoignition hazard that is of concern in industrial processes. The authors report studies of the combustion of cyclohexane + air, in the molar proportions cC/sub 6/H/sub 12/:air = 1:2, using five closed vessels covering a very extensive range of volume (0.2-20 dm/sup 3/). The authors use the minimum ignition temperature measured in each vessel to test scaling rules for the prediction of conditions for criticality. Measurements were also made of the yields of some products, the extent of reaction (and from it the rate), and the accompanying temperature change under both subcritical and supercritical conditions. Characteristic cooling times from hot gases in each vessel were also assessed experimentally. The authors show that fuel-rich compositions undergo isothermal oxidation that follows a quadratic, autocatalytic rate law. Departures from this due to self-heating of the reactants are also reported. Spontaneous ignition occurs as a result of chemical autocatalysis augmented by self-heating. On the basis of the Semenov parameter for criticality in a corrected form of the condition for thermal ignition, the autoignition temperatures in vessels of different size are found to match a linear scaling relationship. This would be expected in systems in which spatially uniform temperatures prevail.
RESEARCH_ORG: Health and Safety Executive, Research and Lab. Service Div., Harpur Hill, Buxton, Derbyshire, SK17 9JN (GB); Dept. of Physical Chemistry, The Univ., Leeds LS2 9JT (GB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Combust. Flame; (United States); Journal Volume: 75:3

TITLE: An experimental study on extinction and stability of tubular flames
AUTHORS: Ishizuka, S
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 42 ENGINEERING; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; AIR; MIXTURES; BURNERS; FLAMES; METHANE; PROPANE; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; HYDROGEN; ALKANES; DATA; DISPERSIONS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROCARBONS; INFORMATION; NONMETALS; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; 400800* - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 421000 - Engineering- Combustion Systems; 090110 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Using a swirl-type burner, the characteristics of tubular flames in a rotating, axisymmetrical stretched flow field have been experimentally investigated for lean and rich methane/air and propane/air mixtures and for lean hydrogen/air mixtures. The tubular flame region and the corrugated flame region are mapped as functions of the fuel concentration and the tangential ejection velocity, and the variations of the flame diameter with the fuel concentration are also determined. The results qualitatively agree with the previous observation for lean mixtures and substantiate the domainant effect of the Lewis number on the characteristics of the tubular flames. A further detailed discussion has been made on the extinction characteristics of the tubular flame and the corrugation of the flame front.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Saitama Institute of Technology, 1690 Fusaiji, Okabe, Saitama (JP)
RELATION: Journal Name: Combust. Flame; (United States); Journal Volume: 75:3

TITLE: Chemical nature of alkali-promoted copper-cobalt-chromium oxide higher alcohol catalysts
AUTHORS: Sheffer, G R; Jacobson, R A; King, T S
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; ALCOHOLS; SYNTHESIS; CATALYSTS; SURFACE PROPERTIES; CHROMIUM; STRUCTURAL CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; COBALT; COPPER; CALCINATION; CHEMICAL REACTION YIELD; CHROMIUM OXIDES; COBALT OXIDES; COPPER OXIDES; DISTRIBUTION; FISCHER-TROPSCH SYNTHESIS; MICROSTRUCTURE; PHOTOELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; SPINELS; SYNTHESIS GAS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; X-RAY DIFFRACTION; X-RAY SPECTROSCOPY; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS; COBALT COMPOUNDS; COHERENT SCATTERING; COPPER COMPOUNDS; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; DECOMPOSITION; DIFFRACTION; ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; MAGNESIUM OXIDES; METALS; MINERALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDE MINERALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PYROLYSIS; SCATTERING; SPECTROSCOPY; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; YIELDS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: The chemical nature of alkali-promoted copper-cobalt-chromium higher alcohol catalysts has been evaluated as a function of calcination temperature by using X-ray diffraction and X-ray photolectron spectroscopy. Also investigated were the alkali-promoted mono- and bimetallic oxide systems. The activated catalysts was determined to consist of copper metal and a cobalt-chromium spinel. Oxygenate production correlated with the dispersion of copper metal in the catalyst. Poorer copper dispersion and a decrease in oxygenate formation were observed with increasing catalysts calcination temperature. There was no evidence of cuprous ions or cobalt metal in the activated catalysts; therefore, it is unlikely that component synergism is a result of alkyl chain growth on cobalt metal sites coupled with alcohol termination by CO molecularly adsorbed on copper(I) chromite.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 115:1

TITLE: Higher alcohol and oxygenate synthesis over Cs/Cu/ZnO/M sub 2 O sub 3 (M = Al, Cr) catalysts
AUTHORS: Nunan, J G; Herman, R G; Klier, K
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; ALCOHOLS; SYNTHESIS; CATALYST SUPPORTS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; CESIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; COPPER; ZINC OXIDES; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHROMIUM OXIDES; DOPED MATERIALS; ETHANOL; ETHERS; METHANOL; PROMOTERS; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; ALKALI METALS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; MATERIALS; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; ZINC COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-)
DESCRIPTION: Surface doping of Cu/ZnO/M{sub 2}O{sub 3} (M = Al, Cr) catalysts prepared from hydrotalcite precursors with cesium (Cs/Cu/ZnO/M{sub 2}O{sub 3}) significantly enhanced to the alcohol synthesis rate under higher alcohol synthesis conditions. With respect to the unsupported Cs/Cu/ZnO catalyst, the product selectivity of the Cs/Cu/ZnO/Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} catalyst was shifted toward methanol, while the Cs/Cu/ZnO/Cr{sub 2}O{sub 3} catalyst maintained a high selectivity toward C{sub 2}{sup +} alcohols. The presence of cesium in the Cu/ZnO/M{sub 2}O{sub 3} catalysts inhibited the synthesis of dimethyl ether. Comparison of the product distributions obtained over the Cs/Cu/ZnO/M{sub 2}O{sub 3} catalysts with those observed over the Cs/Cu/ZnO catalysts indicates that the function of the Cs/Cu/ZnO/Cr{sub 2}O{sub 3} catalyst is similar to that of the Cs/Cu/ZnO in that higher alcohols are synthesized by a stepwise carbon chain growth via a unique aldol coupling with oxygen retention reversal mechanism. The Al{sub 2}O{sub 3}-based catalysts undergo complex structural changes that probably cause occlusion of the Cs dopant, thus resulting in low selectivity to higher alcohols while retaining high activity toward methanol. 23 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 116:1

TITLE: The pyrolysis of acetylene initiated by acetone
AUTHORS: Colket, III, M B; Seery, D J; Palmer, H B
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ACETYLENE; PYROLYSIS; ACETONE; BENZENE; CALCULATION METHODS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; ETHYLENE; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; HIGH TEMPERATURE; IMPURITIES; OPTIMIZATION; SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS; THERMODYNAMIC MODEL; VERY HIGH TEMPERATURE; ALKENES; ALKYNES; AROMATICS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; DATA; DECOMPOSITION; HYDROCARBONS; INFORMATION; KETONES; KINETICS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PARTICLE MODELS; REACTION KINETICS; STATISTICAL MODELS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; 400800* - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 090110 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A detailed, radical chain mechanism is used to model the pyrolysis of acetylene near 1000 K. The initiation process, C/sub 2/H/sub 2/ + C/sub 2/H/sub 2/ ..-->.. C/sub 4/H/sub 3/ + H, appears to be inconsistent with thermochemistry. Since experimental evidence indicates the presence of a chain mechanism, alternative sources of initiation are considered. Acetone, a common impurity in purified acetylene, was found to dominate radical initiation during the pyrolysis of acetylene near 1000 K despite concentration levels only 0.1% that of acetylene. Modeling results compare favorably with the experimental results for acetylene decay and the formation of products vinylacetylene, benzene, and ethylene. Rate constants for the following reactions were adjusted to be: C/sub 2/H/sub 3/+C/sub 2/H/sub 3/ /equilibrium/ C/sub 4/H/sub 6/ k/sub 4/=2.0X10/sup 13/ cm/sup 3/ mol/sup -1/ sec/sup -1/; n-C/sub 4/H/sub 5/ /equilibrium/ C/sub 4/H/sub 4/+H k/sub 32/=1.6X10/sup 14/ x e/sup -(41.4 kcal mol -1/RT)/ sec/sup -1/; n-C/sub 4/H/sub 5/+C/sub 2/H/sub 2/ /equilibrium/ C/sub 6/H/sub 6/+H k/sub 33/=4.5X10/sup 12/Xe/sup -(10. kcal mol -1/RT)/ cm/sup 3/ mol -1 sec/sup -1/; n-C/sub 4/H/sub 5/+C/sub 4/H/sub 4/ /equilibrium/ C/sub 8/H/sub 8/+H k/sub 35/=1.2X10/sup 13/ x e /sup -(5. kcal mol -1 /RT)/ cm/sup 3/ mol -1 sec/sup -1/, to optimize the fit to the experimental data. A sensitivity analysis shows that the computed results were most sensitive to rate constants for these and a few other reactions.
RESEARCH_ORG: United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, CT (US); Pennsylvania State Univ., University Park, PA (US)

TITLE: Transition to detonation in a flame jet
AUTHORS: Moen, I O; Bjerketvedt, D; Engebretsen, T; Jenssen, A; Hjertager, B H; Bakke, J R
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 42 ENGINEERING; ACETYLENE; IGNITION; MIXTURES; AIR; FLAMES; TURBULENT FLOW; JET ENGINE FUELS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; DETONATIONS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; GASES; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; TUBES; ALKYNES; DATA; DISPERSIONS; FLUID FLOW; FLUIDS; FUELS; HYDROCARBONS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; 400800* - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 090110 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989); 420400 - Engineering- Heat Transfer & Fluid Flow
DESCRIPTION: The results of an experimental and numerical investigation of flame-jet ignition of an acetylene-air cloud contained in a 2 m diameter plastic bag, 8 m long, are reported. The flame jet is produced by an acetylene-air flame in a 0.66 m diameter tube, 11 m long. The composition of the mixture was varied to obtain the critical composition for initiation of detonation in the cloud, with and without obstacles at the end of the tube. Numerical calculations were used to characterize the flame jet. Transition to detonation in the flame jet from an open tube was observed for acetylene-air mixtures with more than 7.9% C/sub 2/H/sub 2/. The mechanism of transition observed on the high-speed film records is analogous to that seen in similar laboratory experiments, with a localized explosion somewhere in the turbulent flame jet leading to the onset of detonation. Transition was facilitated by placing various obstacles at the exit of the tube. With an orifice plate with 50 mm diameter holes, initiation of detonation in a 7.0% C/sub 2/H/sub 2/ mixture occurs uniformly across the flame jet a short distance downstream of the plate. With a circular central obstacle in the tube exit, transition to detonation was observed in a 5.6and C/sub 2/H/sub 2/ mixture. From the results of this investigation, it is concluded that the phenomena of hot gas jet initiation of detonation seen in laboratory experiments with fuel-oxygen mixtures also occur in fuel-air mixtures provided the jet is large enough.

TITLE: Higher alcohol and oxygenate synthesis over cesium-doped Cu/ZnO catalysts
AUTHORS: Nunan, J G; Bogdan, C E; Klier, K; Smith, K J; Young, Chyi-Woei, Herman, R.G. (Lehigh Univ., Bethlehem, PA (USA))
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; ALCOHOLS; SYNTHESIS; CESIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; COPPER; ETHANOL; PROPANOLS; ZINC OXIDES; CARBON 13; CARBON MONOXIDE; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMICAL REACTION YIELD; DOPED MATERIALS; ESTERS; HYDROGEN; METHANOL; MOLECULAR STRUCTURE; NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE; PROMOTERS; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; SYNTHESIS GAS; ALKALI METALS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON ISOTOPES; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; ELEMENTS; EVEN-ODD NUCLEI; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; ISOTOPES; KINETICS; LIGHT NUCLEI; MAGNETIC RESONANCE; MATERIALS; METALS; NONMETALS; NUCLEI; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; RESONANCE; STABLE ISOTOPES; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; YIELDS; ZINC COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 010408 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-)
DESCRIPTION: The synthesis of higher (C{sub 2}{sup +}) alcohols and esters has been studied over cesium-doped Cu/ZnO catalysts. Under high alcohol synthesis conditions, e.g., 583 K, 7.6 MPa, and gas hourly space velocity = 3260 liters (STP)/kg cat/hr with a H{sub 2}/CO = 0.45 synthesis gas, the presence of cesium promoted the formation of higher oxygenates, especially 2-methyl-1-propanol. The yields of products passed through distinct maxima at cesium nominal concentrations of 0.3-0.5%. The principal role of cesium was to increase the ethanol synthesis rate and to provide an even greater enhancement in the rate of ethanol conversion to 1-propanol and subsequently to higher alcohols. To obtain insight into the mechanism of the carbon chain growth and linear versus branched carbon chain growth, a {sup 13}C-NMR study of the C{sub 2}-C{sub 4} product formed over Cu/ZnO and 0.4 mol% Cs/Cu/ZnO catalysts was performed. The presence of Cs effected a mechanistic switch and promoted {beta}-carbon addition, CH{sub 3}{sup 13}CH{sub 2}OH + CO/H{sub 2} {yields} {sup 13}CH{sub 3}CH{sub 2}CH{sub 2}OH. The position of the {sup 13}C label in the CH{sub 3} group of propanol provides evidence for retention of oxygen associated with the C{sub 1} intermediate, formed from CO/H{sub 2}, and loss of oxygen associated with {sup 13}CH{sub 2}OH group of ethanol. Mechanistically, such a retention is favored by a {beta}-ketoalkoxide intermediate that is bonded to the cesium centers via its anionic oxygen. This unique mechanism is termed here in as aldol coupling with oxygen retention reversal and is specific to the presence of the cesium salt dopant. 35 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 116:1

TITLE: A study on soot formation in premixed constant-volume propane combustion
AUTHORS: Kamimoto, T; Bae, M H; Kobayashi, H
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; PROPANE; COMBUSTION KINETICS; SOOT; AIR POLLUTION; COMBUSTION PRODUCTS; HIGH PRESSURE; OXYGEN; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALKANES; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; ELEMENTS; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; POLLUTION; REACTION KINETICS; 400800* - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 090110 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The soot formation in premixed propane-oxygen-inert gas combustion is investigated over the equivalence ratio range of 1.9-2.2 at intervals of 0.1, the pressure range of 0.4-5.8 MPa, the temperature range of 1000-1800K, and the inert gas fractions by using a specially designed disk-type constant-volume combustion bomb. In order to observe the soot formation under high pressure, the premixtures are simultaneously ignited by eight spark plugs located on the chamber circumference at 45/sup 0/ intervals. The eight converging flames compress the end gases to a high pressure, and the soot concentration in the chamber center during the final stage of combustion at the highest pressure is measured by the in situ laser-extinction method. The pressures during soot formation are varied by changing the initial charge pressure, and the temperatures by changing the inert gas compositions. It is found that the soot yield at lower temperatures rises sharply with increasing pressure, but the dependence of pressure gets weaker with higher temperatures, and the pressure and temperature during soot formation mainly influence the soot yield.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1, Ohokayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo (JP)
RELATION: Journal Name: Combust. Flame; (United States); Journal Volume: 75:3

TITLE: Kinetic simulation of ammonia synthesis catalysis
AUTHORS: Dumesic, J A; Trevino, A A
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; AMMONIA; SYNTHESIS; IRON; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CATALYSIS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CHEMICAL REACTORS; DISSOCIATION; FORECASTING; HIGH PRESSURE; HIGH TEMPERATURE; MEDIUM PRESSURE; NITROGEN; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; SIMULATION; SPECTROSCOPY; ELEMENTS; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; METALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NONMETALS; REACTION KINETICS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Kinetic simulation studies were carried out and showed that kinetic and spectroscopic data collected on iron single crystals under ultrahigh vacuum conditions can be used to predict the rate of ammonia synthesis over a commercial iron catalysts in a plug-flow reaction operating under industrial reaction conditions (i.e., 720 K, 107 atm). The results agree with earlier calculations by P. Stoltze and J.K. Norskov. Furthermore, the kinetic simulations confirm the fact that the dissociation of molecular dinitrogen precursor species is a slow step in the mechanism; however, other steps may also become slow depending on reaction conditions. Atomic nitrogen appears to be the most abundant reactive intermediate on the iron surface, except at the reactor inlet, where a variety of adsorbed species may compete for surface sites. Finally, the kinetic simulation results are also shown to describe the performance of iron catalysts in laboratory reactors operating at pressures from 1 to 20 atm.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 116:1

TITLE: Preparation of ternary Cu/Co/Al catalysts by the amorphous citrate process I. Decomposition of solid amorphous precursors
AUTHORS: Di Cosimo, J I; Apesteguia, C R
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALUMINIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; COBALT; COPPER; AIR; ALCOHOLS; CITRATES; CITRIC ACID; DECOMPOSITION; DERIVATIZATION; FUEL ADDITIVES; INFRARED SPECTRA; METHANOL; NITRATES; NITROGEN; OXIDATION; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; SYNTHESIS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; THERMAL GRAVIMETRIC ANALYSIS; ADDITIVES; CARBOXYLIC ACID SALTS; CARBOXYLIC ACIDS; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GASES; GRAVIMETRIC ANALYSIS; HYDROXY ACIDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; METALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; QUANTITATIVE CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; SPECTRA; THERMAL ANALYSIS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Cu-Co-Al amorphous precursors were prepared by means of the citric complexing method. The atomic ratios R = (Cu + Co)/Al and r = Cu/Co were varied between 12 {ge} R {ge} 1 and 5 {ge} r {ge} 0.5. The thermal decomposition of solid citrate precursors was carried out in air and nitrogen, and characterized by DTA, derivative thermogravimetry (DTG), and IR spectroscopy. Results showed that the main steps of the decomposition in air were (i) an exothermic transformation at 135-150{degree}C which represented a mass loss of {Delta}W = 25-35%, (ii) an intermediate decomposition at 220-240{degree}C of {Delta}W = 10-12%, and (iii) a highly exothermic decomposition at 280-300{degree}C of {Delta}W = 20-25%. IR spectra indicated that the low-temperature decomposition was caused by an exothermic reaction between ionic nitrates and free carboxyl groups. The high temperature stage corresponded to the oxidation of the citric acid structure. Above 280{degree}C, the treatment in N{sub 2} caused the breakup of the citrate chains through several consecutive transformations. In all the cases, the main characteristics of the decomposition peaks depended on the metallic composition. The decomposition of the precursors in air showed a high tendency to uncontrolled decomposition. On the other hand, after the N{sub 2} treatment at 500{degree}C a significant content of carbon remained on the samples. The advantage of performing a two-step decomposition procedure using first nitrogen up to 280{degree}C and after that an air atmosphere to oxidize the organic part of precursors at relatively low temperature is particularly discussed in this paper.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 116:1

TITLE: Exciplex fluorescence thermometry of liquid fuel
AUTHORS: Stufflebeam, J H
SUBJECT: 47 OTHER INSTRUMENTATION; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; DECANE; FLUORESCENCE; FUELS; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; ENERGY SPECTRA; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; LIQUIDS; MEASURING METHODS; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; ALKANES; DATA; FLUIDS; HYDROCARBONS; INFORMATION; LUMINESCENCE; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SPECTRA; 440300* - Miscellaneous Instruments- (-1989); 090100 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: An experimental program is described that investigates the applicationof exciplex fluorescence to the internal thermometry of flowing liquiddecane in the temperature range 24--91 /degree/C. Decane is doped withpyrene and excited by laser radiation at 354.7 nm. A library oftemperature-dependent, exciplex fluorescence spectra is obtainedfrom a static, isothermal solution, and the spectral featuresare analyzed to produce a temperature-prediction algorithm. Thesolution then flows through a temperature gradient region, and thelaser-induced fluorescence spectra that are recorded as used todetermine the local temperature in the solution by applicationof the algorithm. Excellent agreement between the predictedtemperatures and those measured by thermocouples in contactwith the solution is realized. The experiment demonstrates thehigh accuracy and spatial resolution obtainable with this laser-basedthermometry technique.
RESEARCH_ORG: United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, Connecticut 06108(US)
RELATION: Journal Name: Appl. Spectrosc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 43:2

TITLE: The synthesis of butyronitrile from n-butanol and ammonia over rhodium (111) and (331) single-crystal surfaces
AUTHORS: Naasz, B M; Boeszoermenyi, I; Somorjai, G A
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; AMMONIA; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; BUTANOLS; NITRILES; SYNTHESIS; RHODIUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; ACTIVATION ENERGY; AUGER ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; CATALYSIS; CATALYTIC CRACKING; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; DEACTIVATION; DESORPTION; LAYERS; OXIDATION; POISONING; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; SPECIFICITY; SURFACE PROPERTIES; ALCOHOLS; CRACKING; DECOMPOSITION; ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; ELEMENTS; ENERGY; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; METALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; PYROLYSIS; REACTION KINETICS; SPECTROSCOPY; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 102000* - Synthetic Fuels- Products & By-Products- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The rhodium (111) and (331) single-crystal surfaces selectively catalyze the formation of butyronitrile from n-butanol and ammonia without the production of other nitrogen-containing species. The reaction is found to be structure sensitive. The Rh (331) surface is three times more active in the ammonolysis reaction, but poisons faster and produces 8-10 times more cracking products than the Rh (111). Auger electron spectroscopy and thermal desorption spectroscopy results indicate that the reaction takes place on an overlayer which covers 95% of the total surface of the catalyst and contains C, N, and O. On the deactivated catalyst this layer contains more carbon. The mechanism of the reaction is independent of the surface structure of the rhodium catalyst since the apparent activation energies for the two surfaces are practically the same (21-22 kcal/mol). Most of the results are consistent with a model according to which the n-butanol is oxidized first to n-butanal which then reacts with ammonia and then possibly through an imine intermediate the butyronitrile is produced. 34 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 115:2

TITLE: Acid and catalytic properties of nonstoichiometric aluminum borates
AUTHORS: Peil, K P; Marcelin, G; Galya, L G
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; MICROSTRUCTURE; BORATES; PROPANOLS; DEHYDRATION; ALUMINIUM 27; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; BORON 11; BORON OXIDES; CATALYSTS; MIXTURES; NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE; OXIDES; PH VALUE; POROSITY; QUANTITY RATIO; STABILITY; STOICHIOMETRY; SURFACE AREA; ALCOHOLS; ALUMINIUM ISOTOPES; BORON COMPOUNDS; BORON ISOTOPES; CHALCOGENIDES; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; DISPERSIONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; ISOTOPES; LIGHT NUCLEI; MAGNETIC RESONANCE; NUCLEI; ODD-EVEN NUCLEI; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RESONANCE; STABLE ISOTOPES; SURFACE PROPERTIES; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 360602 - Other Materials- Structure & Phase Studies; 360603 - Materials- Properties; 102000 - Synthetic Fuels- Products & By-Products- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: This paper details an investigation on the structure-acidity-catalytic activity relationship in aluminum borate mixed oxides. This aluminum borate mixed oxide is amorphous, is refractory, and exhibits properties which are dependent on the exact stoichiometry of the material. A series of catalysts with B/Al ratios ranging from 0 to 1 was prepared and characterized with respect to surface area, pore volume, and thermal stability. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy of {sup 11}B and {sup 27}Al was used to determine the local structure. Two boron species were identified: a tetrahedral BO{sub 4} and a trigonal BO{sub 3}. The relative amounts of the two boron species were dependent on the B/Al stoichiometry. Three aluminum species were identified: a tetrahedral AlO{sub 4}, an octahedral AlO{sub 6}, and an AlO{sub 4} with four B next-nearest neighbors. The strength and concentration of acid sites present on the surface of the aluminum borates were determined using adsorbed indicators. The presence and coordination of boron were seen to have a dramatic effect on the acidity of these materials with the acidity being closely related to the relative concentration of BO{sub 4}. 2-Propanol dehydration was used as a probe reaction to measure the acidity. Results from this reaction have shown these materials to indeed by highly acidic and catalytically active.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 115:2

TITLE: Mechanistic study on the alcohol synthesis over molybdenum catalysts: Addition of probe molecules to CO-H sub 2
AUTHORS: Tatsumi, Takashi; Muramatus, Atsushi; Yokota, Kohshiroh; Tominaga, Hiro-o
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALCOHOLS; SYNTHESIS; CARBON MONOXIDE; HYDROGENATION; MOLYBDENUM; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; POTASSIUM CHLORIDES; ACETALDEHYDE; ADDITIVES; CATALYST SUPPORTS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; ETHANOL; ETHYLENE; FUEL ADDITIVES; METHANOL; PROMOTERS; PROPYLENE; REACTION INTERMEDIATES; SILICA; SYNTHESIS GAS; ALDEHYDES; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKENES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GASES; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; METALS; MINERALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDE MINERALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The addition of probe molecules, such as ethylene, propylene, methanol, ethanol, and acetaldehyde, to CO-H{sub 2} feed was studied over the KCl-promoted and the unpromoted Mo/SiO{sub 2} catalyst under synthetic conditions, in order to clarify the reaction paths for the formation of hydrocarbons and alcohols. The results of olefin addition study suggest that the alcohol formation from CO-H{sub 2} proceeds by a mechanism including steps identical with those in the hydrocarbonylation of olefins and that KCl suppresses the simple hydrogenation of olefins. Both of the Mo catalysts demonstrate a poor catalytic activity for the homologation of methanol to ethanol. Alcohol homologation seems to be only a minor process in the formation of C{sub 2}{sup +} alcohols. No significant activity of Mo catalysts for incorporation of acetaldehyde into C{sub 3} oxygenated compounds may exclude the intermediacy of aldehydes for the chain growth of alcohols. Hydrogenation of acetaldehyde to ethanol is the fast and predominant reaction, in agreement with the fact that alcohols compose more 90% of the organic oxygenates produced from CO-H{sub 2}. Aldol condensation is apparently unimportant for the chain growth. The contribution of alcohol dehydration to hydrocarbon formation may be insignificant over the KCl-promoted catalyst with K/Mo = 0.4. Consequently, a mechanism including CO insertion into the alkyl-metal bond is proposed for the main reaction path for the higher alcohol formation from CO-H{sub 2}. The role of K is supposed to slow the hydrogenation of surface alkyl species to form alkanes as well as to increase the active sites for alcohol formation by retarding the reduction of Mo.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 115:2

TITLE: Potassium's promotional effect of unsupported copper catalysts for methanol synthesis
AUTHORS: Sheffer, G R; King, T S
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON MONOXIDE; HYDROGENATION; COPPER; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; METHANOL; SYNTHESIS; POTASSIUM; CATALYSIS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; PHOTOELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; POTASSIUM CARBONATES; PROMOTERS; X-RAY SPECTROSCOPY; ALCOHOLS; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALI METALS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CARBONATES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; SPECTROSCOPY; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 010408* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- C1 Processes- (1987-); 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents an investigation of the promotional effect of potassium on unsupported copper catalysts for the hydrogenation of carbon monoxide. Using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), the authors determined that under reaction conditions copper exists as a mixture of Cu{sup +} and Cu{sup 0} species. Metallic copper by itself is inactive for the hydrogenation of carbon monoxide, while the authors have found that the addition of potassium to copper forms an active and selective (up to 98 wt %) methanol synthesis catalyst. The initiation of catalytic activity correlated with the stabilization of the Cu{sup +} species. The potassium promoter was determined to be in the form of the thermodynamically stable carbonate. Potassium promotes this catalyst by stabilizing the Cu{sup +} species, probably in the form of CuKCO{sub 3}.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 115:2

TITLE: Infrared diffuse reflectance study of the silicon-rich H-ZSM-5 catalysis of ethanol conversion
AUTHORS: Moser, W R; Chiang, C C; Thompson, R W
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ETHANOL; CATALYTIC REFORMING; ETHYLENE; SYNTHESIS; ZEOLITES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; ALUMINIUM; INFRARED SPECTRA; QUANTITY RATIO; REFLECTIVITY; SILICON; SURFACE PROPERTIES; ALCOHOLS; ALKENES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; MATERIALS; METALS; MINERALS; OPTICAL PROPERTIES; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; REFORMER PROCESSES; SEMIMETALS; SPECTRA; 102000* - Synthetic Fuels- Products & By-Products- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: A new infrared diffuse reflectance reactor was used to study the in situ H-ZSM-5 catalyzed conversion of ethanol to high-purity ethylene between ambient temperature and 400 C. Zeolites having a Si/Al atom ratio of 35 to 126 adsorbed ethanol principally on aluminol acid sites, while silicon-rich materials of Si/Al greater than 500 adsorbed ethanol on both terminal silanol sites and intracrystalline hydrogen-bonded silanols. The silicon-rich materials demonstrated hydrogen-bonded silanol functionalities in their intracrystalline structures which became prominent as the silicon content increased. A portion of these silanols was removed from the infrared spectrum upon treatment with dilute sodium hydroxide demonstrating their acidity. The in situ infrared data showed that ethanol conversion to ethylene using zeolites of low Si/Al ratio utilized aluminum-based Bronsted acid sites while the activity of the silicon-rich materials was based on the hydrogenation-bonded silanols.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 115:2

TITLE: Isomerization of n-hexane and n-pentane mixture on Pt-alumina catalyst
AUTHORS: Radhi, M A; Al-Mutawalli, F S; Al-Sammarie, E A
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; HEXANE; CATALYTIC CONVERTERS; PENTANE; PLATINUM; ATMOSPHERIC PRESSURE; CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL REACTORS; ENERGY CONVERSION; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; ALKANES; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CONVERSION; ELEMENTS; EQUIPMENT; METALS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLATINUM METALS; POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 090121* - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Chemical Synthesis- (1976-1989); 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: A mixture of n-hexane and n-penane (1:1) by volume was isomerized on commercial Pt-alumina catalyst in a continuously fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. The effect of temperature, LHSV, hydrogen/hyrocarbon molar ratio and chlorine concentration were studied. It was found that the yield of isohexanes and isopentane increases with increasing the chloride added up to 0.1 and 0.2 mole % CCl/sub 4/ respectively. The rate of isomerization became slower at higher concentrations. Isomerization activity of the catalyst increases with increasing temperature ranging between 350-400/sup 0/C. The yield of isomers decrease with increasing temperature above 400/sup 0/C. The relative conversion of n-hexane in the mixture was found to be more than the conversion of pure n-hexane at the same conditions.
RESEARCH_ORG: Petroleum Research Centre, Scientific Research Council, P.O. Box 10039, Jadiriyah, Baghdad (IQ)
RELATION: Journal Name: Fuel Sci. Technol. Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:2

TITLE: Examinations of the matrix isolation fourier transform infrared spectra of organic compounds: Part XII
AUTHORS: Coleman, III, W M; Gordon, B M; Lawrence, B M
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; BUTENES; ISOMERS; GERANIOL; METHANE; METHYL RADICALS; SPECTROSCOPY; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; FOURIER TRANSFORM SPECTROMETERS; INFRARED SPECTRA; ISOPRENE; MASS SPECTROSCOPY; MATRIX ELEMENTS; MEASURING METHODS; NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE; TERPENES; ALCOHOLS; ALKANES; ALKENES; ALKYL RADICALS; DATA; DIENES; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; MAGNETIC RESONANCE; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; POLYENES; RADICALS; RESONANCE; SPECTRA; SPECTROMETERS; 090110* - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Matrix isolation Fourier transform infrared spectra (MI/FT-IR), massspectra (MS), carbon-13 Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (/sup 13/C-NMR) spectra,condensed-phase infrared spectra, and vapor-phase infrared (IR)spectra are presented for a series of terpene compounds. Subtle differencesin positional and configurational isomers commonly found withterpenes could be easily detected by the MI/FT-IR spectra. The resultsare comparable in some aspects to those obtainable from /sup 13/C-NMR andthin-film IR; however, most importantly, they are acquired at the lownanogram level for MI/FT-IR, as compared to the milligram level forthe other techniques. These results represent an advance in the technologyavailable for the analysis of complex mixtures such as essential oilscontaining terpene-like molecules.
RESEARCH_ORG: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, Bowman Gray Technical Center, Winston-Salem, North Carolina 27102(US)
RELATION: Journal Name: Appl. Spectrosc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 43:2

TITLE: Oxidative homolysis of pentaaquoorganochromium(III) cations induced by macrocyclic nickel(III) complexes
AUTHORS: Katsuyama, T; Bakac, A; Espenson, J H
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALCOHOLS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; ALKENES; CHROMIUM COMPLEXES; DECOMPOSITION; NICKEL COMPLEXES; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; WATER; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; OXIDATION; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COMPLEXES; DATA; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SYNTHESIS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPLEXES; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 100200 - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The Ni(III) complexes Ni(cyclam){sup 3+} and Ni((9)aneN{sub 3}){sub 2}{sup 3+} oxidize the pentaaquoorganochromium(III) complexes (H{sub 2}O){sub 5}CrR{sup 2+} to Cr{sup 3+} and olefins or alcohols. The rate constants for the oxidation by Ni(cyclam){sup 3+} have values <1 (R = CH{sub 3}), 13 (C{sub 2}H{sub 5}), 220 (2-C{sub 3}H{sub 7}), 2.45 {times} 10{sup 3} (CH{sub 2}OCH{sub 3}), 3.44 {times} 10{sup 3} (CH(CH{sub 3})OC{sub 2}H{sub 5}), and 1.88 {times} 10{sup 4} M{sup {minus}1} s{sup {minus}1} (PhCH{sub 2}). The oxidation by Ni((9)aneN{sub 3}){sub 2}{sup 3+} has similar rate constants: k = 95 (R = 2-C{sub 3}H{sub 7}) and 1.31 {times} 10{sup 4} s{sup {minus}1} (PhCH{sub 2}). The one-electron oxidation of CrR{sup 2+} by the Ni(III) complexes yields a short-lived CrR{sup 3+} complex, which subsequently decomposes by homolysis (R = alkyl, benzyl) or by intramolecular electron transfer (R = alkoxyalkyl). The results are compared to the one-electron oxidation of organocobaloximes. 1 fig., 1 table, 22 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Inorganic Chemistry; (USA); Journal Volume: 28:2

TITLE: Recover butene-1 or -2 easier
AUTHORS: Emmrich, G; Lackner, K
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; BUTANE; SEPARATION PROCESSES; PETROLEUM FRACTIONS; CATALYTIC CRACKING; BUTENES; DISTILLATION; HYDROCARBONS; PETROLEUM REFINERIES; STEAM INJECTION; SYNTHESIS; ALKANES; ALKENES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CRACKING; DECOMPOSITION; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUID INJECTION; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM; PYROLYSIS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; 020400* - Petroleum- Processing; 090121 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Chemical Synthesis- (1976-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Extractive distillation of butanes from butenes makes it easier to recover butene-1 and butene-2 as individual products. Large amounts of C/sub 4/ hydrocarbons are produced from steam crackers and catalytic crackers. Some of these C/sub 4/ fractions are isolated for use as chemical raw materials. For example, butadiene can be isolated by extraction. Isobutene can be selectively combined with methanol to make MTBE. To date, only a few plants use the residual C/sub 4/ raffinate (Raffinate 2) as chemical raw materials. Most of the Raffinate 2 has been burned as fuel. Until recently, a great deal of effort and expense were needed to separate butene-1 and butene-2 because their boiling points were very close to other C/sub 4/ fractions. But now there is an extractive distillation process, the Butenex Process, in which a solvent alters the vapor pressures of butanes and butenes, thus facilitating--or at least rendering possible--separation by distillation.
RESEARCH_ORG: GKT Gesellschaft fur Kohle-Technologie mbH, Essen (DE)
RELATION: Journal Name: Hydrocarbon Process.; (United States); Journal Volume: 68:1

TITLE: Viscosities of alcohol-hydrocarbon systems in the critical region
AUTHORS: Brunson, R R; Byers, C H
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALCOHOLS; VISCOSITY; HYDROCARBONS; BINARY MIXTURES; CHEMICAL BONDS; HYDROGEN; LASERS; LIGHT SCATTERING; MEASURING METHODS; DISPERSIONS; ELEMENTS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; MIXTURES; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; SCATTERING; 023000* - Petroleum- Properties & Composition; 090210 - Alcohol Fuels- Properties- (1976-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The viscosities of pure alcohols and hydrocarbons, as well as binary mixtures of these compounds, were measured from room temperature to the critical region by use of a laser light scattering technique. Specially prepared monodispersed submicron silica particles were developed and used to achieve suspension stability into the critical region. The lower temperature data were verified by conventional techniques and by comparison with reliable literature data. In both pure materials and mixtures, the Andrade correlation is clearly not applicable over a wide temperature range. Excess viscosity indicates expected disruption of hydrogen-bonding networks by the hydrocarbons in alcohols.
RESEARCH_ORG: Oak Ridge National Lab., TN (USA). Chemical Technology Div.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Chem. Eng. Data; (United States); Journal Volume: 34:1

TITLE: Product yields and kinetics from the vapor phase cracking of wood pyrolysis tars
AUTHORS: Boroson, M L; Howard, J B; Peters, W A
SUBJECT: 09 BIOMASS FUELS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; ETHYLENE; CHEMICAL REACTION YIELD; METHANE; WOOD; PYROLYSIS; ACTIVATION ENERGY; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; COMBUSTION CONTROL; ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY MODELS; ALKANES; ALKENES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONTROL; CONVERSION; DECOMPOSITION; ENERGY; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; YIELDS; 090400* - Solid Waste & Wood Fuels- (-1989); 090121 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Chemical Synthesis- (1976-1989); 400800 - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry
DESCRIPTION: The homogeneous vapor phase cracking of newly formed wood pyrolysis tar was studied at low molar concentrations as a function of temperature (773 - 1.073 K), at residence times of 0.9 - 2.2 s. Tar conversions ranged from about 5 to 88%. The tars were generated by low heating rate (0.2 K/s) pyrolysis of --2 cm deep beds of sweet gum hardwood, and then rapidly conveyed to an adjacent reactor for controlled thermal treatment. Quantitative yields and kinetics were obtained for tar cracking and resulting product formation. The major tar conversion product was carbon monoxide, which accounted for over two-thirds of the tar lost at high severities. Corresponding ethylene and methane yields were each about 10% of the converted tar. Coke formation was negligible and weight-average tar molecular weight declined with increasing tar conversion.
RELATION: Journal Name: A.I.Ch.E. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 35:1

TITLE: Modeling of the thermal n-octane oxidation in the liquid phase
AUTHORS: Garcia-Ochoa, F; Romero, A; Querol, J
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; ALCOHOLS; CHEMICAL REACTION YIELD; KETONES; OCTANE; OXIDATION; ORGANIC ACIDS; CALCULATION METHODS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; EQUATIONS; LIQUIDS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; OXYGEN; PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS; PARTIAL PRESSURE; PHASE STUDIES; REGRESSION ANALYSIS; THERMAL CYCLING; ALKANES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; KINETICS; MATHEMATICS; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; STATISTICS; YIELDS; 020500* - Petroleum- Products & By-Products; 020400 - Petroleum- Processing; 090200 - Alcohol Fuels- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Thermal n-octane oxidation in the liquid phase is studied. Molecular schemes of reactions with two possibilities of kinetic equations used for lumping compounds are tested. Parameters are calculated by a multiresponse linear method, and discrimination among kinetic models is carried out applying both statistical and physical criteria. The production rate and distribution of the products of interest, such as ketones, alcohols, and acids, are described, after the relationships of the parameters with temperature and oxygen partial pressure are established by nonlinear regression.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. de Ingenieria Quimica, Facultad de CC Quimicas, Univ. Complutense, Madrid (ES)
RELATION: Journal Name: Ind. Eng. Chem. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 28:1

TITLE: Viscosity of pure hydrocarbons
AUTHORS: Knapstad, B; Skjolsvik, P A; Oye, H A
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 02 PETROLEUM; HYDROCARBONS; VISCOSITY; ALKANES; BENZENE; CYCLOHEXANE; DATA ANALYSIS; DECANE; HEPTANE; MEASURING METHODS; OCTANE; AROMATICS; CYCLOALKANES; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; 090110* - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989); 020500 - Petroleum- Products & By-Products
DESCRIPTION: Accurate viscosity measurements have been performed on eight pure hydrocarbons at atmospheric pressure in the temperature range 20-150/sup 0/C, or up to approximately 20/sup 0/C below the boiling point of the hydrocarbon, by use of an absolute oscillating viscometer. The hydrocarbons are cyclohexane and benzene and the n-alkanes of hexane, heptane, octane, decane, dodecane, and tetradecane. The viscosities are described with a modified Arrhenius equation, and the deviation in fit is 0.12% or less. The accuracy is estimated to be 0.33-0.56%. The lowest viscosities are assumed to have the highest deviation. Literature data reported by Dymond and Young normally fit our viscosities within our estimated accuracy. Other literature viscosities tend to be higher than our results, especially for the n-alkanes.
RESEARCH_ORG: Trondheim Univ. (Norway)
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Chem. Eng. Data; (United States); Journal Volume: 34:1

TITLE: The roles of carbon dioxide in methanol synthesis
AUTHORS: Lee, S; Parameswaran, V R; Wender, I; Kulik, C J
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 09 BIOMASS FUELS; CARBON DIOXIDE; HYDROGENATION; METHANOL; SYNTHESIS; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CATALYSTS; CATALYTIC CRACKING; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; CHEMICAL REACTORS; CHEMICAL SHIFT; CHEMISTRY; COPPER OXIDES; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; SIMULATION; SYNGAS PROCESS; THERMODYNAMICS; ZINC OXIDES; ALCOHOLS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COPPER COMPOUNDS; CRACKING; DATA; DECOMPOSITION; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; MANAGEMENT; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PROCESSING; PYROLYSIS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; WASTE MANAGEMENT; WASTE PROCESSING; ZINC COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 091000 - Biomass Fuels- Properties & Composition- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: The roles played by carbon dioxide in the chemistry of methanol synthesis over CuO/ZnO/Al/sub 2/O/sub 3/ catalysts have been experimentally investigated. It is concluded based on reaction rate measurements and thermodynamic considerations, that the two reactions that best describe the chemical system of methanol synthesis are the CO/sub 2/-hydrogenation and water-gas shift reactions. It is found that the presence of CO/sub 2/ is vital for maintaining the catalytic activity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fuel Science and Technology International; (USA); Journal Volume: 7:8

TITLE: Alumina supported Co-Mo oxides as a catalyst for hydrodesulphurisation of organic sulfides and disulphides using stopped flow gas chromatography
AUTHORS: Ali, L H; Sulaiman, S T; AlTamer, M Y
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 02 PETROLEUM; HYDROCARBONS; CATALYTIC CRACKING; SULFIDES; DESULFURIZATION; ACTIVATION ENERGY; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CATALYSTS; COBALT OXIDES; GAS CHROMATOGRAPHY; MOLYBDENUM OXIDES; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMATOGRAPHY; COBALT COMPOUNDS; CRACKING; DECOMPOSITION; ENERGY; MOLYBDENUM COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PYROLYSIS; REFRACTORY METAL COMPOUNDS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 100200* - Synthetic Fuels- Production- (1990-); 020400 - Petroleum- Processing
DESCRIPTION: The authors present a model study on the hydrodesulphurization of dimethyl sulphide, di n-prophyl sulphide, di n-butyl sulphide and dimethyl disulphide on Co-Mo-Al/sub 2/O/sub 3/ surface conducted using stopped-flow chromatographic technique. The plots for the rates of hydrocarbon formation agree well with the first order reaction at the surface of the catalyst.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fuel Science and Technology International; (USA); Journal Volume: 7:8

TITLE: Natural gas as the fuel for the future
AUTHORS: Rogner, H H
SUBJECT: 03 NATURAL GAS; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 33 ADVANCED PROPULSION SYSTEMS; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; GASOLINE; FUEL SUBSTITUTION; INTERNAL COMBUSTION ENGINES; SYNTHETIC FUELS; NATURAL GAS; MARKET; ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY SUPPLIES; EUROPE; FORECASTING; METHANE; ROAD TRANSPORT; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; ALKANES; CONVERSION; ENERGY SOURCES; ENGINES; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; HEAT ENGINES; HYDROCARBONS; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; LAND TRANSPORT; LIQUID FUELS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; TRANSPORT; 030600* - Natural Gas- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 294003 - Energy Planning & Policy- Natural Gas; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 330800 - Emission Control- Alternative Fuels; 320200 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Transportation; 100700 - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: This article is a critical analysis of a study which examines the prospects for natural gas use in Western Europe. The study attempts to forecast the market share that will be held by natural gas compared with other sources of fuel in the transportation and other industries. Based on analysis of the study the author concludes that the target of a 20% CO{sub 2} emission reduction for Western Europe by the year 2005 appears technically and economically feasible.
RELATION: Journal Name: Annual Review of Energy; (USA); Journal Volume: 14

TITLE: Energy and transportation in the United States
AUTHORS: Ross, M
SUBJECT: 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 33 ADVANCED PROPULSION SYSTEMS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; FUELS; ECONOMICS; PETROLEUM; FUEL SUBSTITUTION; TRANSPORTATION SECTOR; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; USA; AIR POLLUTION; PUBLIC POLICY; SYNTHETIC FUELS; ENERGY SOURCES; FOSSIL FUELS; NORTH AMERICA; POLLUTION; 320200* - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Transportation; 330800 - Emission Control- Alternative Fuels; 320301 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Industrial & Agricultural Processes- Energy Sources; 100700 - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-); 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology
DESCRIPTION: In this paper, energy use in all areas of transportation is analyzed. Issues facing the largest of the activities, personal passenger transportation based on petroleum fuels, are explored in depth: the reasons for past and future growth in driving, the past developments in fuel economy, and the possibilities for change in the next one to two decades. This look involves the technical potential for further improvements in fuel economy and reduction in air pollution, the role of the market in these areas, and the role of public polices. Other fuel options and other transportation modes are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Annual Review of Energy; (USA); Journal Volume: 14

TITLE: Road transport fuel pricing policy
AUTHORS: Newbery, D M
SUBJECT: 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 33 ADVANCED PROPULSION SYSTEMS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; DIESEL FUELS; PRICES; GASOLINE; ROAD TRANSPORT; FUEL SUBSTITUTION; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; ENERGY POLICY; ETHANOL FUELS; METHANOL FUELS; VEHICLES; ALCOHOL FUELS; FUELS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LAND TRANSPORT; LIQUID FUELS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; SYNTHETIC FUELS; TRANSPORT; 320200* - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Transportation; 330800 - Emission Control- Alternative Fuels; 100700 - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-); 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: This paper discusses pricing of road transport fuels, which account for the bulk of all transport fuels. Although diesel and gasoline are the dominant road fuels, some countries have, at various times, encouraged the use of alternative fuels such as methanol and ethanol. According to the author, these fuels should be priced according to the same principles that guide the pricing of gasoline and diesel. Some qualifications to this are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Annual Review of Energy; (USA); Journal Volume: 14

TITLE: Selective synthesis of dimethylamine over small-pore zeolites IV. Effects of SiO sub 2 and Al sub 2 O sub 3 coatings
AUTHORS: Bergna, H E; Keane, M Jr; Sonnichsen, G C; Abrams, L; Shannon, R D; Ralston, D H
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; AMINES; SYNTHESIS; CATALYSTS; SURFACE COATING; ZEOLITES; SPECIFICITY; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; AMMONIA; CATALYTIC EFFECTS; CHEMICAL PREPARATION; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CORRELATIONS; DEACTIVATION; HEXANE; METHANOL; MICROSTRUCTURE; SILICON OXIDES; SORPTION; THICKNESS; ALCOHOLS; ALKANES; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; DEPOSITION; DIMENSIONS; HYDRIDES; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; MATERIALS; MINERALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; 102000* - Synthetic Fuels- Products & By-Products- (1990-)
DESCRIPTION: Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} and SiO{sub 2} coatings are effective in increasing dimethylamine (DMA) and decreasing trimethylamine (TMA) selectivities of small-pore zeolites H-RHO and H-ZK-5 used as methylamine catalysts. The H-RHO catalysts typically contain chabazite or chabazite and pollucite impurities. SiO{sub 2} is more effective than Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} for improving DMA selectivity. SiO{sub 2} coatings from monosilicic acid (MSA) reduce dimethyl ether (DME) yields over shallow-bed nitrogen (SBN)-calcined H-RHO, whereas Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} coatings and SiO{sub 2} coatings (from tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS)) do not. Correlations between thickness of SiO{sub 2} (TEOS or MSA) coatings and DMA selectivity as well as a decrease in the n-hexane rate of sorption suggest a physical hindrance to egress of TMA from RHO channels and cages to the product stream. Coating deep-bed calcined H-pollucite with either Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} or SiO{sub 2} from TEOS reduces activity and increases DMA selectivity through deactivation of nonselective surface sites. Improvement of DMA selectivity by coating DB-calcined H-RHO catalysts occurs primarily from (i) H-RHO port constriction and (ii) deactivation of external acid sites of H-RHO and H-pollucite and secondarily from deactivation of H-chabazite. Improvement of DMA selectivity by coating SBN-calcined H-HO catalysts occurs primarily from (i) H-RHO port constriction and (ii) further deactivation of external acid sites of H-RHO and amorphous H-chabazite and secondarily from the deactivation of H-pollucite. SiO{sub 2} coatings on H-ZK-5 increased DMA selectivity and decreased DME yields, but reduced activity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Journal of Catalysis; (USA); Journal Volume: 115:1

TITLE: An electrically driven multistage countercurrent solvent extraction device
AUTHORS: Scott, T C; Wham, R M
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; SOLVENT EXTRACTION; PHASE STUDIES; ACETIC ACID; DATA ANALYSIS; DISPERSIONS; ELECTRIC FIELDS; KETONES; MASS TRANSFER; SCALE MODELS; CARBOXYLIC ACIDS; EXTRACTION; MONOCARBOXYLIC ACIDS; ORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; STRUCTURAL MODELS; 020400* - Petroleum- Processing; 090100 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- (-1989); 400105 - Separation Procedures
DESCRIPTION: An electrically-driven, high-surface-area solvent extraction system has been conceived and tested. The system accomplishes droplet formation, coalescence, and phase separation utilizing a single electric field while operating under countercurrent flow conditions. The mass-transport capability of this system has been analyzed by observing the transfer of acetic acid from water (dispersed phase) into methyl isobutyl ketone. Results are reported in terms of the number of theoretical transfer stages per centimeter of column. The emulsion-phase contactor, which has 1.7 stages/cm, outperforms laboratory-scale versions of the York-Scheibel column by a factor of 17 and the Podbielniak centrifugal contactor by a factor of 10. The mass-transfer performance along with the minimal energy requirements of this conceptual device combine to make it an attractive possibility for greatly enhanced solvent extraction operations.
RESEARCH_ORG: Oak Ridge National Lab., Oak Ridge, TN (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: Ind. Eng. Chem. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 28:1

TITLE: Diesel particulate emissions
AUTHORS: Williams, P T; Abbass, M K; Andrews, G E; Bartle, K D
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; DIESEL FUELS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; CHROMATOGRAPHY; COMBUSTION KINETICS; EMISSION; PARTICULATES; POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC HYDROCARBONS; AROMATICS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PARTICLES; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; REACTION KINETICS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; 090110* - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989); 400800 - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry; 500200 - Environment, Atmospheric- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The relationship between diesel fuel composition and that of the solvent organic fraction of diesel particulates was investigated for an old DI Petter engine and a modern DI Perkins engine. Polycyclic aromatic compounds (PAC) were identified using high-resolution capillary column chromatography with a parallel triple detector system for polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH), nitrogen-containing PAH, and sulphur-containing PAH. Identification of the PAC using retention indexes was confirmed using an ion trap detector, which was also used to quantify the low-concentration (<1 ppm) benzo(a)pyrene. It was conclusively shown for both engines that the bulk of the particulate solvent organic fraction, including the PAH fraction, was unburned fuel. However, there was some evidence that high molecular weight five-ring PAH may have an in-cylinder formation contribution, and it is postulated that this could be due to pyrolysis of lower molecular weight unburned fuel PAH. The contribution of lubricating oil to the particulate PAC is discussed, and evidence is presented that shows the unburned fuel PAC accumulates in the lubricating oil and thus contributes to the particulate PAC via the large lubricating oil component of the particulate PAC.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Fuel and Energy, Univ. of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT (GB); Dept. of Physical Chemistry, Univ. of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT (GB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Combust. Flame; (United States); Journal Volume: 75:1

TITLE: The isolation of precursors responsible for insolubles formation in mid-distillate diesel fuels
AUTHORS: Wechter, M A; Hardy, D R
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; DIESEL FUELS; SOLVENT EXTRACTION; METHANOL; SOLVENT PROPERTIES; BY-PRODUCTS; CATALYTIC CRACKING; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; PETROLEUM DISTILLATES; PRECURSOR; ALCOHOLS; CRACKING; DATA; DECOMPOSITION; DISTILLATES; ENERGY SOURCES; EXTRACTION; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM; PETROLEUM FRACTIONS; PETROLEUM PRODUCTS; PYROLYSIS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; 020500* - Petroleum- Products & By-Products; 020400 - Petroleum- Processing; 090100 - Hydrocarbon Fuels- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Extraction of mid-distillate fuels with methanol has been found to reduce the tendency of the fuels tested to form insolubles under conditions of accelerated aging. The effect is most pronounced among those fuels which contain catalytically cracked light cycle oils. Extraction of four test fuels, 70/30 blends of straight run stocks and light cycle oils, with aqueous base indicated that base extraction had little to no effect on insolubles formation. A fuel blending experiment, which involved blending several straight runs with various light cycle oils, implicates the catalytically cracked light cycle oils as primary repositories of the precursor materials which bring about the formation of insolubles. The methanol extract may serve as a chemical probe for the sediment precursors and may thus function as an indicator for instability under long term storage conditions.
RESEARCH_ORG: Southeastern Massachusetts Univ., Dept. of Chemistry, N. Dartmouth, MA (US); Naval Research Lab., Washington, DC (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: Fuel Sci. Technol. Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:4

TITLE: Pressure and temperature dependence of reactions proceeding via a bound complex
AUTHORS: Stewart, P H; Golden, D M; Larson, C W
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; ETHANE; COMBUSTION; METHANE; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALKANES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; HYDROCARBONS; KINETICS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDATION; REACTION KINETICS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; 090110* - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989); 400800 - Combustion, Pyrolysis, & High-Temperature Chemistry
DESCRIPTION: Elementary bimolecular processes that involve the formation of a chemically activated intermediate are common. In a previous paper the authors described the formation required to ensure that a kinetic model extrapolates the rate constants involved over wide ranges of temperature and pressure. This approach is illustrated here for the system centered around the ethane intermediate. It is necessary and sufficient to specify the temperature and pressure dependence of three rate constants k(T,P) and the temperature dependence of two equilibrium constants K(T), viz., C/sub 2/H/sub 6/ ..-->.. CH/sub 3/+CH/sub 3/ k/sub luni/(T,P), K(T); CH/sub 3/+CH/sub 3/ ..-->.. C/sub 2/H/sub 5/+H k/sub bi/(T,P); C/sub 2/H/sub 6/ ..-->.. C/sub 2/H/sub 5/+H k/sub 2uni/(T,P), K(T). Rate constants are cast in the form of an analytical expression and appropriate parameters are tabulated.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Chemical Kinetics, Chemical Physics Lab., SRI International, Menlo Park, CA (US); Univ. of Dayton, Research Institute, Air Force Astronautics Lab. (LKCS), Edwards Air Force Base, CA (US)
RELATION: Journal Name: Combust. Flame; (United States); Journal Volume: 75:1

TITLE: CO hydrogenation over alumina-supported sulfide cluster catalysts
AUTHORS: Thompson, Jr, L T; Curtis, M D
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; METHANE; CATALYTIC CONVERTERS; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CARBON MONOXIDE; CHEMICAL REACTION YIELD; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGENATION; IRON; METHANATION; METHYL ETHER; MOLYBDENUM; SYNTHESIS; ALKANES; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; EQUIPMENT; ETHERS; METALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; YIELDS; 090121* - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Chemical Synthesis- (1976-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Bimetallic Mo-Fea nd Mo-Co sulfide clusters were anchored on Al/sub 2/O/sub 3/ and used for CO hydrogenation. In addition to methane, significant amounts of dimethyl ether were produced. The reaction orders obtained from power rate laws for methanation indicated that the surfaces of the catalytic ensembles were not completely saturated by CO, in contrast to the observations for most conventional CO hydrogenation catalysts. A kinetic analysis and parameter estimation was performed to identify the rate-determining step for methanation. A catalytic cycle was postulated that could account not only for the formation of methane and higher hydrocarbons, but also for dimethyl ether as a primary product.
RELATION: Journal Name: A.I.Ch.E. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 35:1

TITLE: Transportation energy futures
AUTHORS: Sperling, D; DeLuchi, M A
SUBJECT: 33 ADVANCED PROPULSION SYSTEMS; 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ENVIRONMENT; SAFETY; PETROLEUM; FUEL SUBSTITUTION; SYNTHETIC FUELS; FORECASTING; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROGEN; METHANOL FUELS; TRANSPORTATION SECTOR; ALCOHOL FUELS; ELEMENTS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; NONMETALS; 330800* - Emission Control- Alternative Fuels; 100700 - Synthetic Fuels- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects- (1990-); 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: In the 1970s the preferred petroleum alternatives were so-called synthetic fuels made from coal and oil shale that imitated gasoline and diesel fuel. Around 1984 or so, conventional wisdom shifted to methanol as the fuel of the future. In both cases a driving force was the perception of a lack of adaptability by the oil and automobile industries. Resistance to fuels different from gasoline and diesel fuel eased in light of the economic and environmental problems of synfuels. In this paper, the authors address the following questions: Will economic forces motivate another shift, to natural gas Will environmental forces compel an even more drastic shift, to hydrogen or electric vehicles
RELATION: Journal Name: Annual Review of Energy; (USA); Journal Volume: 14
